It was kind of random how this large space was taken up by a few random things thrown on the ground, literally. I think these items should be placed in the playground area. Maybe more seating so people can sit and relax while the bands play?

I can only assume the type of music changes since someone said they play reggae music too. This bad was pretty emo and low key, very enjoyable for a date night. Unlike Fremont street that plays music which encourages lots of screaming, dancing around, and it's just a different scene. At the park, I saw many couples and people on dates. There was one group of people getting drunk and rowdy, and they looked kind of out of place. It's a great place to people watch and with that being said, there are tables surrounding the play area in the middle. You can't sit at the tables with heaters unless you eat at the tables. You can't just sit there with alcohol you get from a bar or restaurant. I saw a security guard go up to a group and tell them to move because they were drinking and sitting. Apparently it's ok if they moved to a bench about 3 feet away, you just can't sit at the tables and drink. But I guess you can sit and not drink since that's what we did at first and we were not bothered. I am not sure if the guard was picking on these people or what the deal was, but they ended up buying popcorn just to be able to sit there. 

My hubby went to get a beer and the guard didn't bother us for sitting with alcohol. There is a sign though that says if you sit there, you need to eat. I later saw it after we had been sitting there for a while. I did not go inside the restaurants, but I can assume by the size of each restaurant/store that there is no dine in seating in the majority of the restaurants. Also, it appeared that everyone was sitting outdoors and eating at the Pork and Beans restaurant. I am all for outdoor eating, but I kind of expect that with less expensive food, or casual cafes, but I don't believe these restaurants were that cheap. I could be wrong, as I said I did not go inside them, I just glanced over them as I walked by. 

I also liked how the music played throughout the park on the speakers, so even if you did not sit near the stage, you could enjoy the music. I love the lights at the park, the store designs in containers, and 5 stars to the fire breathing praying mantis! Every time he shot out fire, people screamed and jumped. It was quite a scene to watch. This place has so much potential and is very trendy. I do have to say that the stores are tiny, only a few people can fit in them at a time, and I don't believe they appeal to most people. I did not see anyone inside the stores and I actually thought they were closed! Surprisingly they were open but they looked dark from the outside. 

I hope that they open up some more stores that appeal to more people and hope they expand since there is not much here. I walked by every store in 15 min and was done. I even went inside almost all of them. It has so much potential and I love the idea, so I just hope there is more to it as time goes on.
My kids love this place. Great for adults and kids anytime of the day. The have movie nights during the week and at night the place closes down for adults only.

Wonderful place to bring the kids, go on a romantic date, enjoy a concert or a picnic. I have been here many times and I have painted, watched movies in the park, listened to live bands, amongst other invigorating activities. Plus the food and shops are amazing. Really a one stop shop for everyone! Soak up the sun and good vibes, or sip on some wine and dine; either way a good time is inevitable.

Loved this place! Kids had a blast playing. The shops are really cool. It is extremely small and hard to maneuver around with a stroller though. We spent a few hours playing in the tree house and walking around. The preying mantis was phenomenal! Will definitely go back soon.

A great new addition to the Fremont St area.We were on a pub crawl as a group and stopped for a bite to eat .Everything you need was there food, drink , music, washrooms.I was impressed and will be back next year, keep rezitalizing the area it will draw more people.

This is a cool hip place to take your hipster friends from out of town. The pace is made out of shipping containers brightly painted and stacked together. Right at the front there is a giant metal praying mantis that shoots fire at night (first seen at burning man festival) it has cool shops and eats plus a small park for the kids and free concerts. 

You do have to pay for parking.

Super cool area to visit just off the strip. Every building is crafted from containers, which gives this area a distinct feel and a cool aesthetic. It's the perfect place for a Sunday coffee and stroll, maybe a good chat. I've only stopped by once, but given the space they have and the stage, I'm sure they have little concerts and such in this area. 

Plus they have a little play area for kids, so it's a great spot to bring the family!  There's a good mix of food, coffee, and shopping here to explore, with a vintage store, and some nice views from the second level.

Parking is pretty easy, with streets nearby to find a spot. Definitely go check out The Perch if you're coming here. It's a great brunch spot, and I hear its not bad for dinner/drinks either!
I don't shop or have kids so this place was really boring.  There are playgrounds and a toy store and a bunch of small business shops and restaurants.  It's very clean and safe though.

I'm from Las Vegas. Born and raised. So, to me, it's exciting when new things are being built.

The Praying Mantis at the opening is as cool as it gets however.

First of all ,parking is ridiculous, be prepared to make a few rounds. And if you are there during "business" hours, be prepared to pay.

I came here with my brother, my mom and my daughter today. My brother is on crutches, and is well over 6feet tall. My daughter is one, so I had the stroller with me. 

These containers are way too small to be stores. Sure, they're "boutiques" but the small space is not cool. We all could only go into one store, the red stitch that was a "double" container. Super close quarters.

I find this place to be overpriced. There really isn't anything unique for sale, like I was expecting..... You could go to town square and probably pay less.


If you are claustrophobic, this is not the place for you. It was hard enough to maneuver with the stroller, I could only imagine how my brother felt.

There aren't many food places here. To be completely honest, the food court at the galleria looks more promising.

Playground looks cool, but that's about it.

Has potential, but it has some growing pains to go through.

Great new addition to the downtown area of Vegas. Easy to find and easy to find parking. Go at night. The large praying mantis breathes fire at night. Since they seem to be adding more and more all the time it's a great place to try more than once.

LOVE this! I've been hiding from downtown Las Vegas and now I'm not sure why.  The praying mantis greets you at the entrance and it went off twice while we were there, shooting flames from its antennae. It's was pretty freaking awesome even though I originally thought they were gunshots and that I had been brought here to die. It was also surprisingly cozy at the chilly night. 

The park itself is made up of those shipping/freight containers (not containers from the Container Store as I had previously imagined). The containers now house very cute shops that sell cupcakes, trinkets, clothes, beef jerky, etc. There are also a lot of very interesting and enticing looking restaurants and food options and, like so many other places in Vegas, you can just wander about with alcohol. 

The BEST part of the park, however, is the tree house and play area in the middle, which is not just for kids (things that are not allowed include pets, drinks and food; there are security people there and they're serious about this). The tree house is fun to climb on even for grown ups and has lots of fun slides, including a two-story slide that's pretty intense. The security guide who stands there to ensure that only one person goes on the slide at a time suggesting I pick my feet up so I did. I suspect he was trying to kill me because I ended up doing a complete 180 degree spin on the slide and came out upside down. 

There is also a light game where you can compete by hitting the lights. Which was surprisingly fun even for someone who usually tries to avoid movement and I highly encourage anyone to give it a shot even if you see other people playing it and looking crazy. Also, blocks for building forts :)

Love this palace.  If you're a big fan of the Tiny Homes movement like me, this place is a must visit.  I can't wait to purchase my first Tiny home.

The recycled containers are fantastic.  Love the vertical tower design. They have a nice courtyard where kids can play, and a stage for performances designed for locals and visitors. 

There are plenty of shopping here, local businesses. Please support them. There is a very tiny coffee shop. You order on the side, outside like a drive thru.  Don't forget to checkout the dinosaur up front, and bring a key lock to share.

Cheers!

Love bringing out kids here. The playground is great - the shops and restaurants are great - and it's never really that busy, despite being so close to Fremont Street and all the tourists that are there. We only hope they fix the slides, because they have been broken for a while now.
One of our favorite spots to stop at when we come to Vegas. Love the feel of it, very PNW. Great options of food and drinks. Plus some cute stores to shop out.

Crazy loud!

This is a review for the Downtown Container Park after 9pm.  This is when it becomes an adults-only area.  We were looking for a place to hang out and enjoy some drinks and chitchat that was away from the madness of Fremont Street.  The Container Park was clean, well-lit, patrolled by security, and an easy walk from east Fremont.  The lack of under 21s was refreshing.  So what was the problem?  The live entertainment.  I appreciate live entertainment but when you're in a small area and just want to drink a beer and talk with your friends, it's hard when you have to scream.  (Nothing against the band - it was just the venue that was a problem).  If I want my eardrums to bleed, I'll go back to Fremont Street.

We wound up just strolling through quickly and playing on the awesome playground "for kids of all ages" before leaving.  It was too loud to eat or drink in comfort, plus most of the eating is outdoor.  I'm glad the stores were closed.  From a quick glance, it looked like a bunch of mixed media crafts made by local, well-meaning self-professed "artists" who would usually make their living on Etsy.  I would have felt bad about not buying anything.

I will probably go back during the day and give it another try.  Fingers crossed that there isn't live (un)entertainment.

I realize the Container Park was a bit controversial because it's part of the urban gentrification, residents need a grocery store not a nut tray made of an old wine bottle, blah blah blah.  Well, tough.  That fire hazard/vagrants' lot was abandoned for a very long time before it was finally bulldozed and turned into the Container Park.  The gradual clean-up of downtown now finally extends past East Fremont.  A year ago, I would not have felt safe walking past the Ruby Slipper neon sign.  Thanks to the Container Park, I'm now more comfortable heading out further.  To be fair, it's not so much a service as it is a destination.  It requires a bit of effort to get there.  I have no idea who would deliberately seek out the merchandise sold there except out of kindhearted patronization.  Regardless, I hope it stays.

In A Nutshell:

*A local Vegas buddy took us to this brand-new (3 months at the time of this review) spot in the Arts District.
*I love the upcycle/recycle use of these containers (we called them connexes in the Army).
*Each one was made into a mini-bar, restaurant, shop or art gallery. Super-clever.
*This is hipster-hangout-central.

Overall, you can't miss Container Park, especially with the HUGE, fire-breathing Praying Mantis in the entrance.

Five words: Giant, fire-breathing preying mantis.

I visited on a quiet afternoon on an unbearably hot summer Sunday. I had a coffee, checked out some shops, and sat at a table and watched some kids/parents run around in the treehouse. Aside from the heat, I didn't feel like I was in Vegas (that's a good thing). This is a unique, fresh and fun addition to the downtown area.

I vacationed here in Vegas and this park wasn't what I'd expect in Vegas. So cool and unexpected. The ambience and energy was awesome! There are some cute boutiques and eateries. Great experience for sure!

We came to this place around 4 pm yesterday. Although I was freezing my children and I enjoyed it very much.  I climbed on this huge tree house sliding with my 4-year-old girl and I laughed so hard that  I  could heard my echo.  I'm not a kid but I had fun and so did  my kiddos who climbed on it  more than 3 times lol. It is great! 

I'm coming back this weekend to eat at pinches tacos and to see some show there.

This place blew my mind... stepping into Container Park can make you forget what city your in. We came here on a Friday night to see the fire spewing preying mantis after we got done cruising the Fremont Experience and ended up chilling here for awhile to check everything out.

The guys from Zappos have really changed this section of downtown Vegas for the good... it was so cool to see a place for kids to play at night while the adults get to chill with a drink and listen to some good music in a safe, lax environment. From a sustainability aspect, I really applaud the use of the old shipping containers as building materials... I think a lot of people will walk away from this place with new ideas for the future.

Because who doesn't love large adult playgrounds with a treehouse and never ending  slides surrounded by booze, food, and candy?!  

This place is so random it's awesome.  Out front you'll be greeted by a ginormous praying mantis that spouts fire at night at no particular times, only whenever they feel like it.  Feeling shaggy?  Get a haircut in the train located next to the front stage.  The workers walk around with ukuleles and there's a mexican food place that clearly says 'Real Mexican Food By Real Mexicans'.  Rad.  

Go here and feel like a grown up ass kid all over again.

This place is the artsy gem of Downtown Las Vegas in my opinion.  We decided to check this place out while finishing up our evening stroll down Fremont Street (awesome experience as well).

The entrance to the Container Park is guarded by this fire breathing praying mantis so prepare for scorching blast of heat in your face whenever it goes off and loud effects (NOTE: Not for the faint-of-heart. I always walk by praying it won't go off because it goes off unexpectedly and scared the crap out of me! Pardon my language). It startled myself and a couple of others around the area half to death.Once you're in the park, things are a little more calm.  The decor and lighting of the place is just beautiful (you have to go at night to fully experience it).  You don't feel like you are in Vegas anymore, the park blocks off the casinos and the bright lights.  I definitely felt more safe and comfortable, I was definitely digging the vibe.  

There are many small art stores and bar/restaurants in this area.  If you are hungry, check out Big Erns BBQ or if you want a small bite I recommend getting some jerky and nuts at JoJo's Jerky.  This place is also a great place to just explore. There's live music on weekends and a fun play area for the kids. Make sure you go to the 3rd floor to get a pretty view of the park, it looks gorgeous.  There is also a super tall slide in the middle of the park which my boyfriend and I decided to do (hey, it's not just for kids), It is definitely a fun, unique experience away from the stereotypical feel of Las Vegas.  

This place is wonderful and a great escape if you are looking to get away from the gambling and drinking for a bit. Definitely family-friendly!

The Container Park is a unique experience with a wonderful collections of shops, food, unique offerings, clothing and nick nacks. Lots to do for the kids if you have little ones with you. Also lots of food and beverage options with plenty of outdoor seating. Just minutes from the bottom end of the Fremont experience. 

Parking is easy and inexpensive. The place is safe and compact. To save its name, there is one container on site, as part of a walkway. Admission is free. 

2016 Review #67

After spending over $300 for a meal,  the security guard comes inside the restaurant and states curfew is enforced at 9pm and that we have to leave. We had my 16 year old nephew with us. On the way out,  we stopped at a candy store and began to pick out chocolates. She came in that store and kicked us out.  So apparently they will kick you out while you are actively spending money in the restaurants and stores to enforce the BS curfew. It's 9:10pm on a Saturday night and he is well behaved. I don't see the big deal.  I am curious to see the future of Container Park and its stores if they keep throwing out paying customers. Good luck with that!  There's plenty of other businesses that will gladly take our money

I absolutely love this place! Shops, restaurants, and bars created out of shipping containers (think Wall-E). As you walk you pass a huge flaming praying mantis. At night he comes alive to put on a show. As you walk in there is a large playground made out of (you guessed it) containers. After 9pm, when it is a 21+ container park, the adults take over the play equipment. There is a stage in the back complete with misters for those hot summer days. We stopped by Oak & Ivy, a whiskey bar with flair. Dinner was at The Perch, a second story modern diner with a view. Shopping was fun with unique, locally owned stores. This is one of those places with something for everyone.

I'm a fan of Downtown Container Park. It's a family-friendly haven offering all the excitement and energy of Vegas without the ringing of casinos and stomping of stilettos. 

Stacked containers hold a variety of shops, restaurants, and bars and wrap around a giant playground (kid AND adult-friendly!) plus a lawn area/stage showcasing live entertainment. 

I've enjoyed the musical performances and restaurant experiences... and the playground ain't so bad either. This "park" is free entry, so go on and check it out if you're in the area!

Cute and fun place to hang out and day drink or pregame before heading out.

During the day time container park is open to everyone then at night it is 21 plus.  I love the 3 story slide right in the middle.  The "containers" are fun little bars. I especially like Bin 702 and their turkey and Brie panini. 

There are a few quirky retail shops but the main thing to do here is eat, drink and have fun with friends.

Love love love!! It's amazing how much Downtown Las Vegas is building and transforming into the creative, family-friendly and hip area it is. Container Park is definitely a spot to visit if you are in Downtown Las Vegas, or if you want to listen to good live music, see local artists' work, and eat local good food. It's also such a cute setting. After I came here for the first time with a few friends, I knew I had to take my boyfriend here for a date night (tonight). We both had such a good time :)

When I posted about Container Park on Facebook during my Christmas 2017 holiday I had a hard time explaining exactly what Container Park is. Basically what it is are shipping and storage containers that is turned into functioning stores and placed in a complex. It was cool to see that you can make a storage container into a store. Imagine this for housing. Could this be the solution to resolving the housing crisis in my home town of Vancouver? Most of the stores are clothing stores. It is a small complex, therefore, selection as to what the stores actually are is limited in terms of variety but it is still worth it to check out. There is a hipster vibe to it which was very refreshing after being on the Strip. The best part is that this is way off the Strip and requires a bus trip (we had a 3 day bus pass). It was a welcome break. We stayed at night to see the fire breathing Mantis. Yes I uploaded the 30 second video on my Facebook and Instagram.

Live music, good selection of drinks, a few places to eat, and no cover ... what more can you ask for? Actually, I am impressed by the bartenders at the Oak & Ivy ... I watched them a while, true bartenders making gorgeous drinks. We are a bit of beer snobs and found their selection on tap very tasty. 

The playground in the middle of the container park is open for adults ... must do! 

A fun place with a cool vibe!

Nice place to go for the afternoon especially if you've got kids. Food selection is okay. I had a hot dog from the hot dog place. Some boutique stores but most were overpriced hand made art. If the weather is too hot, it will be unpleasant. Excellent art pieces, the container and the huge grasshopper in front.

Love it! It's a great, unique spot. It's basically an open air mall and gathering spot that's made all out of shipping containers. It's totally cool. There's live music, a place for kiddos to play, places to eat, places to drink, and places to shop. It's fairly small, but definitely a fun place to spend an afternoon - wander around and window shop, grab a bite to eat, and have a couple of drinks. And there's a giant preying mantis too! I will definitely be back here many times. What a wonderful addition to downtown!

Cool spot to check out if you are in Old Town Las Vegas. Lots of fun stores and restaurants! 
 I did like the huge praying mantis statue and the heart with all the locks! There were some fun photo opportunities along the way.
We just walked through after having brunch and then we went to check out downtown. 
I think it's more focused for kiddos, which none of us have. Definitely a fun alternative for something to do with your kiddo to get away from the Strip!

Container Park was the perfect destination for us on a temperate Saturday night.  The weather was perfect.  Dina from Teazled was the consumate host and it was fun to browse her unique LGBTQ greeting cards and gifts.  Avalon Landing was on the main stage and began performing about halfway through our patio dining experience at The Perch.  The Perch blew away my expectations and will be a favorite dining spot for me because I live right down the street.  We explored the 4-story treehouse and excitedly went down the slide.  The upper stretch of the slide is really scary at night because you are in pitch black darkness for at least a couple of fast curves.  My arm hair and leg hair generated quite a bit of static electricity so all of you can geek out on that if you go down with your hairier guy friends.  My 6'1" frame actually got stuck in the upper tube for a split second but I forced myself to unstuck myself so I wouldn't get rammed from behind by the next slider.  I was impressed that even drunk bachelorette party participants have the good sense to wait 15-20 seconds after the person in from of them slides to slide down.  I expected to see more of a pile up but it didn't happen.  Awesome 360 degree views from the top level of the tree house and you can take great pics if you hold your camera phone right up against the square holes of the protective netting.  I need more Container Park in my life!

For Vegas, this place is pretty cool. For any other "real" city I'd say, eh, whatever, but here it's possible a respite can be found from the extreme horror that is the rest of the "city."

It was DEAD here on my visits because of the weather, but I was able to glean a few things:

--More of an attempt at "less is more"--smaller shops and restaurants, and a small entertainment area for live music.

--Decent restaurants and bars, including artisan cocktails.

--Too many sweets-only shops. Doesn't seem sustainable that around six places can sell only candy and survive.

--Retail stores here are kind of cheap. Made in China kind of junk. Would have expected more boutiques highlighting locals.

What's really to like is both the less-is-more approach with a walkable area and the lack of gaudiness that is the Strip, and the attempt to be green, the only one I saw citywide. There are actually multiple stations for recycling, trash, and compost--separately. I never saw this anywhere else in this town of excess and waste. For that reason alone, I hope more businesses and developers can find inspiration here.

This place is awesome! The whole concept of using shipping containers to build an entire shopping/entertainment complex is so cool! There's a fantastic play area for kids and adults alike also made of shipping containers. My little guy had a blast building with the huge foam blocks and climbing up the "treehouse" 
The shops are great, funky eclectic stores are my favorite. The gourmet hot dog place looked yummy but we weren't hungry. 
I guess after 9pm they ask anyone under 21 to leave and the whole place becomes something of a nightclub. The music gets louder and there's a "dj" in the praying mantis who's controlling the fire to go in time to the music. We just happened to be leaving at 9pm and the whole place was transforming from family shopping center to a lounge/bar scene. Great concept to capture both demographics. 
Can't wait to come back without the kiddo!

A nice break away from all the craziness of Vegas.  Kids get to run around and have fun, adults get to sit and relax a bit.  Make sure to grab a table in the shade.  It can get pretty full around lunch time.  

Plenty of decent looking food options immediately in the area.
Super cool place to take your family or just stroll through. There's also outdoor entertainment, which was nice. Definitely worth exploring.

Who would of known in this not so great part of Downtown Las Vegas lies a park made of storage containers? This place is fun for kids and adults. The perimeter of this place is surrounded by stacks of storage containers housing stores of unique shops, a mix of snack shops and artisan/hipster eateries. Southern part of the park lies a grassy areas and stage with live entertainment during the weekends. Winding slides, bridges, and climbing areas can be found in the center part of this park. The eclectic artwork adds quite a bit of charter to this place that would make it look very industrial without it. I didn't eat here but there's a cook toy shop with unique stuff you can't find at Toy's R Us if you're looking for something out of a norm for kids.

Definitely a cool and new place to check out if you're in town and tired of looking for stuff to do with the kids. This place is located a few blocks from Fremont Street Experience on 7th/Fremont Street.

This poor review is for the lack of information on their yelp site and business website. I looked this place up before bringing my children here. We're in vegas visiting my sick grandmother.  The kids have been cooped up in the ICU waiting room all day for about 4 days. We took them to the park to run around, but I decided to find something different that we cannot experience at home. The container park sounded like THE place for a unique kind of fun! Checked out the website,  it had a great yellow area telling us about how family friendly it is with a tree house, etc. I was excited! I mean, it's vegas, the adults playground,  so I was happy to find something unique for my kiddos. But there's a curfew!! Wtf?!?! No kids after 9!! Wtf?! Why have it be family friendly and then kick the kids out?? And why not boldly state that on the website?!  We wasted time and gas coming here, finding parking, walking, etc. Only to be promptly turned away since we got there at 8:45.... you guys suck...

Firstly, let me say that dealing with the poor parking situation is worth a visit to the downtown container park; don't let the cost or unavailability of spots deter you from enjoying the park. 

The park's center play area is monitored at each gate so that children can run freely in a contained environment (no container pun intended) without hesitation. 

Kids that love to run and climb will adore the central play area. Younger kids have the ability to build Legos on the Astroturf nearby the climbing area, yet the turf area is not enclosed for free run of its participants.

All of the businesses surrounding the play area are independent retailers rather than chains.  They offer a variety of shopping and food options.

Our visit occurred on Easter in March so the park was not too hot and rather nicely shaded. I would definitely advise taking caution on hotter days during summer months, but to say so seems incredibly obvious since the park is made of mostly metal containers. 

Overall, I was incredibly pleased with the central play area being so nicely monitored by security at both gates.

Actually I was surprised and amazed how downtown changed and what a place! I do not like to go this way because of parking. Paid parking lot just right there, what is already good. Nice graffiti art around. Park is so cool place during a day and evening time! Kids are happy - this is the most important thing! Live music, many places to eat good food as for kids and adults, some small shops! Probably there is the best toy shop in Vegas on the premises, though a bit on expensive side, but you will not go empty handed, they sell things for all ages. Fire show is great, all starts from drums, kids are playing, and then fire! Just my advise, to watch it from distance for the first time. All kids are very scared for the first time, run and scream, hiding behind mamas' skirts. Really good place!

When you are over the glitz and glam of the strip, the Container Park is a breath of fresh air. All the stores are specialty shops, boutique clothing and hip food joints/bars, not the average mall or forum finds. All the stores are in shipping containers, cool concept. Great for kids (big play area) and very fun visuals, nice artsy vibe. Also it is surrounded by some casual hipster bars. I love Downtown Vegas :)

All in all a great experience, especially for the family. Wish there were more shops. Some dining a little pricey but the food was very good. More live entertainment would be nice, especially during the day. Well-managed and clean.

Loves this a little on the small side but that's ok. WAY clean and they keep rif raff out which I was impressed with. Loved the play area for the kids and the little boutiques. Think there should be more places like this!! My kids and I loved hanging out here for a couple of hours!

This place is very interesting. It's a newly developed area created by the Zappos owner. He is definitely turning the values around downtown upward by making great spots such as this place. 

The giant attraction that has flames is pretty cool and very hot. 

The heart with lock is a great spot to take a picture. 

The live music from the main stage was very entertaining. 

The treehouse was a great way to enjoy the view of the park. 

You must visit this place when in the area. 

The only gripe I have is the parking. Most of it you have to pay for as none of the eateries or stores validate.

If you're visiting downtown and haven't been here yet, definitely take a stroll down E. Fremont and check it out. Don't get scared by the flames coming out of the Praying Mantis! It'll be difficult to spend your entire night here as a lot of the shops close earlier but the atmosphere is cool and unique and worth what is now a nice walk.

i love downtown container park. Between all the shops and restaurants there is something here for everyone. i love that they have a huge jungle gym play area that literally looks like a huge tree house for the kids. They also have building foam blocks, huge legos and a huge connect four game for the kids too. However, I've seen a few adults play with them as well. =) Love coming by on the weekends.  Also at night they have a nice fire music show by a huge prey mantis. Although I'm not quite sure of what time or days. So grab the whole family and stop by!

When I was first brought here it was not what I expected.~ 

I fell in love after experiencing this place.. it is so cool! From the history of how everything is made from shipping containers that is so neat and creative. Upon entrance you are welcomed by the surprising fire shooting praying mantis, the presence of the heart of locks, and being carded at entrance.. then boom you're in!

Best part of all it's FREE~ 

Awesome place to hang out at:
-shops shops shops
-eateries
-entertainment: grassy lawn outside music stage, play area & slides
-nice for exploring and strolling around the whole shopping center 

Great place to enjoy good vibes with all amazement, so much to see and do here.. places to lounge at and walk around and enjoy. This area reminds me of "The High Line in New York", with the elevated walk on the second floor with awesome views appreciating the wonderful concept all enclosed within. =)

Great place to grab a bite to eat and have an adult beverage with the wife...while the kids safely play a few feet away. Lots of cool little shops to explore. A very pleasant way to kill a couple of hours.

This is a really neat concept. It is a mini specialty shopping center made out of shipping containers. There is this awesome playground right in the middle. The shops are all small, but cute. The only real downside is that most of the activities, including eating, take place outside, so dress warmly if it is cold out.

This was my favorite part of Vegas for sure. We found great food, a cool environment, and a short walk away from old Vegas. I think its a very clever use of old containers by turning them into a outdoor mall and it is awesome!! I would suggest for anyone and I would say for sure visit Downtown Terrace!!

Like many others have said, Container Park is a new retail complex in Downtown Las Vegas comprised of shipping containers.  It's trendy and eclectic and offers a safe, clean place for families to hang out during the day and a "contained" place for the 21+ crowd to socialize at night.  There is adequate, if not ample, street parking around Container Park and rates are $1/hour (maximum 2 hours).  I believe parking is free after 6pm -- anyone know for sure?  

We went in the afternoon during a weekday and found the place very quiet (not a surprise).  Cool things: praying mantis sculpture at entrance, treehouse and slide in the center of the park, super yummy smells emanating from the various restaurants.  Not so cool: how excited will people be to visit Container Park in the summer during the day?  This park is obviously meant to be enjoyed whilst wandering around outside.  Will there be misters come summer to rehydrate the bodies of the dehydrated visitors staggering around for relief from the desert sun?  

I would have liked more variety in the existing shops.  They range from recycled jewellery/housewares, "artsy" women's apparel, goodies (frozen desserts, cupcakes), and art galleries.  Fun to browse, but not enough interest to keep my attention for very long.  Then again, perhaps I have a shorter attention span than most other people....?

We ended our visit to Container Park by chilling at The Beat Coffeehouse (just a short walk away).  Great way to conclude the afternoon and another plus in favour of Container Park!

Wow! This park exceeded my expectations. Clean and family friendly; perfect for parents who could use a glass of wine (or 2) as they watch their kiddos climbing up and down the coolest tree house. I went there on a beautiful day to catch up with a girlfriend, and we could not stop commenting on how perfect the park is. Very relaxing, fun to people watch, it's a side of Vegas that is definitely worth bragging about. I normally don't go downtown with my 6 year old diva because of the questionable neighborhood, but with all the positive changes, it's definitely worth the drive to support local businesses as well as the ever growing city.

Great place to hang with the family! They have shops and Restaurants around this giant tree playland. The play land isn't just for kids either, its fun and big enough for adults to be kids again! 

Great spot for everyone, bars for the adults to enjoy a drink, restaurants to feed the hungry and shops to buy some goodies. 

Downtown Las Vegas has a spot for every age!

I'm definitely a fan of the Container Park. The container architecture is cool and fun to walk around. It feels very inviting and cozy. There are a lot of places to sit and relax.

But it's far from perfect just yet. There are many stores in there right now, but I'd be surprised if most of them survive for long. There are a few that seem unique, but many of them are very run-of-the-mill tchotchke and psuedo-style stores that don't sell anything of real substance.

And Pork and Beans? $13 for some sausage and beans? Really? Ridiculous prices for a container restaurant.

So, hopefully the park will survive. Essentially, it's a really nice environment to hang out at.

I just hope they figure out an alternative fuel to use in the fire-breathing praying mantis whose burnt fumes don't give people headaches.

First time I visited Container Park I thought it was an interesting concept.  I recently went with family staying downtown and we were probably only there for about fifteen minutes.  Even though it was a Friday night it was pretty dead there.  Not a place suitable for many return visits unless you really love one of the restaurants there.

I think this is the coolest idea. I was immediately intrigued when we drove by and saw the praying mantis that spits fire! However, when you are actually there, the sound of the fire is terrifying!! And, way too loud. 

I loved all the little stores inside. Although it was pretty cold to walk around, I cannot wait to go there this summer. There is a great area for live music, a jazz band was playing, and the music plays around the whole center.

For my 100th review I wanted to review something that gets 5 stars. This place would get more, but 5 is the limit. :p

Whenever I'm in Vegas, I find myself doing things that aren't typically "Vegas-y". This place falls right into that category. Family friendly all the way to 9pm, this place boasts many neat features. 

1. A neat touch-sensor game that can be played solo or with multiple people. It's free! :)
2. A "lawn" for concerts that have comfortable patio furniture, blankets, and large lego-like bricks for kids.
3. The best tree house! Why? Because adults can slide down the slides too! These aren't the slides at your local park. Use caution if you get motion sick easily or if you're drunk. Also, take off your shoes for less friction and more speed.
4. A fire-breathing metal mantis.
5. Really neat layout made from reclaimed containers.

This is a great place to go to for a date. They have a few neat places to eat and drink as well as shop. Looks like they have free concerts fairly often and some paid ones. I also noticed that they have a "Doggie Date Night" where you can bring your pooch into the park.

This place was on our "We'll go if we have time" list when we last went to Vegas. After coming here we agreed that we're going to make it a point to come here whenever we're in town.

Somebody (in a glass building) recently pointed out that it seems from my reviews that I only go to good places.. Well, I promise my life is not that awesome - I just don't tend to review things I'd consider mediocre. 

Is the Container Park mediocre? Not necessarily in theory. In theory this place is amazing. In design it's pretty damn sweet. However, in execution it seems a bit lackluster. 

On paper this is a shopping area with small scale, local artsy stores and boutiques. In reality, the food choices outweigh the shops by far. In a parralel reality, the shops themselves feel a little random.

Unfortunately, a candy store, flip flop store, several jewelry places, toys store and a sock store do not get me too excited.. they give off a bazaar feel rather than a local arts feel. To boot, many places were closed for whatever reason - not closed for good, they were just not open.

The food choices here are pretty diverse. Actually, if the Container Park was purposed to be an alternative style 'food court' it would hit it right out of the park.  Between the 'elevated' hotdog place, Mexican restaurant, coffee bar, pizza joint, vegan place, juice bar, bbq spot and several bars this seems to be a happening little spot.

I am all about the shipping containers and the repurposing/upcycling of materials, I can appreciate the random (but sweet) Burning Man artifact and I can even deal with the hipsteresque vibes going around here. I just really wish that there was a nicer balance between food and shopping, and that the shopping itself was as unique as its location.

Interesting concept. The treehouse playground looks awesome and like a lot of fun. The BBQ smells amazing but I didn't try it ;-) 

The lemon shakeup place had great refreshing lemonade, which you need because somehow the heat rattles rains all the metal containers and whatever the paving is made of (not concrete) and makes it super hot in the courtyard. Good thing there are couches and tables in the shade and a fairly big grassy lawn to sit on and watch live music which they have throughout the day. 

Good place to bring kids downtown but nothing too special for adults.

If I had kids, I could definitely see myself spending a good chunk of my afternoon here.

The Downtown Container Park is a fenced-in sanctuary of unique dining and drinking, entertainment, and boutique shopping.  The "fenced-in" part (with a friendly, yet stern security guard at the entrance) is what keeps the riff raff of downtown Las Vegas out, and allows for an extremely safe vibe and super clean atmosphere inside.

The shipping containers which house the shops and restaurants surround the large outdoor quad area, and there's a substantial kids play area in the center of it all.  There's enough slides, toys, and things for them to climb to potentially keep busy for hours, or at least tire them out by 9pm (when the Container Park becomes 21+ only).

If you don't have kids, the Downtown Container Park is definitely still worth checking out.  If you do, it's an absolute must during your Las Vegas vacation!

The flaming pray mantis at the main entrance during nights is probably the biggest attraction here. And if you're into playing in the playground looking area with slides that's another attraction. Sometimes there's a band or some type of entertainment at the stage area. The parks looks like it was built partially from metal containers  but other than that there really isn't anything about it thats attention grabbing.

It's not to big.  There's a few shops, bars, and restaurants. Seems like there should be more felt a lot like the food court area or play area in a large shopping center. It should be located between the Fremont Street Experience and East Fremont not at nearly the end of it all. 

They do enforce curfew and will check for IDs after a certain time, probably after curfew. It's a place to check out at least once but I probably wont be here unless I'm showing someone around or if there's something to do here. 

This is where young adults or kid by heart adults go to play in the playground.

Family-oriented Vegas activity that includes:

-A gigantic fire-breathing praying mantis that does nightly shows after sunset. SO COOL. I highly recommend planning to see it! 

-Interesting boutiques that sell clothes, jewelry or unique Vegas souvenirs... plus a pop-up wedding chapel!

-Food and coffee shops, such as Stoned and Baked (pizza and cookies... creative huh?! Hahah), a cutesy donut shop that sells out EARLY and a speciality lattes place. 

- A play place for kids at the center of it all! Easy and safe place to let them run around and expend energy! 

Overall, we had fun checking this place out! As mentioned, it's a little outside downtown Vegas, but in that short two block walk it is a little dark and sketchy. Practice awareness and you'll be fine :)

Talk about a hidden gem! Nestled in downtown Las Vegas is a family friendly venue with so much to explore!

As soon as you walk up a HUGE praying mantis greets you with music and flame throwing from its antenna. The property has 3 level of containers stacked on top of each other, truly living up to its name. 

Really cool amenities are the open air design, string lot trees, child's play area, grassy knoll and stage for love music! The property showcases unique local eateries and retailers. This is all about small business. Most of these retailers and resteraunts are not chain owned. 

Absolutely loved the space, the amenities and the fall decor! Totally worth the stroll to visit this local grown spot.
The dessert is really good out here. It's my first time here at the container park. People should check this place out.

Wow.  I think I just found my new favorite Las Vegas spot.  

Whoever thought up and designed this place deserves a lot of credit.  And this place does not feel like Las Vegas at all (which, I suppose, defeats the purpose of going to Las Vegas, but I digress).  

First, it feels very safe.  There are security guards at each of the entrances and they let you know they are there.  And security is a very good thing in this neck of the woods.

It also does not feel like you are walking in and amongst a bunch of shipping containers.  It feels like a clean, safe, secluded, open-air little mini-mall with a bunch of interesting restaurants and shops and a really great play area (with a huge treehouse) in the middle.  So, the big kids can enjoy their grub and tequila and whiskey and wine and craft beer on the little outdoor patios while the kiddos go wild in the interior play area as you watch them.  It is a win-win for all.  Grown ups can have their fun (and booze) and bring their kids, too.  Plus, there is live music at night.

The front entrance, as you can see by the photos, is very cool.  Again, great design, great effort, great job.

Added bonus:  You are only a few blocks away from Atomic Liquors in one direction and a few blocks away from Fremont Street in the other direction.  So work in the Container Park and Atomic, if you really must go to Fremont.  Or, better yet, go to Container Park and Atomic and skip Fremont altogether.

I really liked this place, so many different things to do. And at night they have live music which is fun. 

They have a couple different restaurants to try and a couple of bars to go to. They allow you to buy a drink and walk around the park which is nice.

Downtown Container Park is one of the most unique places I've been to. Definitely a must see spot in Vegas. It's really trendy and artsy, photo opportunities everywhere! There are a wide variety of stores and restaurants. Beef jerky shops and toy stores. Places to get coffee.

There is also a play area for kids which is cool to bring your kids and hang out!

This is a little sanctuary in the middle of downtown.  It's serene almost, with kids playing and adults chilling out.  Two reasons I don't give it five stars: (1) if you go there in the summer, you will completely bake as these are recycled steel containers with little to no shade offered; (2) when you reach the upper levels, you will find the walking surface is see through, mesh, and gives as you walk on it.  I had an extreme case of vertigo while I was stuck walking on the second level, and had to immediately get down to the lowest/ground level. Other than that, it's a good place to bring the family, enjoy a meal, and let the kids play.

This place is cool. Nice places to eat and a super place for kids to play. Looks as though some of the stores might be "Pop Up" type stores. 
On the second level there's a vegetable place to get things to go. Head on down to The Perch for a nice sit down meal.
This is a nice place to just to sit and relax it don't feel like ur downtown a month after it open me and my son were down here a year straight he loves it

Downtown Container Park is the latest in the East Fremont DTLV development.

The concept is solid: Stack up a bunch of shipping containers and turn them into clothing, art, and novelty shops....Include a few food spots, a couple of bars, a concert stage and an aesthetically impressive children's tree house/play area...and set it all in a part of town where interest is growing = 3.5 Stars!

I've been here twice since it opened.  Both times I was heading someplace else but our group was distracted by Container Park and we felt compelled to explore.

The shops tend to be a little overpriced.  But that's to be expected in a place like this.  We had just eaten both times that I came in so I haven't tried any of the food here.  There aren't many drafts available from the bars inside, but they both had options that would appeal to the more discerning beer drinker.  The park closes to those under 21 after 8pm or 9pm and this was great because they were packed on Friday night.

They appear to have a wide variety of music artists scheduled to play.  The music was great both times I went.  ...a true highlight for our group.  Another big plus for us was the local aspect of many of the shops.  I'm not sure that I would come down here to specifically hangout...eat...and drink here, but it was a great distraction between bar hopping!

Such a cool destination to check out downtown, it's near El Cortez.  Very modern and clean design.  We loved the ginormous preying mantis statue, it's pretty cool in the evening as the antennas light up with fire.  There are a variety of restaurants and shops along with a kid friendly play area.  FYI- 21+ after 9pm.  We stopped by the kettle corn shop and enjoyed the most fresh lemonade, the kettle corn was spot on as well.  Definitely a nice alternative for when Fremont Street gets overwhelming.
My family enjoyed the park. It's a good place for parents to dine and drink all while in the view of your children playing.
Wow this place is so cool! The kids loved it during the day & i would love to return at night with adults for some of the events!! Also want to see the praying mantis "on!!" So so cool!!

Warning! Hipster Alert! 

Wait ... hipsters in Downtown Las Vegas? Yes. If you haven't been to Downtown Vegas in a while, there is a slow but steady transformation and revitalization of the areas surrounding the Fremont St. Experience. And perhaps the most grand of these efforts is the Downtown Container Park, a slice of hipster paradise amidst one of the oldest parts of Las Vegas. 

DTCP is a pretty neat place. The concept is that they have taken old cargo containers used for rail transportation and turned them into a hipster strip mall. There's also different pieces of art made out of junk to fit the theme, and at the center a massive playground where the hipsters can dump their kids while they get a glass of wine or microbrew. 

And of course the shops themselves are uber-hipster as well. There's several art galleries (including one that is focused on Disney Fine Art, so hipster cute!), specialty food shops (cupcakes, jerky, kettle corn, oh my!) and apparel shops. There's a nice selection of restaurants and bars here as well, including some great BBQ, a Kerry Simon backed venture that specializes in pork and beans, a vegan/raw food eatery, a wine bar, and a specialty cocktails/craft beer bar. 

DTCP does look a little bit out of place in the midst of the old "low roller" casinos in this part of Vegas. If anything, it looks like a destination pulled right out of a Portlandia sketch. But that's not necessarily a bad thing. Variety is good, and the locals I spoke with seemed to like it as a spot that was different - something that you wouldn't normally find in Vegas. If you need a break from the Glitter Gulch, a short walk down to DTCP will provide a nice respite that will appeal to your inner (or outer) hipster.

I live a stone's throw away, so this is something my husband has been looking forward to for months, showing me the progress every time we drove by. From the "outside" I didn't really know what this Container Park was going to be like. We went for the first time last night, and it was a very nice surprise.

Once "inside", I realized all that they had been planning in this little area of DTLV. There are shops (clothing, art, candy and popcorn yay), restaurants and bars. I wish I had a little store here! There's 3 levels to the place and a large play area for kids. Big kids too, b/c I took a ride down the slides. So fun! There was also a stage with a small seating/standing area and a live band playing. 

It's such a cool little place to hang out with friends/family, maybe grab a bite to eat/drink, and be entertained by performers, and well, people. I'm so excited about bringing my California friends here the next time they're in town. They're always so surprised to see the other side of Vegas, since like most people, their knowledge is limited to the strip.

The Container Park is definitely worth checking out. I'm totally excited about it. I think it adds to what I'm hoping will be DTLV's beautiful awakening!

I went to Vegas back in April but forgot to write a review for this place.  I was overwhelmed by places to review in April. :)

This place is amazing.  My group of friends went to Fremont to do the whole downtown experience away from the strip on a Saturday night.  We typically leave 1 night per trip to come to Fremont for the completely different experience you get there as opposed to the Las Vegas Strip.

We were actually trying to find the new SlotZilla Zipline (that was unfortunately still under construction) when we wandered south a bit from the Fremont Street experience.  Boy I am glad we decided to do that because we found this little treasure.  Keep in mind it was about midnight when we wandered across this place so I am sure it is a difference experience during the day.  When we got there, it was not very busy and they carded us at the gate.  I guess it becomes 21+ only after 9pm which is awesome.

The middle area was a playground type of thing which I'm sure kids use during the day, and then drunk adults use at night.  The stand out in this area was a light up game that made you push lights as they come on while your opponent tried to do the same.  This led to hysterical fun (especially after drinking a few) and burned quite a few calories in the process.

There were also restaurants and stores around on multiple levels but the majority were closed.  It was Midnight after all so I cant fault them.  The Jerky place in there was amazing....I ended up buying like 10 bags because it was so good.  I would like to come earlier to see more of the stores and places.

Did I mention that the whole place was made out of shipping containers by the way?

Way cool!
We had an hour to kill in Vegas and found ourselves here with ample people watching and good eats.
Funnest place to take date to grab a coffee or a quick bite to eat. Really fun environment. The shops are a great idea. This is one of my favorite places in las vegas.

Eh.  It's alright.  Worth checking out, but I won't be going back.

We parked in the metered area, and I remember thinking "2 hours max - damn."  Going in, I assumed we'd have to leave and park somewhere else after our time expired.  We were out of there in about 90 minutes, and that includes waiting forever to get some grub.

The entire footprint is small.  And cramped.  The design is nice, but I don't feel like logistics were considered very well.  The bathrooms are a joke - super tiny and hard to find.  Lines for the various eateries were extended out in the path of travel.  The play area in the center is nice, but already filthy and not well maintained in general.

There are several decent places to eat.  There is also live music which was nice.  Definitely a "cool" concept that works well in theory, but, as executed, I just don't think it will work out.

P.S. I fully expect that this place will receive a slew of 1 star reviews by people visiting in the months of May-October.  It will be way too hot to enjoy anything the place has to offer, especially considering there are no shaded areas and very limited seating within a few eateries.

Finally getting to check this place out! I'm a huge fan of downtown to begin with so this just takes it over the edge! We got there right at sundown where they were doing the drum circle & "waking up" the praying mantis (lots of fire!) which was fun to watch. They've got a really nice park in the middle for kids to run around. Lots of fun little bars, restaurants, stores surround the area. Looking forward to our next visit!

We stumbled upon this place by chance and did not expect it to be so cool! My coworkers and I just saw a giant preying mantis blasting fire outside of the park and kept walking inside. There are so many small shops and food around the area that you can check out. Very kid friendly in the day time. They have a giant jungle gym and some large Lego blocks in the back of the park. But after 9 pm, it's only people over 21 and they do I.D checks. I wish I got to see this place in the day because some of the stores were closed already. 

Tip: If you play in the jungle gym or with the blocks in the back, wash your hands afterwards, because they were a little grimey. 

Highly Recommended!!! I will be back!

I love pinches tacos! The praying mantis outside rocks because it reminds me of burning man, which that beautiful art car has made an appearance some years ago. Love the concept of this place. 

The security is a little intense and agressive though. I've watched him yell at people because they were either coming in with an alcholic beverage or leaving with one. I get they just changed the law but is it really necessary to chase after and yell at people?! Especially, if tourist are not aware about the new law. Gosh! What happened to old Vegas when you could walk around w booze anywhere. Anywhere!!!!

Also, they don't allow doggies unless you go to a place down the street to make sure your dog as all her shots. Then you can put your dog on a list to be allowed to come in on Thursdays only. Random. 

Otherwise, its cool.

What a rad addition to downtown! Every time I go, I find something else I love about it, and this was the perfect thing to do. 
I remember sitting at a pop up dinner in Tony Hsieh's apartment about 2 years ago. The guys across from me talking about their current project and how they are tearing down a old motel and building apartments and retail centers out of containers. They said, "you must think we're crazy right?' My boyfriend and I both responded with "NO WAY, WE THINK YOU ARE SMART, AND LONG OVERDUE!"
Finally, I can bring my child downtown without being scared she will be offered drugs!! And I am serious. Also, I can leave her at home after hours, come here, and still enjoy myself. 
At this point Container Park does close, but not til late on the weekends. I was there at around 6pm on a Sunday night and the number of children equaled adults which is cool. There should be the option for adult and kid entertainment. 
Live reggae music played in the background. It was not to loud yet you could hear it throughout the park. There is a little something for everyone. From cupcakes, to jerky, to art, a barber shop, and of course BBQ and TACOS!! (Which I will be trying on my next trip because pork and beans DID NOT make the cut!)
In the middle there are 2 separate play areas, one more appropriate for younger kids and then of course the 50 foot tree house slide that is good from youth on up til you can't make it up those stairs. 
This really was a great idea, and I hope the decide to go up a couple stories or at least continue to add on across the street.

WHO: Take the entire family downtown to see the GIANT FIRE BREATHING GRASSHOPPER and play in the actual playgrounds, or make the container designed restaurants and stores YOUR PLAYGROUND! hint hint...

WHEN: The retail stores open at 10am, the bar/food places open at 11am daily. RETAIL STORES: On Sunday through Thursday, they close at 9pm; and on Friday & Saturdays they close at 11pm. BAR/FOOD: On Sunday through Thursday, they close at 11pm, and Friday & Saturdays they close at 1am.

WHERE: Located in Downtown Las Vegas on Fremont & 7th St.

WHAT: I am so excited for Downtown Las Vegas! There are great things happening, which include THE CONTAINER PARK! I just loved the idea of how this park/shopping/eatery area has been set up!

Before you enter, you are amazed by the fire breathing grasshopper at the entrance (KID FRIENDLY). When you actually enter the park, the shops are contained in metal containers- so clever! When you look straight ahead (the middle of the park), there is a Super cool playground!! There was also a tree house made of balloons you can take pictures of and or with! As you walk towards the back end of the park, there is a stage where live bands play! Behind the live band, there happens to be a barber shop. COOL! FREE, LIVE MUSIC WHILE YOU GET A HAIRCUT!

I also love how this park gives our locals a chance to express themselves and let you taste, see, and try what they have worked so hard for! There are many boutiques that are locally owned as well as the eateries! I did get to try Jojo's Jerky, which is a locally made beef jerky store. They do not tax because they make the jerky themselves. My friend and I clearly supported, we ended up buying 3 flavors, saving us the rest of the day! =D

I am going back soon to try some of their food spots! I suggest you all to bring the family and just HAVE A GOOD TIME! :)

YAY DTLV!!!

I absolutely love that Downtown Las Vegas is getting a facelift. Awesome dog parks, lofts, hipster type bars, poetry nights, food selections galore, mixed with old neon nostalgia and newer modern fixtures. Add every type of walks of life, some art and a little culture, and you get a pretty awesome area to hang out at.

 One of the best additions to the Downtown area is the Container Park. 

There are two different experiences: before 9pm when all ages are welcomed, and after 9pm when it becomes an adult only wonderland. 

Before 9pm:

 I've taken my 3 kids (ages 14, 11 and 7) on numerous occasions, and they've all enjoyed the place. We've given our business to as many store fronts as we can, as we'd like to see this place stay open, be successful, and possibly expand somehow. We walk around and get treats from the popcorn and cupcake stores, I indulge in a Thai Iced Coffee, we've eaten at the BBQ and taco restaurants on more than one occasion. We browse the art galleries and have of course, sat in the grassy area to listen to live music, and for the kids to play on the playground. We always make it a point to go near sunset, as we love to be part of the drum circle at the front entrance.

 We once went with 15 or so people, and even on a busy Sunday, found an open table and enough chairs to where we could all eat at the same time, right next to the playground tree house so where we could supervise the kiddos. 

 Tip: When you first arrive, ask what time the first drum circle begins. Go back to the front entrance 10-15 minutes beforehand, to guarantee a seat and a drum, so as to be in the drum circle to wake up the big Mantis out front. The drum circle lasts 15-25 minutes, you're following a khaki-clad Downtown Ranger, following the ranger in a series of drum beats and patterns. The Mantis then wakes up, blowing out fire. It's quite impressive. 

 
 After 9pm:

 A few friends of ours got together at Container Park to join their 'movies in the park' series that they had in May and part of June. They show old movie classes on a big projector screen over the stage at the grassy area. We brought our own blankets, but the park provided beach blankets, floaty blow up inner tubes (PERFECT to use as pillows) and beach balls. The two times we've gone, they showed the original Jaws and Weekend at Bernie's. They have a mini bar set up on the grassy area, but some of the restaurants are still open. The vibe is chill and it's quite a different experience, sharing the tree house slides with only other adults, instead of having to wait your turn amongst a million 5 year olds. 

  Hoping that they bring back the 'movies in the park' series soon! Definitely going to make this a regular place to visit.

I love this place. I love coming with my kids so they can play in the park and enjoy being outdoors. I love coming with other adults and sitting outside under the pretty lights at night time. I love all the events that they have. This is a great addition to downtown Las Vegas.
This is great for downtown Las Vegas.  Fun atmosphere for everyone.  Places to eat, drink, shop and listen to music.

What a fantastic area for families! I LOVE the play area in the middle. I really appreciate the fact that it is monitored by an employee, who keeps an eye out of the entrance and exit. We were told that they would not let any kids out, unless the parent is ok with that. 

My kids had a great time playing in the playground. It was very spacious and had lots of fun activities. I didn't get a chance to walk around the stores, due to time constraints. I would definitely come back again and take a longer look.

This is a must experience first hand type of spot to truly appreciate. "Container Park" does not do justice to the eclectic businesses, restaurants, bars, play areas, bandstand, fire breathing praying mantis, Trikke rides/rentals/sales; public art and more....

Even though I was starving enough to gnaw off a body part after the Gold Spike Typhoon Relief event, Daniel convinced me to stop here. Sure glad that we did, it was all lit up for the holidays and bustling with families, couples, singles et al. REALLY want to ride the giant slide next visit. The Las Vegas Youth Orchestra serenaded from the festive bandstand as children young and old availed themselves of the play area immediately facing them. 

Know Kerry Simon has a spot here, there's a vegan joint and the makes me giggle taco pinches, places to eat, drink, people watch, listen to and view art in the making...the only thing that concerns me is a previous review mentioning the restrooms being inside of these "containers" as well; this screams Porta Pottie and is HIGH on my list of phobias. Since I did not seek out the facilities during my visit, I will reserve judgement there. 

For now, I'm thrilled this unique destination is available and can imagine wiling away the hours or Trikking the nearby streets. I dig it, I reallllly do :-) 

Yelp 100 Challenge

Since there isn't a Jurassic park you can always go to container park. I find myself down on Fremont an awful lot, for concerts and photo shoots. So i definitely pass by Container park a whole bunch. However I am usually preoccupied with some business so I have yet to enjoy it to it's fullest extent. I really like the atmosphere of the area around here. It's a family friendly/relaxing spot with not a lot of riff raff ruining things with their nonsense. Security is usually nice, If someone starts acting a fool or gets sketchy they usually stop them at the gate. The layout reminds me a lot of the district, before it wast butchered by the whole drive thru traffic ordeal. I really want to try the BBQ place, so far I've only been to pinch'e tacos which is pretty good. Anywho there's a whole slew of neat shops and places to eat, a cool haircut place that's in a train :D and they almost always have some type of entertainment going on. Oh and for the little ones they have this huge playground that looks awesome. They even host movie nights so the whole fam can enjoy. I really like the fact they keep this place safe for the fam. No loud drunken morons, or punk teenagers spouting profanity just to be idiots. So would really recommend this place if you have kiddos or friends or fam visiting and want a place for the kids to play. 

Best of all they have a giant robotic praying mantis that shoots fire!. When I first saw it my A.D.D. went straight to OMG 0_o.

P.S. be careful when approaching the robo mantis the guy who operates it tends to play opossum with spectators, the mantis is hooked up to a loud speaker, and when you least expect it. BOOM! loud noises or music will come from the mantis as well as giant flames from it's antennas. I've passed by there a ton of times and every now and then I get got.
this place is really cool. went to the little wine bar there and had a great time.  Friendly staff and good prices

I took a nice stroll through this park for the first time with a group of friends. The praying mantis at the entrance is quite a unique welcoming act for the park. It shoots flames from its antlers every 15 minutes. Beware because it can get quite hot if you are standing too close. We took a stroll during sunset and the as the night approached. In the center of the park is a large park, with tall slides and other games for the little ones to play. On the opposite end of the entrance is a large grassy area with live music on stage and couches to lay on. It was a very chill and laid-back environment--perfect to let loose and relax on a Friday evening. This place is extremely child-friendly and appropriate for all ages. The park is filled with restaurants and boutiques on both sides. Grab a popsicle, find a spot to relax, sit back and relax, and enjoy the live music in the background!

This place gets 3 stars only because of the expectations that I had. Being near the art district, I hoped that this was a more artsy place with unique artisans and craftspeople. Bummer...just touristy stuff like every other touristy area in every other touristy city on the planet.

It would be a great place for people to go with kids as they have a pretty cool playground. It took longer to find a parking spot than it did to see the place.
 
The huge Mantis in front is awesome.

I'm sorry. I so want to like it but it's always such a disappointment. The park is small, the stores are few. As a small business owner I want to support local businesses but it's hard here. I can't quite finger what it's missing but last trip down will most likely be my last.

Super cute kick-it spot in DTLV.  LOVE going here.  It doesn't feel like Vegas one bit.  Although it's not that big, there's definitely a lot to see and do while you're at the Downtown Container Park.  There are shops and restaurants--all made up of freight containers (hence the name ;)).  I really like the ice cream/popsicle/snow-ice shop that's located on the first floor (they've got cocktail popsicles! yum!).  I also really enjoyed the Disney arts store they've got, too (gotta buy a piece one day).  There's a big jungle gym for the kiddies to play.  There's also a stage.  The day that we were visiting, there were a group of musicians playing live jazz music--so fun!  The restaurants also serve alcohol, and you can drink while inside the park.

MY TIP: Have brunch at Eat. Then hang out here!!

A little different than what I was expecting. When you stand outside you notice a huge praying mantis made of various metals, it's pretty cool. When you go inside container park you see a 2 story rectangle of shops and boutiques. The downfall is most everything in here is pretty pricey. If you have kids they have a really nice play area with misters. My friend and I didn't stay here very long.

*There is an ice cream/bubble tea/dessert place on the first floor that has $3 snow cones with a million flavor choices that you get to add yourself!

Lots of fun to be had by all. Interesting concept turning old shipping crates into stores. With the big treehouse in the middle the kids can play to their hearts content. The have a stage with live music, saw a cool folk music duo. Only downside it is a bit small.

My family and I finally had a chance to come visit container park!! We loved it and are excited to have a park located downtown as a possible after-party destination to the Lied Discovery Children's Museum. So, this is located down town, therefore please beware of your children and the surroundings. There is a lot of trash everywhere and shady people. On our way in, there was a possibly homeless man shouting the homophobic F word at a security guard, and just a lot of people that are intoxicated. 

Aside from the crazy surroundings, the park is fantastic! There is a multi-level tree house with slides, and what I want to deem as life-sized bop-it. The kids both had a blast and there was live music and plenty of people for people watching if that's your thing. We arrived at 5 and it was extremely crowded, but by the time 6PM rolled around, it had died down quite a bit. That may be the time when hipsters begin standing in line to go down the slides for the perfect photo OP, but my children didn't mind. They just kept trying to convince me to go down the slides since they kept seeing so many "grown-ups" go down them. Unfortunately, my stomach was a little out of sorts on my first visit. I will certainly try them on my next. Thanks for building container park! We love it and will be back.

Been coming here for a what seems to be years now and We still enjoy the uniqueness.  These old shipping containers have some character.  The little boutique type stores are nice for browsing but sometimes cater to such a niche market that it is difficult to appeal to everyone.  

When we comedown it is nice to relax in a clean and safe environment.  They Security staff is always friendly and keeping the creeps out.  CP also has a good variety of food and bev outlets to enjoy while basking in the sun listening to some live music which they often have.  Local artists and bands for sure but it still is a nice feature.  The food I have tried at the restaurants has been fresh and of decent quality.  The BBQ place Big Ern's has been my favorite so far but Pinche's Taco's and Cheffini's is also good.  

My recommendation for the Adult Beverage places is to come during "happy hour" to get the most buzz for your buck.  After you have had a few climb to the top of the "TreeHouse" for a little drunken slide'in.  Ahh... to be a kid again would be a blast.  We never had places this cool to play growing up. 

Container Park is a good time day or night.  With or without kids a good time can be had by all just sit back relax and enjoy.  The pay for parking is not too bad at only $1 and hour which is better than some of the Casino's on Fremont St.  I used to validate at Benny Binion's but those days are gone now.

Better concept than production product but still a cool little place to see.   Definitely a family friendly place.  Cute shops and decent inexpensive restaurants.   Not really a place for guys unless you're bringing the family along.  Playground for kids and cool fire breathing praying mantis out front.  Fun for the kids.  (Atomic liquors is a short jaunt away.)

i really liked this park. the playground for the kids was super cool and hope to take my little one there. the night we went they were playing Jaws on their movie lawn and the place smelled of good food all round us. i love the look and direction DT is going.

Mary Rose already gave a great review that I am in 100% agreement with.   My husband and I stumbled across the Container Park while staying at the Downtown Grand last weekend and I was instantly in love with this place that is funky and eclectic.

First, its new so it's clean and lovely to look at.  There is a massive security force, so it feels safe and comfortable.  I love the vibe and I love that they have bands playing, which really gives it a festive feel.  We played in the jungle gym/treehouse/slide thingy and sat on a patio drinking beer and listening to the music and we walked around peeking into stores.  It's just a great atmosphere and there are some fun stores... I guess we'll have to see how they do.

I used the ladies room and it was actually very clean and comfortable, although my husband said the men's room was stinky. 

They have a cool giant grasshopper that was once a Burning man art car and now greets visitors with antenna that spout flames.  

I just really fell in love with this place.  It has something for everyone and I can see myself returning here again and again when I'm in the downtown area.  Yea, Vegas!  Nice one.

I like the idea of Container Park but it really misses the mark. Store are unique but small, lacking ability to have any decent amount of items and it doesn't have a lot of stores. It is also a bit of an eyesore. Parking is horrible especially at busy times.

This place is pretty cool.  Bring the kiddos!  There's a nice play structure in the middle with a guard manning the gate.  You can have the kids trapped in the middle while you enjoy a beer at one of the surrounding tables.  There are a number of kid friendly shops to walk through as well that they'll like.  We liked the reptile shop.  Although there's a number of eating places inside container park, there's also a number of foodie establishments just around the block.  If you come at night, the huge praying mantis is an awesome piece of art.  It moves and has fire antenna heating up the scene to some pink floyd.  Pretty cool spot.

Have been itching to check out this place but was warned of the crowds so I finally made the trip on a Tuesday morning.  Here are a few opinions bulleted for convenience:

- Parking would probably be a pain if it was a busy weekend.  Be prepared with quarters and comfy shoes.

- The team behind the design and construction of this place is genius.  The transformation of container vans into a sleek but whimsical, fun but functional space that people can enjoy for FREE is an admirable feat.  

- The main playground/treehouse is quite a narrow space, I would definitely not attempt to go here if the place was packed.  But on a slow weekday, they still had lots of security guys roaming and constantly looking after kids and parents.  Great job guys.  I'm also not sure that the treehouse and slides are something that I would keep bringing my son back to play with.  Once or a few times would suffice.

- There's a grass field fronting a small concert space with good sound quality so you might want to check out their monthly event lineups here - http://downtowncontainerpark.com/events/.

- I wish the awesome mantis at the entrance was part of the space inside where people can enjoy it more.

- I was only able to try 1 restaurant, the Mexican one and wasn't very impressed.  The only other spot that interested me sold charcuterie and wine but they opened late for lunch.  You could see that the people hanging out at Container park were there primarily for the space and not the food.  I wish they'd have some really sick/awesome food joints to keep people coming back for more.

I'm glad I went on a lazy slow day before it became too hot.  It was quite enjoyable walking around to Jazz music wafting in the air, flowers on the sidewalks and children running here and there.  Will I go back?  Only for great food and music.
