Worth persuing if you're already in the downtown / Fremont Street area. Just a few blocks from the Deuce bus stop, this collection of shops and restaurants might be built from shipping containers, but it feels like a true city-center oasis in an otherwise low-density, endlessly sprawling city. 

There's a large artificial lawn with a stage that plays host to concerts, movies, games, and other events. Leading away from the lawn is an easily navigable loop around the premises that takes you past many quirky boutiques and inexpensive restaurants. There's also art throughout the venue, including a gigantic preying mantis sculpture. 

It all feels like the food truck parks and beer gardens that we have in the Bay Area. In retrospect, it's uncanny and hardly surprising that, while on vacation, I would go out of my way to seek out things that I would like visiting or doing at home anyway.

My only need to go back is for Sweet Spot Candy Shop (looooove them!) and Jo Jo's Jerky. Other than that, the food is overpriced & sub par, the shops are touristy crap and I hope the art galleries get out alive without wasting too much of their time & money (love you guys, but no one is buying art in the Container Park, I wish you all the best).

If you have kids this place is great! Out door mall with lots of options for good food.with gated playground in the center. They also have lots of fun activities. There was also live music. Love the idea of the recycled containers too!

Hands down my favorite experience from Las Vegas. This place was RIGHT up my alley. Located at the bottom of Fremont Street, it was so refreshing to find a spot like this in the ever so commercial place that is Las Vegas. We came during the day, so it was really hot and we basically ran from store to store. However, this place would be precious to visit on a cool day or night. The child's park was really nice and looked like it would be a huge hit with kids. They had a movie theater (SO cool!), coffee place, vegan eatery/ juices, jerky spot, children's toy store, chocolate spot, bars/restaurants... there's a lot of stores tucked into these recycled shipping containers. It was all so cool to see and experience. I also personally loved the three trash cans that were together throughout the park- trash, recycling and compost. I always appreciate seeing a place that cares about the environment. I just simply loved it here and would love to return if I visit Las Vegas again.

Best spot to hit up in Downtown. Good food and a fun atmosphere for the whole family. Even adults can go on the slides ;) go go go!

I've never been to a place like this before.  I first noticed the place when I ran the Las Vegas Rock n' Roll marathon. The fire breathing pray mantis was what got me curious. I finally got to check out the place back in January when a group of my friends and I hit the downtown scene. We went bar hoping and then checked out the Container Park. After 9pm the park doesn't allow minors in the facility. It was really cool that playground was open to "children of all ages" so we were able to go up on the super tall slide. It felt good to be a child again. The security guards and staff around the park are very welcoming and friendly. 

Totally a Vegas must...Go go GO!!!
Love the live music, small boutiques, and amusement park feel of this little gem.  I'm a tourist so it's not typical to be in this part of town, but I would definitely come back.
I expected it to be bigger but wasn't disappointed it has a cute hipster vibe. Plenty of seating and shops with food or alcohol drinks to grab.
Lots of fun for kids and adults alike. Boutique shops are cute but pricey. Drinks are over priced as well but some great food venues. LOVE the live music. Overall great place to just chill.

From 5/08/15
My brother came to town with his girlfriend and my 18-month-old nephew, they wanted something to do that was toddler oriented- so I said Container Park is the way to go! 

Even though, Vegas has a bunch of fun places kids; finding cool activities for a toddler is a bit trickier, but I figured this would be fun for him because he can run around and play. They have a large area where children can have a blast, even by the stage- it's still a kid-friendly spot.

Speaking of a stage- yes they have concerts here! I am sure there is a list on their website of who performs at the concert series. Also, there are boutiques and restaurants, so if you have the urge to shop, or grab a bite to eat it is only a few steps away. Container Park is the perfect spot to hang because it has something for everyone

"WHAT THE HECK IS A CONTAINER PARK?"

That was my first question when my friend asked me if I wanted to go check out the Container Park while having dinner at Pizza Rock. So off we went along with my wifey and kids.

Wow. This place was a whole park made out of ACTUAL containers. I mean, who does that? Anyways, before we even stepped foot in it, you see a giant preying mantis out front with flames shooting out of its antennae. Again, I ask. Who does that? I gotta say, just that alone is a pretty good first impression. The other thing I liked was that you have a couple of security guys watching over the entrance, which is the only way in, and the only way out.

As you come in, you will see various stores/restaurants from a beef jerky place, to a barbeque place. There is even a decent sized stage towards the end of the park. What I think the main attraction of this place is the big treehouse that is smack dab in the middle of the whole place which features a 33 foot tall slide.

Bottom line is that my kids loved hanging out here and this place is a refreshing sight to see compared to all the casinos going up all over the place and the Fremont Street Experience is no different.

Some random info: There is free wifi and the bandwidth is very good I might add. 21 and over only after 9 pm.

Retail Open       
 Sunday-Thursday
 10 a.m. to 9 p.m.
 Friday-Saturday
 10 a.m. to 11 p.m.

Food & Beverage Open
 Sunday-Thursday
 11 a.m. to 11 p.m.
 Friday-Saturday
 11 a.m. to 1 a.m.

Yelp 2014 365 Review Challenge #22

i love how all the businesses are local businesses. Super clean place, does not look ghetto like the rest of Fremont Street. Great food, Live music, & playground for the kids! i will defiantly be coming back!
Great place! Very hip, amazing concept, awesome music and super family friendly atmosphere. My personal favs are the jerky store and DIsney art studio.

This is a must go to portion when you visit Downtown Vegas. It's a great place for families to play in the day time and adults to play at night. The outdoor furniture welcomes all the chance to relax and listen to local grooves on weekend nights. Occasionally, movies will be projected for families in the evening. The bars are reasonably priced and there are several places to choose from that all have different vibe. 

Don't miss the shops on the second stories. Otherwise you'll miss out on salons,  additional bars, art, and chocolate. The bathrooms are always clean in the back right corner and have multiple stalls!

Come here at random times of the day and you'll see how the crowd changes from family to late night fun!

Absolutely love this place and so do my kids. Awesome (secure) play area with slides, giant tree house, giant blocks and more. Play area is visible from almost every part of the park - so as a parent you can walk around or sit just about anywhere. To top it of, most restaurants serve alcohol. #EnoughSaid

I can't comment on the stores that are there, but the park as whole gets 5 stars.

A few weeks ago I read a really interesting article about some looney toons wanting to build a park out of shipping containers in East Village San Diego. What are these guys, cray-cray? I thought so until I actually saw Downtown Container Park in Las Vegas, which was made out of, you guessed it, shipping containers - nothing short of awesome. Now I'm with the looney toons, let's build this sucker.

Peep the pics before you think I've completely lost my mind and then bookmark this place for your next Vegas trip. It doesn't feel touristy and it seems that lots of locals come here to spend their afternoons eating, drinking and even getting their hair cut at the barber shop. There's a stage for live music and I was a little bummed that we strolled in when the band was breaking down their instruments since this seems like a great place to take in a cheesy cover band. Better luck next time!

Take a lap or two, grab some curry jerky from Jojo's and maybe some wings from the food truck on the way out. I get it now, looney toons... SD needs this!

That damn fire spouting preying mantis has shortened my life by 5 years, I have mini heart attacks every time it goes off.  I learned that it was actually constructed for Burning Man, and they could've left it there! I did like the "locks of love" at the entrance, leftover from Life is Beautiful.

I've been here a couple times now, don't really need to go back. I covered all the little shops and "food stands", the only place that was of worth was Simply Pure. I'm lazy and don't feel like writing a review for each place we tried, so I will just put it all together here and summarize.

Overpriced boutiques. I'm all for supporting local businesses, but the prices were outrageous. Food stands were ok, but nothing spectacular, and for the price, you can do a lot better.

Pinches Tacos-overpriced street tacos
The Beatnik Coffee-not sure how you can ruin iced coffee
Bin702-one of the more decent places to drink/snack here
ChillSpot by SasaSweets-worst Halo Halo ever

I'm not a fan of the "Downtown Rangers" or whoever they are that accost you at the entrance, I don't understand why you would want to scare away kids and families, it seems like this place would be more suited for them anyways. Metered parking was a bitch, 2 hour time limit and the parking enforcement Nazis are out in effect! 

The coolest thing was the enormous slide and at the end of the park, the old train engine that is a traditional men's barber shop inside.

The only thing worth looking at here is the giant praying mantis at the front entrance that blows fire out of its antennae. The place is just a bunch of shipping containers with a bunch of junky shops and restaurants. Just a few blocks away from the Fremont Street experience

Most kid friendly spot I've seen in Vegas!  AND ample places to sit down while watching the wifey shop in an semi-affordable mall.  Some really unique stores. 

(This mall just opened a few weeks ago and many of the stores don't have Yelp accounts yet.)

I love the concept and execution. Too bad the stores are an afterthought when looking for a reason to come here. If you've got a kid the top reason for visiting is their tree house and slide. Adults can go down the slide too, but chances are you may get stuck as it quickly snakes from side to side. My kid loved all the building blocks and the faux grassy area. It makes for a nice spot to spend a few hours with the fam when you're downtown. The couple times I've been there (once during the day and once at night) it wasn't tough to find street parking. After 9pm you have to be 21+ to enter.
Unique and neat! Haven't been to Downtown Vegas/Fremont street in years. I like the artsy feel to the place. Like the stores and eateries. Such a nice experience, especially during the holidays.

This place is amazing! We had the best time hanging out here on our last trip to vegas whenever we wanted to get away from the Strip. Highlights were Pinches tacos, the Wine Bar, Jerky place but most of all I LOVED Blue Marble. They have the most amazing assortment of upcycled bottle items from glasses and candle holders to light fixtures, that you would never imagine Don't miss it!

My first time here 7-8-16.  Cool concept, something different for Las Vegas.  I really enjoyed how at night they allow the adults to play on the playground and kick the kids out.  I just wish more of the shops and restaurant were open late. We really wanted to try pizza and brownie but after the comedy show it was closed. Instead we enjoyed our time at JoJos jerky. We were happy to see all the security present. It felt very safe. Earlier I was told there was music but late night nothing. Kinda disappointment since Vegas is such a 24 hour open late type of town.  Overall it was nice to be able to support local businesses.

what a cute upgrade to downtown vegas!  and being that i work at a port where shipping containers are everywhere, it was awesome to see them as restaurants, a tree house, unique shops and other things pretty for a change.  :)

visit this place at least once.  it's definitely a different vegas vibe in that it's super family friendly.

This is definitely an off the beaten path place to visit.  Located at the end of the Old Las Vegas Strip on Fremont Street.  The Container Park is literally what is sounds,  a park or space made from old shipping containers. Really a neat idea. Each shipping container has a store or restaurant in it. Very unique places ranging from handmade jewelry to hot dogs and even a wedding Chapel! 

The container Park has a playground in the middle where children can play. It is a great place to bring your kids if you have come to visit Vegas. Vegas doesn't have all that many kid-friendly attractions but the Container Park is one of them! 

From the Container Park you can walk about 15 minutes north to the Neon Light Museum, which is really cool but gets booked up fast!

This place is so cute! I only been in the evening when there's no kids. It's like a little town.

Once you get near it's like you're not even downtown anymore. They have security guards outside checkin IDs they are super nice but pretty strict they won't let you linger outside. Either you're in or you're out. Lol 

Inside is pretty cute they have a huge slide that my friends went in. They have restaurants, bars, & cute little stores. Of course the stores were closed. Everything is a tad over priced but that's normal. The bartenders there were not stingy with the alcohol we ordered a drink & they made it like 80% alcohol lol

The praying mantis would blow out fire and would scare the living sh** out of me each time!

Love this place! Great place for families! You dont even feel like your in Vegas. Very hip and down to earth. Great places to eat and the chill spot has great popsicles!  Got some great classic kids toys from the new toy store that recently opened. Great play equipment.  We will be going back

Recently went to a free concert at the park witnessed some great bands, American Cream and Cayucas.  Looks like they are taking my advice to have events and new bands every night.  I hope it turns into a great downtown attraction.

yet another great Downtown Las Vegas find! apparently, it's the brain-child of the founder of Zappo's (whose company headquarters is located in DTLV). this place is awesome.

it's got a unique pull being that these shops and bars are housed in shipping containers, which makes it a great place to have small local businesses set up shop as well as a great tourist attraction that's even family-friendly because of the different eateries within the Park. the playground in the middle of it all is very reminiscent of Disneyland's "Tarzan's Treehouse" attraction because of the spiral stairs up to the second level and the skybridge along the top. 

a very cool place to meet with friends and get the night started if you don't intend on doing the whole expensive dressed-up clubbing thing on the strip. there's a variety of shops and the drinks are great, plus you're walking distance to other cool DTLV attractions once you exit the Container Park. 

-civilities.

We discovered this hidden gem when we decided to walk a couple extra blocks from Downtown Fremont Experience.   The fire shooting from the fun praying manthis, which is set to go off during certain songs, and I didn't hear any songs repeated during the two visits we made. Stores and restaurants are included.  No chain stores here.

This is a great place to go on a date or with friends, but it's also great for a solo outing as well. There are places to eat and/or grab a drink as well as a few stores and boutiques to visit. And while it is an outdoor area, there's an abundance of shaded places to sit and relax. Even on a hot summer day the layout of Container Park keeps you cool and protected from the sun (for the most part), and let's not forget about those glorious fans that blow cool, misty air at you in your sweaty times of need. 

So far, the places I've been to in Container Park are Pinches Tacos and The Black Cup Coffee Co. 

I wouldn't waste your time at The Black Cup Coffee Co as their coffee is not up to par and neither is the customer service. 

Pinches Tacos is another story though -- taco connoisseurs, this place is worth trying!

What a great little gem in Las Vegas!

I was in town for my dad's 60th. Half my family was tired from Vegas shennaningans, the other half gamblers. I fit into neither category so around 11Am on a beautiful, sunny Monday I bought a yard-tall frozen margarita and walked up and down Fremont St. by myself. I decided to venture past the more touristy area and wound up in downtown Las Vegas. Unfortunately Container Park didn't allow outside food and drink so I had to down my alcoholic beverage. And at $13 a pop, I sipped down every last margarita-filled drop.

(Only) slightly intoxicated, I walked into the park. It had a badass play area for kids and an outdoor stage for concerts and movie nights. The park itself is made of about 3 levels of shops and restaurants, ranging from toy shops to street art shops. (I wish I'd purchased some art but was worried about carrying on the plane.) Almost everyone could find something in there. The restaurants smelled delicious.

It's a great area to pass the time and just wander around, get some vitamin D while you're at it. If gambling's not your thing and you get tired of the drunk scene, walk on down to Container Park.

There really is nothing bad to say about this place. During the day it's very family friendly and allows a great place for adults as well as kids to hangout. 

There's a jumbo play place with a multitude of slides to go down (both for kids and adults), large soft building blocks you can use to create towers from, and interactive electric running games in the middle of the park that are surrounded by restaurants, stores, and bars. :) 

Towards the back end of the park is a stage surrounded by fake grass, tables and chairs to watch performances and eat, a blackboard wall to write messages in chalk with to the left, and a large bench swing to the right. 

After a certain time, this park is only open to adults, which switches up the dynamic to a chill adults only playground and hangout without the crazy loud feeling of other downtown places. Great place to hangout with friends, take a date, or just grab a drink and listen to live bands play after work. 

This downtown project is one of the bests that have happened by Fremont Street that allows locals and visitors alike to have a fun, relaxing spot within the hustle and bustle of Vegas.

Security sucks ass !!!! I left my phone in the restroom and someone turned it in to lost and found with my iD and all and when I went to. Go look back for it they wouldn't let me in because obviously my iD was with my phone. I had to go look for my he people that used the restroom after me because security swore no one turned anything in but when they where faced to face with the people that turned in my phone they had no choice but to give it to me .... be careful with your personal things !!!! Container park employees love to steel !!!! Not the first time it's happened before r I have it a second chance like anyone else would

I feel a little bad not giving a 4-star review. It really is 4 stars for a tourist. I am writing, though, for locals such as myself. And my little review won't impact its overall excellent rating, which it deserves. But the fact is, I don't know that Downtown Container Park is all that engaging for those of us who live and work in the area. I am not aware of discounts or other promotions that appeal to Nevadans or Clark County denizens. It's hip, but not worth the downtown trip, and parking nightmare for the average resident.  But that doesn't mean that it is not a fun place, and a cheery atmosphere. It is super fun to lounge around this little oasis of shipping containers full of interesting tchotchkes, pubby food, and cute little outdoor park.  

To appeal to us locals, I would recommend some events, such as Shakespeare in the Park performances, or an occasional farmer's market, or outdoor movie, or some such thing (similar to what Tivoli does, which is a much more appealing locals spot), as well as some promotions or discounts! 

If you are a tourist and not too far from downtown, go there for at least a spare hour, if you have it! You won't be disappointed.

Bruhhh...this place is da day time and evening spot to be ladies and gentlemen...this is truly a must see awesome addition added to downtown with it's unique architecture being the place is made of actual Truck storage containers,hence the name "container Park"A place for the whole family to enjoy,live music,a safe park for children to play,good local based foods for all foodie type lovers. The greatest thing about this place is that it seems to support mostly Las Vegas locally based stores which is awesome and I do support since I am a local!!! Here is that drum Real question??????????would I ever go again???easy to answer"Absolutely"I actually just did...LOL

Environmentally friendly. Economical. Cool. Modern. These are all things someone can easily say about the unique Downtown Container Park. I'm always trying to convince my California visitors to move out to Las Vegas, and bringing them here is one way to do it. If this place were in SF, it would be as crowded as Dolores Park and filled with hipsters and trash. Since it's in Vegas, it's usually filled with families and very clean. I love the random performances during the course of the year. Although it's 3 stories high in some locations, the park is still pretty handicap-friendly with elevators, but some of the stores may be a bit tight to navigate. So far I love visiting the playground area, Kappa Toys and JinJu chocolates. My husband loves Cheffini's, but I haven't made it out their myself yet. There's a ton of food options here, and it's close enough to other downtown attractions if you just want to walk over.

What a sweet and great place for families and locals.
But please - get live music 7 nights a week!
people will come and eat if you have music .... promise!
I love the concept, the design, the stores, and the misting fans!
I would have stayed for drinks and dinner if there was live music ..... 
Playground for families.
BBQ joint, Oak & Ivy, Blu Marble, Hot Dogs, CupKates, and so much more!
But please  -- live music or movies nightly!!!!

I don't know what there is here to give a great rating and review or a bad one.   It's shipping containers completely modified to house retail shops and restaurants.   The spaces are as you would expect.   Small but some of them have been done in creative ways.   We didn't shop or eat so our experience was based solely on visual.   It's interesting briefly.   I wouldn't call it an attraction but if you downtown in the day doing Freemont or a museum or something it is worth walking over and checking out.

Cool little trendy dig.  Hipster family friendly and active interactive.  Nice hub for a bit of First Friday-like art or local business support.  There are a few restaurants including Mexican, bar food and even a Vegan chef there.  You can find boutique clothing like the Bettie Page lingerie and a separate Bettie Page shoe shop.  You can get a haircut at the Barber shop too.  In the middle is an enclosed play area that is attended by a clerk who makes sure that your kids can't just wander off.  It has a pretty tall multilevel fun house including a really long winding slide.  You can watch popular family movies from a giant projector on Thursday evenings.  There is a stage for what I think may be live acts.  When the sun is waning they make a semi impromtu drum circle and encourage the kids to play along while a giant Mantis emits flames.  Pretty cool.  The kick to it all is that it shows examples of green living and how even businesses can think outside of the box reuse abundant resources and still be sheik.  Lets see how this experiment plays out..

This was a cool little shopping center where the stores are running out of a storage container. It's a good visit if you're also in the area from the Fremont Street Experience. I came here in the evening time around the winter holidays so the lights made the ambience so much better. There was holiday themed decor and design. 

There are unique stores and restaurants in here. It's a unique local experience. 

Along with the stores, there is a play area in the center for kids but adults are able to go in and walk around. There are some cool slides and play structure to take cool pictures. 

It's a nice break from the Vegas life and cool to see something new.

During my recent visit to Vegas I took a walk down the Fremont Street Experience until the very end. I noticed a arched sign saying Fremont East District. I decided to cross the street and continued to walk until I noticed a big bug in front of a building. 

That building turned out to be the Downtown Container Park. The big bug was a praying mantis that shoots flames and it scared the bejeezus out of me. I jumped every single time the flames shot out.

I noticed a heart shape sculpture with a lot of padlocks. I believe it was the Lock of Hearts for Downtown Las Vegas.

I continued on towards the entrance where the security was standing. 
"May I help you?" Asked the security. 
"Is it alright if I walked around?" I asked.
"Go right ahead. It is a shopping center," was his response.

I passed the entrance and noticed a play area for children as well as kids at heart. There was a Mexican eatery, a store where you can purchase hot chocolate,  few other restaurants, a toy store, plus a big open area with a couple lounge couches for movie nights. 

I had asked a different security guard about the open area and he mentions that in the summer they would have at least two bands perform on stage daily. At 9pm it would be adults only because of all the alcohol being served.

That sounded very interesting. I may have to plan for a summer visit and experience what the Downtown Container Park has to offer.

This is a super cool concept - a bunch of different stores and restaurants in a central area, all housed in shipping containers! There's a treehouse in the middle of the "park" and lots of fun bars with patio seating etc. However, when my friends and I went (at 10 pm on a Sunday), it was almost completely deserted and most of the vendors were closed. I was pretty bummed because I was excited to check it out and thought it would be a nice break from the crazy business of Fremont Street. Apparently most everything closes at 11 pm on Sundays. (Thankfully we were able to get an amazing dog at Cheffini's!) It's 21+ after 9 pm, which is nice.

There is a big praying mantis sculpture at the entrance of the park that dances to music, talks and shoots fire... so that was interesting. 

Overall I believe this would be a really fun place to explore during the early evening hours, but definitely don't go after 10 pm on a Sunday!
Container Park is the new hipster hang out for the kiddies early in the day allowing even the parents to try out the variety of foods/desserts/wine/beers choices offered

This place is a great place usually very friendly and fun environment, but recently a friend of mine was there with another girl and as she was saying good bye they kissed goodbye. The security guard approached them and said they couldn't go that. Having a different social background you know most cultures outside of the USA kiss and what they did wasn't wrong  it was distasteful and makes it uncomfortable to go back

Cool shops and food!!!  But my only issue is the parking. $10 flat rate after 6pm?  WTF!  Come on, this isn't L.A., even L.A. isn't that expensive. I tried decreasing times, because there is no signage anywhere about rates. Okay!!!!  Why not?  Those fucking pay machines are a joke and too complicated, practically impossible to see the screen with the sun beating down. Normally you press print or OK the process your credit card and I was trying to cancel and the fuckers charged me 10 bucks any way. Definitely lost a client. I will not be driving down that way to use the businesses. Fuck Tony Shay for trying to make this place like some big city stop. Also just paid a $40 parking ticket I didn't even know I had. Thanks city of Las Vegas. You all suck.

Amazing park to have a leisurely lunch in the concrete jungle of downtown. Pork and beans is great and the open seating in the area makes for el fresco dining. Plus if u have kids they will LOVE the play pen jungle gym it's like climbing a pirate ship. He'll I wanted to start racing the kids to the top.  Bravo on the new hip spot downtown!

I was impressed how well the interiors of the individual containers came out. Overall structure, design, stage area, multiple levels and exterior windows provided a vibrant look and feel of the park. I also liked the characteristics design of the bars, restaurants and boutique shops. This park is located at the Bar District area and it made sense to include bars. However, a children's playground is placed in the center of the park surrounded with bars I believe was an oversight, huge! One would think that a "family park environment" would not be in plain sight of bars and people with beers in their hands getting drunk. Just to add, it appears that miscellaneous boutiques shops at the park to fill open containers. Who is coming to the park to shop??? I am a regular at the Container Park because of Ernie's BBQ which by the way is the ONLY closest BBQ joint in the area.

i didn't know what is was for the longest time but we went on a Friday night and it was one of the best nights i've had in a while. we came in with a big group of friends and start looking about. they have shops and food and music and A BIG PEOPLE PLAYGROUND. yes, my favorite part is the big people playground. they have a tree house with slides and bridges and wonder! they also have this touch light game. it was so much fun. they have different games you can play, one on one or even doubles. best part is watching your friends try and find their lights. HA! 
we also grab some drinks but you cant take them in the playground or outside the actual park, just a heads up. still was an awesome place.

This place was pretty fun. It was smaller than I expected...the children's park in the middle was fun for my little niece, but other than that, it was mainly just us walking around in circles. Definitely can see it as a hipster hot spot, with overpriced everything, including the cupcakes. Only plus side is that the park tuckered out my niece so we strolled off with her sleeping in her stroller. :-)

I love the container park!! It is one of the coolest things to do with friends- Locals or visitors does not matter!

There is always cool stuff going on here! Events, music, movies!

The food and stores are super cool! It is really great for kids! Right in the middle of all these awesome little LOCAL shops is a giant playground!

Go to the website, check out the calendar. I promise there is something fun coming up!! Or just go and check out the great little local merchants.

5+ stars!

The Container Park was such an awesome place to visit and quite honestly, one the highlights of my trip to Las Vegas. 

The area was still relatively new and we found it really quiet on an early Thursday afternoon. So we took advantage of the ample lawn space and practiced our handstands and cartwheels, hung off the ladders of the caboose, visited the barber, ate some jerky, lazed on the swinging bench, and watched some kids tag the brick wall with some chalk. All while the sun loomed high with nary a cloud in the sky.

The centerpiece was a tempting treehouse that was off limits because the scorching heat had turned it into a huge vertical frying pan. We entertained ourselves with the NEOS play system where we tuckered ourselves out with light-tagging challenges that sent us in cardio circles. Running under unrelenting heat rays sent us panting to the shade where we constructed a giant-sized Jenga set with the foam blocks. A nearby curious child joined our game and with his father's help, he managed a few key plays.   Another friend fashioned herself a couch complete with a drink kozzie and sat back chanting, "Jenga...Jenga...Jenga..."  What goes up must come down and down the tower tumbled at eight levels high, raining cushy blue rectangles to a chorus of mirth and merriment.

Intrigued by tales of the past-9 PM wonder hour, I will surely return the next time I am in the hood.

Artistically creatative. I'm hoping this brings the city more revenue. Prices seem to be pricer than one might expect for being downtown. 

Hoping more tourist make it down this way to share the Ora of a new age for the down town scene. I've brought my guest from California down here hoping to share some culture for them to spread.

There is a sense of no tolerance for negativity with security and law enforcement presence. I was happy to be able to see that their are boundaries and curfews inforced. ;) keep up the good work downtown project. I'm sure theirs many challenges ahead to turn around this area and proud to see iniative.

The best local shopping area in Vegas with a giant metal fire-breathing Praying Mantis. 

Yeah, as you walk-in a giant metal Praying Mantis greets you with a warm and cozy fireball blast, because why not. If that first sentence wasn't enough to tell, but place literally has everything. Coffee, clothing, ice cream, cat candles, novelty socks, hot dogs, tanning, toys from all over the world, whiskey, wine, craft beer, a jungle gym, BBQ, and high end beef jerky! Phew, that was mouthful! 

 A great place to take your out-of-town friends who are looking to do something other than the normal overpriced strip experience, plus the surrounding Downtown area has a ton of other entertainment, drinking and eating options. 

I highly suggest going to Oak and Ivy, Kappa Toys, Cheffinis Hot Dogs, JinJu Chocolates and Perch for a great view of the park and solid cocktail.

Shop. Eat. Enjoy. Local

My punishment in life is I make business plans out of everything I see. This place is unique and cool, but here are the problems- the tiny shops limit every store's footprint so they can't display/sell much product, hence they have to charge more. The restaurants have to have limited offerings (storage and prep space) and count on patrons eating outside in the heat. Most of the tiny shops don't have employee bathrooms but since the shops can't support multiple employees they have to close the door and run down the hall. The land acquisition and build out costs were surely high, so rents probably reflect that. There is no dedicated parking. I can't believe the locals would become repeat customers, so they have to rely on the tourists bubbling up Fremont Street. From a business perspective the place is most similar to airport kiosks- counting on throwing out a net and catching 10 out of 1,000 people passing by.  After 4 years the place has a vacancy rate of about 20% so what I'm seeing must be what others are seeing too.
Cute little boutique. Clearly designed to be child friendly (at least during the day - it might be another story at night). Lost of nice little restaurants and shops, and it's a cool concept.

Unique park in downtown that has restaurants, mini shops, and other specialty stores. They have this tree house in the middle that has a bunch of bridges and long slides. The lights and the whole concept of this place is pretty cool and of course, is great for taking pictures at. The food their is pretty over priced but hey you don't have to go there for the food. Overall, cute place!

P.S. - beware the preying mantis (or embrace it)

I like the CP because it is off the path a bit. Another nook of DTLV to explore. Cash or card to pay for street parking. Unique shops and food choices. A playground area for the kiddos. Concerts in the evening. I appreciate the one entrance/one exit with a staff member monitoring the patrons. I like the idea of small shops which can change throughout the year to hopefully keep the CP from becoming stagnant. I will be back- daytime only for me. The area outside of the park can be a bit sketchy after dark.

A flaming praying mantis!?...i had to check this out and I am quit happy i did! lots to do for all ages, kids and adults. Shops, playground, live music, food and booze. After 10pm it is 21 and over and you have the whole place venture and be a kid again.
   Highly recommend checking this place out!

Thanks to the "new businesses" section of Yelp, we found and visited this cool, innovative spot in downtown Las Vegas.

I love the idea of using shipping containers as businesses, and the atmosphere here is relaxed, friendly, and inviting.  I love that this casual, laid-back spot is just a couple of blocks from the frenetic Fremont Street Experience.

We wandered the shops of the Downtown Container Park and talked with several of the owners/workers.  We loved the playset in the middle, the stage (and lovely music coming from it), the fire-spewing praying mantis, the foam-rubber building set...

My husband kept saying, "We need a place like this in Seattle..."

This is clearly a great addition to downtown Las Vegas.  I'll be watching with interest to see how the Downtown Container Park -- and downtown Las Vegas in general -- evolve.

Pros:
  Plaza is made from shipping containers
  Three stories up
  Holiday decor
  Kids play area and tree house
  Security at the front gate (only entrance)
  Plenty of street parking ($2 an hour)
  Full bars and restaurants
Cons:
  None

Container Park is awesome and free to get in and check out. It's near Fremont but there's security and it's blocked off from the street so it's super safe.

When we went they had cocktail popsicles at one store and a bunch of different cute stuff. They had a beauty bar bus that has since closed down I believe. 

They had a lot of fun playgrounds for little kids and everything is made of recycled materials which is pretty awesome and gives me a new found appreciation of the place!!

this place sucks. very tiny area. kids can play but theres a couple tiny bar/restaurant areas. a few shops which no one seems to be buying anything at. there is public parking but u have to pay. downtown las vegas freemont st is very dirty, ghetto and smells like piss. not sure why people like this area so much. ya i wont be back

Excellent ideas, sustainability plans in place and clearly well executed. Definitely a Berkeley dream come true and trust me, when it comes to hippies, few people smell the hippie better than those of us out here in the Bay.

This is kinda like a strip club. Stay with me now. If the best "dancer" in the history of stripper poles was "dancing" at a club, but nobody went to that club cause it was not worth going to, would anyone know she's the best "dancer?" Of course not!

We were excited the night before when we saw the flames coming from the.... grass hopper? Praying mantis?? Whatever it was, it was cool. We just got done grubbing at eat across the road and wanted to check out what kind of stores were here to take our money. But here is the kicker. Crazy Legs leggings store is the best you could do? I mean, maybe cause I was in the house in January and the Flip Flop store wasn't on the radar cause it was 52 degrees midday. I just don't see how the businesses chosen were chosen to attract real money. Sure, I love some leggings and I was ready to stroll inside Crazy Legs and pickup somethin' sexy for my wife. Problem being, they were closed in the middle of the day. I know, I know. You can't please everyone all the time. If I had kids, I'd take them here to play around on the "tree" house and stuff, but I wrapped up in my twenties and don't have any kids. 

Overall, I can't say with great certainty that they missed the mark, but if you asked my opinion, I'd say with great confidence that they missed the mark.

Seriously though, wtf is a container park? I get the concept, but was unsure of the execution. Could a pile of containers really be cool? Would it be a tourist gimmick? A place that you see once, never to return? Well, it turns out it is cool, and I will return many times. 

There are several places to dine, imbibe and shop for quirky items. Mexican, BBQ, jerky, cupcakes, ice pops, cocktails... it's all there with plenty of outdoor seating to combat the small interior dining space. Bolt Barbers are there (in a caboose) to give you a cut 'n shave, there's a play area for the kids, a gigantic slide for drunk adults, live tunes and a massive grasshopper with flames shooting out of its antennas.... what's not to enjoy? There is something for everyone. I think it's definitely a must-see if you're downtown. (note: there might also be some sort of party dome here) 

I've never been to another container park, so there's really no comparison. For now, and possibly forever, it will be the best and worst container park I've even been to.

I go to Vegas every year for work and I've grown tired of the shenanigans on the strip and in casinos. When I heard about that there was a development that consisted of shipping containers, I thought it sounded cool until I heard it was in Downtown Vegas. Don't get me wrong, downtown has some neat parts but the area can be sketchy. 
When I learned that CP had a large fiery praying mantis, I told myself I had to check it out. I came back in January and visited again last week and I love this place. It's a nice retreat from the craziness of the strip and a lot of fun. I love the atmosphere, the restaurants (I've had good experiences at Big Ern's and The Perch) and the chocolate shop and candy shop have unique, tasty stuff.
I REALLY want to give it 5 stars but there are 2 reasons I cannot give it that final star:
1. The $10 flat rate (after 6pm) for parking seems too high
2. The top of the slide has been closed all 3 times I've gone. Seems silly but I'm bummed that an attraction like that isn't available.

I probably wouldn't have been here if it wasn't for my friend.  On the outside it doesn't look much but when you go in it's open and full of ma and pa shops.  I bet it's a lot of fun during the night though.  There were cute play areas for children with a supervisor watching them and making sure they are safe.  There wasn't a lot of shades so it gets very hot.  

I would totally come here again especially at night.
Loved container park!  They have very good vegan food and cool shops.  I would return in a minute and if I moved to Vegas, I'd try to move Downtown.

Cool art and food area to walk through all housed in containers - you could make a meal of drinks in one place, main in another, and dessert in  third. Fun and all the shop folks are friendly and helpful. I tried several of the restaurants and didn't go wrong.

The only Vegas attraction I was completely and utterly disappointed by. For one thing, you can't smoke anywhere on the property (in Vegas?). Most wouldn't be bothered by that, but when you're with a group of adults it's annoying to have people break off to smoke and come back. But maybe it would be worth it if the shops had interesting things? Not really. If you live in a city of any size, there's nothing you can buy at DCP that you couldn't find in your hometown. Or order off Etsy. Prices were outrageous, shop staff were unfriendly (most didn't even say hello when you walked in). What's more, not only were most stores NOT air conditioned, most didn't even have fans or anything else to abate the oppressive Vegas heat (remember, these are steel shipping containers!). So one had almost NO incentive to stay and browse. 

Before my visit I checked out many of the vendor's websites and found one that claimed to offer "fresh limeaid" (complete with a photo of a condensation-covered glass pitcher full of lime slices). I went to the shop and was told they didn't have anything like that, and never had. To his credit, the helpful employee offered to make a "limeaid" out of sno-cone syrup, but that's not the same thing at all. I eventually found a drink, but was puzzled as to which of the 8 trash\recycling receptacles I was supposed to put the now-empty cup in (and I wan't the only one). Since my hands were sticky (every surface at DCP seemed sticky, for some reason), I had to use the horrific restrooms to wash my hands. 

The bottom line is this: your home city has a "funky" neighborhood, right? Like Plaza Midwood here in Charlotte, or Little Five Points in Atlanta? Take half those shops, fill them with a quarter of the merchandise, jack up the prices by 75% and put the whole thing in uncomfortable steel boxes in a bad part of town and you have the DCP. This place is living proof that you can't "make" cool or interesting... it just has to happen. DCP is kind of a cheesy, hipster Epicenter (Charlotte) or Underground Atlanta, and it's not even a good one at that. There was nothing there to hold the attention of four college-educated adults, which is why we planned to stay at DCP for 2 hours, but only ended up spending 30 minutes there.

If you are looking for hipster Las Vegas, this is where you will find it. 

Just a short stroll from Fremont Street where the old Las Vegas is, is a park that is made completely from old shipping containers. You know you've arrived when you see a large metal praying mantis guarding the entrance.

Everyone knows it's HOT in Vegas right? Shipping containers are made of metal. So, it feels extra hot in this park. But, I think because it looks so run down, compared to the glitz on the Strip that everyone imagines when they think of Vegas, there is a cool hipster vibe to this place.

In this little complex - there are restaurants (many that are on Eater's recommend list), little shops, a fake grass area where you can play with a life sized connect four, jenga, or just run around, and also a kids playing area.

There are misting stations all around - absolutely necessary as it is so HOT in here, but all in all really fun to check out and walk around.

I probably would not go out of my way to come here, but if you are already checking out Fremont Street, then you might as well hit up this spot too and check it off your list.

We came here looking for Ice Cream and found some made with Nitrogen. Man was it great I almost didn't give my wife any, it was delicious. the park and all the stores are very cool. Didn't have time to shop but will make more time to do so next time in Vegas.

This is a great place to bring kids. There were large blocks for the kids to play with in front of a stage. The playground is located in the center if the park and is huge. There is an attendant who makes sure kids can not exit on their own. I was able to grab some food and watch my kids while they played. 

There were plenty of food options. A new Dome featuring short films just recently opened. Parking is plentiful but requires a credit card.  Its is a short walk from Fremont Street, but way more child friendly.

Wow, now this is a place you will have fun. It's not trashy and it seems to be hooker free. The big screen with music videos is a nice touch. We ate Mexican food there before our flight and it was good. They have a good variety of food to choose from and a cool toy store where I bought a whoppie cushion for my son. I would recommend this place for anyone wanting to escape the crowds of Vegas. Also the adults can play on the playground which is cool. Just don't be the creepy single guy hanging by the slides!  Highly recommend this place!

This place is pretty cool.  The giant praying mantis outside is neat to look at, and the atmosphere is great.  I wish they had more stores in the park, but I will say when I went to visit it, it had just opened.

One thing that kind of made me crazy though was that the flooring for the upstairs walkway is see-through, and you have to kind of mentally prepare yourself and reassure yourself you wont fall through.  It is very sturdy, but the mental thing is does to you is distracting.  lol.

They always have live bands playing here and its walking distance to Fremont Street.  Parking was easy.  I really enjoyed it and will be back next time I am over in that area.

Great place to take kids, there is a giant play area right in the middle of it.

If you ever think Vegas is only about partying and excess, head down to the Arts District and check out Container Park. 

This park is great for families and is surrounded by great art. It has great shopping and food options as well as "Black Cup" coffee and some alcohol options as well. It's a short walk down Fremont from the Fremont Street Experience

This place is truly amazing! 
It brings the flash together with the creativity of Las Vegas!
Many of the shops are run by and for local artisans. The offerings in the shops are largely unique items mixed with the trendy and whimsical. 
The live music tonight just added so much to the experience.
More of the stores should be complete and open for their grand opening on Dec. 5. I can hardly wait to return!!

Been here once. It's small, lots of shops. Live music. The praying mantis lights fire around 9pm. I personally didn't like it. It's very much for families. I felt awkward. So my date and I found other things to do. Wasn't my thing, might try it again one day. But not anytime soon.

What a disappointing experience I had at the Downtown Container Park this weekend!  Bought tickets to their On Cloud Wine Tasting event and it was a complete waste of money!  They only had two tasting stations set up right next to the live band.  It was so loud you couldn't even communicate with the people pouring the wine!  Wines offered were very limited and of such a low quality that they were undrinkable. After only two samples we opted to leave the event. Definitely will not be attending any future events at this venue!
So much fun! went during the day so we didnt get to see the fire spitting mantis. But it is definately worth a visit or ten!

So this is a cool and trendy place, think "soda sopa" from Southpark. It's kind a of a gem compared to the surrounding Fremont St area, walking thru the gate you can immediately tell the clientele difference. The fire breathing pray mantis is beyond cool (pretty much a burning man mutant vehicle) and free to watch the show, well worth stopping by.  The kids tree house is fabulous with technology and tons of stuff to keep kids occupied for hours.

Unfortunately all of that is wasted on this containers park security and management .We arrived at the park at 8:30pm Friday May 25th,2018 with our two young boys who darted right to the tree house and started to have a good time. At 9pm the musician/dj/whatever gave a half ass announcement over the PA system that the place was closed to anyone under 21 years old and anyone under 21 to please make you way out. Sure no problem we understand, it would have been nice to have some warning but we understand these things and packed up the kids and headed out. On our way out we stopped by waffelato to grab some icecream for the adults and kids. This is where container park goes to 100% pure trash and should be ashamed of themselves. In the middle of getting our ice cream and very rude security guard busted in and told us our kids weren't allowed in the store and we had to leave now. Not get complete your transaction and be on your way, nope get the hell out of the store right now and let someone else finish your transaction. Not only was this extremely rude and embarrassing it made my kids break down and cry. Even the remaining customers in waffelato commented on how rude and awful it was for security to force paying customers our of the store. 

So a big FU to container park, the security staff, the management staff and I hope Tony Hsieh reads about this as his money is being pissed away by management who shouldn't be managing a trashcan let alone a trendy complex.  Don't believe me? pull the video camera recording from the evening from Waffelato.

To the business manager Kristine R who will read and try and flag this. Don't bother replying to this with some half assed policy reply, you guys messed up. Your yelp reviews are littered with the same horrible security. Kicking out kids and paying customers will eventually come around and bite you in the ass. Thanks for making my kids cry @$$holes

Good use of freight containers; quite creative, I must say. But is it too creative at the retailers' expense or possibly their demise?

If a shop is making a killing, imagine the sales per square feet (as long as the rent isn't too bad)! That is great! But the shops confined in those containers, although not all, are perhaps at risk of not "making it." The shops selling food and drinks may do well enough, but the boutique shops I'm afraid are so empty of buying customers. The Disney art shop has some nice art to sell but I just see a lot of shoppers, like me, who were just there to look. 

It's a nice concept. As a consumer, it's a good place to burn an hour or two. But it's not a destination park/shopping center. I can see myself going there to get a drink or grab something light to eat, although I can probably get the same things elsewhere, but definitely not to shop. 

The place is kid-friendly with a nice tree house and play place in the center, but no kids are allowed after 9:00 PM. Oh, the irony. So why have such a good portion of the real estate for the kids when they only have a limited time. Perhaps it is for the best and safety of the children; this is downtown after all. 

The performance area is nice. There's even a barbershop behind it. Why it's back there? I do not know, but nice use of old boxcars. And of course, one cannot miss the fire-breathing preying mantis at the park entrance.

It's industrial art in an urban setting with its retailers hoping to generate enough sales to stay in business in years to come. I like the art part but the one thing it may have trouble with is staying relevant in this town, never mind making enough money. Even Mayor Oscar Goodman tried so very hard to make Las Vegas a city of art but it just isn't. People don't come to Vegas for art. There's not enough locals to fully support the art aspect alone. Art has struggled in this town.

It would be nice to one day have a true art museum in town with different art installations and exhibits on display -- and I am not just talking about art galleries inside the mega hotels. But I realize once again that this is Las Vegas.

went for secret walls, I had been once before but it was during the day when kids were allowed. Much more fun at night with the 21+ crowd 
The place is aesthetically really beautiful, lots to look at & admire. 
Drink prices were steep here- wouldn't recommend getting alcohol here, it's overpriced and just average tasting. 
The actual event though was really fun! Got pulled on stage, won a free shirt 
It's a cute place, I'm sure I'll be coming back. 
If you want free parking, park a few blocks away and walk. Or pay. It's up to you

Visited here today with a group of friends and enjoyed the wonderful restaurant The Perch.  Location and setting was inviting and a great way to enjoy the Park....menu is really nicely balanced...enjoyed the Power Salad !
Can't wait to come back for brunch!
We went to Fremont street for the first time and stumbled upon this place! It was so cool! Neat idea making buildings out of storage containers. We walked around, got a few beers and window shopped.

Don't miss the container Park. It is a great addition to Downtown Las Vegas. Be sure to support the mix of shops, food and drink places. 
Make sure you stay after dark to enjoy the flame throwing matis. There is plenty of convenient meter parking on the street and lots.

The flavor of this space was amazing, I really loved the open park for children.  Child spaces are lacking for tourists in Vegas, but this was very nice.   
Wheelchair access was decent outside of the shops, but the inside of the shops were so crammed, that with many I could barely get my chair past the front door. Ramps are also not well labeled, and some feel like they run right through dining spaces, which left me feeling like I was intruding.  The bathroom was difficult with a wheelchair as the bathroom opens on the wrong side, so you have to go fully in, hit the sink, turn around and then eek your chair in.

Melvin is the rudest security guard and I work at a county jail! We came all the way from Seattle to see this only to be selected to be removed for not following rules that were not even clear that an area was closed.

*Sigh*

There are a lot of haters in this world - hipsters who think it's, well, hip to hate on Vegas.  I've lived here over 12 years and have heard all of their whiny, skinny-jean clad complaints.  
"Ew, it's like Capitalism on steroids there!"  
"Ew, they don't recycle as much as the rest of the world!"   
"Ew, it's too touristy."  
"Ew, there is no culture there!"
"Ew, there is no sense of community!"

Well, hang on to your scarves and beanies (that you're wearing in 90 degree weather) because Downtown Container Park is the contradiction to all of the above statements.  Most of the business that reside there are local -  contradicting the complaint about capitalism.  Dudes.  The whole park is a grand display of recycling and reusing.  Um, I guess it is somewhat touristy - but what cool thing isn't???  Fact - not all touristy things are cool, but most cool things are touristy.  Maybe.  I dunno. 

There are art displays, local musicians playing, a nightly drum-circle for peace, so there's your culture.  As for a sense of community, when I attended my first drum circle there I couldn't help but feel a swell of pride in my bosom (tee-hee, bosom)  to be part of the wonderful community that is Las Vegas.  Locals will love it - tourists will love it - it's one place we can all come together, beat on a drum, eat some tacos and just enjoy life for a bit.  Well done, Downtown Container Park.  Well done.

Great little park surrounded by incredible food and a cool fire breathing praying mantis at the entrance. Was there with a friend to eat, but there was a cool movie in the park for families which I intend to take my daughter to.

Container park what a unique setting. The architecture here is amazing. Defiantly if visiting pop in here because it's actually one of the best shopping areas around in my eyes. 
If you are a foodie like me they have all type of places there. From stoned and baked a personal pizza shop to vegan options to jojos jerky to candy shops. They have a lot here. I'm never hungry when I'm there that's for sure. Maybe while your out shopping you would like a cocktail? Stop in at Oak & Ivy for a hand crafted cocktail made by elite bartenders in the industry. You can go to the second floor and try the Perch, a restaurant over looking the park with out door eating and great cocktails. 
Many toy shops and candy shops for the kids to go to. Also they have a park for kids to burn energy on. So if you go with your kids at least there is a lot to do for them. At night this place gets busy and quite beautiful I must say. It's a great environment to try day or night, local or not local. Container park is a great spot to entertain and spoil yourself or loved ones!

Despite my anticipation I must say I am slightly disappointed with DCP.  It is very small, crowded, and the bathrooms were very dirty.   Although the atmosphere is nice on today's adventure is seemed more like it was being used for a downtown babysitting station than a staple of downtown growth.

Not going to totally rule out this place as I love the fact of showcasing local businesses and talent, but today was not the day that seemed to be happening.

I will give this place another try when a concert or event is occurring and try some of the cuisine, as several restaurants are appealing.  

On a positive note, DCP is very easily located with plenty of parking around the immediate area, and the local flair is obvious.   

I am sad to say I will only be giving this place 2 out 5 stars as the potential is there, and I want to love this place.  I will give it another try before my final decision is rendered.

5 stars for the unique concept alone! This is a really cool place to have lunch or meet a friend. All of the vendors are based in containers made into stores/offices. There is a huge area for kids to play. I wish the vendors the best. . . some of them I can't see surviving.

PROS: Pinches Tacos
             Cool outdoor sitting areas

CONS: Shopping wasn't very interesting
             Cost $$ to park

Quite shocked at how much I liked the place. Surrounded by downtown Vegas that I really don't find appealing in the least this place is a gem. 

A neat idea, clean and well designed with some really good food and a central play area for the kids that is very nice. Live music and an open air feel to everything makes we want to bring the family down for a bite to eat. 

Just the sort if thing I see as a positive rebuilding downtown. 

As with anything downtown parking is not the best and being at the easy end of the redevelopment the surrounding area is a bit sketchy but well patrolled by metro and security. 

Downtown is going in the right direction and and I think I will be back here with the family. Definitely worth a visit.
Fun but since it was hot some of the slides were closed and when we bypassed that we got kicked out. We are adults, a warm slide won't kill us. That blonde girl was a bit aggressive.

Hipster version of Town Square.

The container park is essentially 200 square foot re-purposed containers stacked upon each other to create a outdoor shopping mall. Most of the units were vacant during the soft opening but I am sure they will fill-up as time passes. Many of the stores were boutiques selling handmade clothing, accessories and snacks, along with a few art galleries. Keep in mind that unlike other shopping areas you won't find any franchise or chain stores here. This place is excellent collection of Mom n Pop style shops... small businesses ftw!

The park itself is beautiful; another great architectural addition to downtown. A giant fire breathing preying mantis greets you at the entrance. The centerpiece is a massive children's playground making the Container Park a great family friendly spot. The outdoor stage for shows and grassy field is going to be great for summer shows and is flanked by plenty of bars to drink up at. The atmosphere is friendly and the park is fun to just run around and explore.

The Container Park is a must-see for any downtown trip and really illustrates how much the whole DTLV scene is evolving.

I love this place. I went earlier tonight with my chic & stumbled upon a cool karaoke concert for children's cancer. Had some drinks & BBQ at Big Ern's while watching the acts. There's also a dope beef jerky store. They even have cactus jerky. Also, I like the big treehouse. It was like I was 7 yrs old again lol Great place to chill & hang out downtown.

Really cool and innovative spot.  One of the contaners serves as a chapel as well.    If you are ever on Freemont Street and have a few minutes to spare, I would recommend a vist to the container park.   It's family friendly as weil with an area for outdoor movies and other entertainment toward the back of the park.

Came here to check out this new place on Saturday during our Fri-Mon visit. We ended up coming back Sunday and Monday right before we drove back home to Costa Mesa, CA. This place has so much to experience... and for all ages. They have a great variety of stores and restaurants to choose from whether you're eating or just drinking. They have live entertainment and an awesome playground. There's an area for the little ones too! Definitely visit this place. I'm sure you'll be back again. Either for a cup of coffee or a bag of jerky. People watching is also fun.

I almost feel bad giving this three stars, but we went today earlier in the day with my 7 year old and three adults.... 7 year old played in the fort thing and found a friend, had a great time. We walked down to the Fremont street experience and decided to have dinner there in the park. We walked back and ordered our meal (at about $20 a plate for tacos and beer!!!!) around 8:48 and my daughter asked if she could go out and see the mantis on fire... I told her yes! Then my husband went to get her and they told her she couldn't come back in!!!!!  She walked back in anyway. At 9:00 they announced that if you are under 21 the park is closing.  Mind you we were still waiting of our meal! This was Saturday night. So we then felt like we had to rush through our  meal we had JUST purchased in order to leave with the under age one. Not so great. If they are marketing this for families, then it needs to be that- 9pm is not that late for families on a weekend. If they aren't, then market it that way but they do need to decide what it is. I didn't appreciate having to rush through my meal.

I am glad this opened up in my neighborhood town! People used to be scared of Fremont Downtown, but now--this changed it all! This is a kid-friendly, couple-engaging, community based experience that encourages art and music for all seasons and ages.

I been there at 9pm this Thursday, we just stop by to explore a bit and check inside, after a couple of pictures we decided to have a quick drink inside of the oak & ivy Bar, but we have to rushed cause we just pay for 30 min of parking outside, anyway in our way out the security guy in the front gate try to stop us of take our drinks out!!!!!!! Are you kidding!!! I just pay 24 dollars plus tip was $30 BUCKS!!! Is understood when people try to bring things inside cause they need to do business and make sales to keep the place up, BUT GUYS !!! DONT TELL ME I CANT TAKE MY DRINKS OUT AFTER I PAY $30 BUCKS FOR TWO Drinks!'!!!!! HELL NOT.

Super nice park downtown made of recycled materials, the shops and restaurants look like refurbished shipping containers and there was a playground in the center for the kids.  There's a huge fire shooting praying mantis out in front of the park that scared me at first sight!  We went on a Friday night and there was a great performer on stage Daniel Park who played multiple instruments and even took requests.  He sounded amazing!  Just had a nice time experiencing the atmosphere here and want to come back to hang out again!
Really cool concept!! We came 2 times in 4 day visit! Little shops and food places all made from containers! The praying mantis shooting fire is so awesome to see!! Definitely check it out!

Sounds like fun - but alarming to find that no one responds to your FB inquiries although it says "typically replies instantly"; YELP has the opening business hour as 10am but the park's info says 11am-which is it?  Wanted to buy tickets for the U2 show at the Dome but can't just buy the tickets - the park won't sell me just dome tickets ... forcing me to buy family packages or dinner+movie deals which I don't want.  

I've been to the park and its a really great place - but we live in a digital world.  If the Park can't get someone to work the social media and website duties responsibly I foresee a heavy impact on the amount of business the park will get.

This is an add-on to my original post that was never published.  We made it to the Dome and it was a DUD.  Even the small ones are going to get bored to death that is if the unsecured reclining seats don't kill you first.  Great idea, bad execution.  Don't waste you time or money.

This place is super cool, especially for those with kids. It's new so they have a few things to work out, but overall very happy to have this downtown. Mainly, I wanted to post a review of the store Crazy Legs. The staff was unprofessional and they have no return policy even though there are no dressing rooms! AVOID CRAZY LEGS!

Ohh my gosh why did I wait so long to come here? I was in the area with my sister and two boys (8 and 4) and we decided to check it out since I've heard so many good things about it. The park was an instant hit for my boys, they ran straight to the guarded gated park and off they went. I like how they have a few attendants within the park making sure everyone is playing nicely. They really have something for everyone. I walked around and really wanted to check out the shops but of course the minions didn't want to leave the park so I'll have to come back to with the boyfriend. 

If you want a nice secured place to hang out with your kids or friends you should definitely check it out. There restaurants, ice cream shops, and stores to keep you busy. There's the famous prey mantis in the front welcoming you.

Really cool small outdoor shopping mall built out of shipping containers. 3 stories high in some parts. Full of neat little shops, restaurants, snack and dessert places. 

They have a really cool play area for the kids, what appears to be a stage for live events and a really cool praying mantis out front that shoots flames from its antenna.

You are able to by alcohol at many of the locations and they allow you to carry them with you as long as you remain in the container park. We ordered drinks while taking advantage of happy hour pricing and walked around the park. This is something you should do if you are in the Fremont area.

JoJo's jerky offers free samples of jerky and BBQ sauce. They also sell flavored and roasted nuts. We bought some tasty BBQ sauce to take home. Very tasty!

Wow am i thoroughly impressed with this place. I could be slightly happier without all the kids running and screaming but hey, its cool DT has a place that is family friendly without all the crazy crack heads.
Ive visited a few times now and Ive been lucky enough to check out almost every store/restaurant. Bin 702 wins for the bar/restaurant for me and blumarble as well as DTLV win for the shops. Gabby Olivia is pretty awesome as well. 
Im so excited that these places are all local companies. That is really important to me since Im a 5th generation Las Vegas girl. This will def be my new hang out spot.

Super fun place to hang out! Tried bin 702 for a grilled cheese and hit up the bar across for drinks.  Went after the shops closed so it was quiet. It was ok. Maybe we came at the wrong time but I wasn't overly impressed. It seemed pretty boring when we were there so I'm only giving it 4 stars as opposed to 5. It would be nice if there was a little more of a night life though
Really cute place and kid friendly. There's a playground right in the middle of the park. Love the individual unique stores and artwork.

I wanted to go to the Container Park to see the giant praying mantis. It's mostly small boutique shops and eateries with a few activities for kids. It was so blazing hot while we were there that we could have fried some eggs on one of the containers.

Cute place to hangout at away from the strip and in the downtown area.  

A few shops around and very nice dcor.  

Such a great concept using shipping containers.

This is a nice place to check out. The praying mantis was impressive and it's easy to include this stop if you're heading to the Freemont Street casinos.  Only three stars because it's small and can been seen rather quickly. Fun to see at least once and in good proximity to other fun sights -worth a stop.
After 9 you must have a photo ID. Good low key fun, help give these new businesses a shot!

Sorta disappointed in the lack of stores that were occupied. Loved the art displays and the giant tree house, but not a lot to choose from to eat or drink, and even though it's an open area you can only smoke in designated areas.

I was very impressed with the park they were able to create downtown. The quick food options are great, as well as the pubs. I am particularly fond of Pinche Tacos and the wine bar, Bin 702. My children enjoy the Disney gallery and the treehouse playground. I imagine this is the only place in the world where one can see a praying mantis shoot flames from its antennae.

Love this place. The concept is crazy, innovative and needed. 

My boo and I walked around and some authentic Mexican food.
I love container park and the popcorn shop in here. Ive made great memories here and will continue to support it :))

What an awesome palve to hang out and take your kids outside the strip. 

This place is located by downtown las vegas. There's pay parking by the streets and theres also a pay parking lot across the street.

You will be greeted by a giant praying mantis that has a fire show shooting off his antenna every once in a while. 

There a giant fenced tree house with play ground for the kids. They even have security watching over the kids. 

The whole place is surrounded by shops and restaurants.

Awesome park. Never seen a place like this before. Ginormous praying mantis made of scraps of metal outside. Their is a game inside that if you hit the buttons in the right sequence fire shoots out from the top. There is a hot dog place inside that's pretty good as well. There is also a bar that's good too. They also have local bands play as entertainment.

This is a great place to stroll through. They have little own boutiques and restaurants made out of shipping containers. It's a great place to take kids and hang out with family and friends. The night that I went they had a jazz band in the park. It was relaxing and a nice experience. I really enjoy this place

Fun little area. Definitely family friendly. Just a few blocks away from the "Fremont Experience." 
Cute little shows at night and music. Praying mantis lights up, blows fire, and dances. 

Local eats are a bit pricey but fun to check out. Kids tried the popcorn place, husband tried the beef jerky and nut place, but the one that stood out was the gourmet hotdog spot so skip the others and try that first!

The city turned shipping containers into little shops. This spot is very family friendly on most days but some evenings are closed to drinking age adults only due to special events. There are lots of neat little stores like a toy store and reptile shop. Also, you'll find plenty of food options. The treehouse at the center of the park is pretty amazing for the kids and the grasshopper sculpture at the entrance isn't bad either, especially since it shoots flames in time to music.

This part of town is really becoming a great place. I really liked the concept of this area. No druggie beggars inside, the food at the barbecue place was very good, everything is recycled, kids can play, and no gambling. Fun place to hang out. I'll come back next time.

Finally came here to check this place out. Walked over here in the heat from Fremont Street Experience. This is a couple of blocks down from Las Vegas Bl. This park is not as big as I thought but cool things to see like the heart of locks in front and the big praying mantis but recommended to go at night to see the mantis. All the structures here are built out of storage containers. There are restaurants and stores and in the middle a playground for kids. Overall a different thing to see in Vegas for me one time was good but I may go back just to see the praying mantis at night.
Great little place for the kids to burn off steam and parents can enjoy a cup of joe!  A few small places for a bite to eat!  My favorite is cupcake place!

Frequent the Park Often Love the atmosphere Resturants,Childrens play area and my Favorite is  the Sweet Spot Candy store......Very Dissapointed that after 9 I could not even sit on the steps outside the main entrance with my children in a stroller.The Security guard said we would have to stand on the sidewalk! Really........I totally get the whole 9pm thing inside, but find it ridiculous you cannot sit even out side the park. The security guard was rude and actually laughed at me. If you want to re amp downtown and make Las Vegas more Family friendly you should reconsider somethings!!

Can't believe i haven't been in the Container Park before last eve. The best thing about this place is the treehouse play area in the middle. There is only one entrance/exit supervised by a kiddy bouncer. My kid was on fire running around. She'd been there before and was begging to go. Couldn't get her to leave, even 3 hours later. That in itself is worth it.

I really didn't get to look around much aside from grabbing a drink as didn't want to leave the immediate park area. Am sure there are some fun shops, but I'm not a shopper so really didn't care. Will be back, and soon.

There is an amphitheatre area that could be good, but vacant last eve. It is a small area so not overwhelming.

Being there I did not feel like I was in LV or anywhere near the strip, and oh what a feeling of joy that can be!

I have strongly positive feelings for this place that outweigh my misgivings most of the time. First my reasons to stop in- 
The outdoor park is incredible for  my younger (8 and 5 y/o) children to play. There's always other kids and they'll play for hours especially on the unique electronic giant thing. Sometimes there's live music which is always nice. If their Dads with us I'll wander to my friend Jessica Galindos cool shop, the galleries and to get a sample of jerky from Jojos. I've gone to this mall since the soft opening so unfortunately several places I really liked are already out (some back to only their original downtown locations at least) due to the short term nature of leases. There's some new ones but I haven't bought anything really special that's still available except leggings from Crazy Legs and random gifts from art box. I've also given up on any food options outside of snacks from the vegan place or the candy or cupcake shops for the kids. The meal places all were either too pricey for the food (big erns, pinches tacos) or wildly inconsistent good/bad food (bin 702) pork n beans was undercooked beans and they're closed now. Sweet Spot was always great but packed every time now which is the biggest drawback of the place. Tourist central!!! 90% of the friends on the playground are from out of town any time we've gone. And it's a mall plain and simple.  Ive never been for the night life time when shops are closed so no comment to that. So with the knowledge that it's a mall and everything that stands for I have a hard time wanting to go but when we're in the neighborhood it's hard to say no to playtime in that treehouse!

This container park is a welcome addition to a really previously junky part of town. Actually, the case can be made it's still a bit neglected up here, but this innovation is a good start. Locals will be quick to tell you this project was made possible by Zappo's, and that's cool, but it's also moot. The point is it's just nice to see the downtown springing back to life!

The container recycling concept is really catching on. I've seen containers used to build seaside condos, but this is the first time I've seen them used in this little outdoor mall/entertainment center format.
