The centerpiece here (and this will surprise some of you downtown Vegas purists) is actually a playground right smack in the middle, where dozens of screaming kids run wild. The whole park is very much family centric, and if you're in the downtown to party, this is not your place.

Otherwise, if the Griswalds need a break from the Old Strip, you'd do worse than to bring them here.

I love this place, The Amantis with the fire, kids playing instruments on the weekends, live music, and after 9:00 pm only for adults.
Is always clean and nice. Take a moment to go with your family.

What a neat place this is.  I saw an ad for it on the flight to vegas and we decided to walk down when we were on Freemont street.  It is a cool little street park made of shipping containers.  Restaurants stores and shops of all kinds with a play ground and stage in the middle.  It's a must do if you are in the area.

I can say very neat little park lots of shops plenty for kids to do I'll take you more than four hours to go through all the shops and look around and buy things but there's plenty for the kids to do downstairs in the Lego area movie night unlimited popcorn so why the parents go gamble get your kids here they will have a blast

Thought I'd add my 2 cents. 

The container park is a fun outing if you're in the area, but as of now I wouldn't make a special trip there. 

The concept is cool but I really think they need more space. Walking around the entire area, including all three floors, MIGHT take 15 minutes. Which doesn't really encourage people to stay and browse. 

I spoke to one shop owner who said she wont be renewing her lease. She's just not making enough to cover rent. And with the minuscule sizes of the "shops" (think boarding house room), I can see why. 

Perhaps if they had some festivals here where the shop owners could put their merchandise out on tables it would help them a bit.  But with how crowded the shops feel, if you are claustrophobic (or salesperson-ophobic), you don't really want to go into the shops. I think they're so small and the salespeople are so desperate that you feel like you'll be assaulted by them the moment you step in the door. So what happens? You don't (or at least I don't) go in. 

The playground is pretty cool. Theres a Huge treehouse and foam building blocks the kids enjoyed playing with. 
The praying mantis is interesting (though the sudden bursts of flame from its antennae terrified my four year old),  but thats not enough to get me to come all the way downtown from hendertucky. The playground is also pretty spread out and if you have more than one child its a nightmare to keep track of them all. The bandstand is a nice idea but the bands can be LOUD and theres really not enough seating to encourage people to stay and listen. 

The only food i tried was the ice cream shop. That was quite frankly a nightmare. They fresh made ice cream for my son - sounds great right? Yeah, except it literally took them twenty minutes to make it! My other kids were done by the time he got his, and i was late getting back to the parking meter and got a parking ticket! That alone was enough to make me not ever want ice cream from there again. Get with it people. This is VEGAS. It is HOT. I do not want to wait twenty minutes for ice cream even if its hand made by Willy Wonka himself and given to me on a jewel encrusted platter made for Elvis by Tony Hsieh. Pre-make your handmade ice cream  for Pete's sake!

Yeah. 

Otherwise its an interesting little jaunt that could kill an hour or two. 

Four stars.

Really great place and visually stunning. Came here to get my hair blown out and was surprised by the layout. Very cool! I'm not a local, but would come back here to visit the shops and spend some dollars next time I'm in town. Wonderful mix of shops. Good work!

This is a really original park for Vegas. It's a super innovative park. I love all the repurposed shipping containers for shops, restaurants, and bars. Great place to come as a family with good live music playing or after dark for adults only cocktail time.

This is a nice place to spend a couple of hours having a drink, browsing the shops and having dinner. If you have kids, they will probably enjoy the playground, but they have to be out of the park by 9:00.  The drum circle to wake the preying mantis is pretty cool (I think it is a preying mantis?). It shoots fire.  

If you like taqueria food, definitely don't miss Pinche's Tacos and their blood orange margaritas!
I love this place!  I can't believe I didn't know about the jazz here! I can't wait til spring time comes, I will be hanging out here drinking my beer from Cheffins, and eat eating a chilli dog!
Cute area with art , food , and shops ! A little gem in the heart of it all . Def worth going to '

Soaking up the Downtown scene and seeing all the new changes they've made... I gotta say I'm thoroughly impressed with all the establishments in here and the little community they've built. The Vegas vibe is nonexistent in this community which is a refreshing change up from the vegas scene. I highly recommend everyone living here and visiting to check it out! Good job Tony Hsieh :)

Such a great concept and fits in perfectly downtown. Greeted with a flame throwing preying mantis your attention is grabbed right away. There is security at the gate checking ID's to go into the park. I suppose you need to be 21 after a certain time but they weren't saying much and nothing was posted. We asked around looking a the shops, some which were closed or not open yet, it was hard to tell. There is a play area in the middle for kids and the far end has a stage for concerts /performers with a grassy area to watch these entertainers. Food, clothing, and art were some stores that caught my eye and  The Vapor shop that we entered. I hope this place does well it's a cool idea.
Nice place watch out door movies live music free wifi a nice place to relax at night in downtown las vegas

YELP 365 CHALLENGE 2014-(87/365) "Start Up Businesses"

Love the cool vibe and the atmosphere here at DCP. I especially love when people walk right past the Giant Praying Mantis and get the CRAP scared out of them!  LOL!!! 

Cool concept and great way to help local businesses get their start, but like other reviews state, the prices here are cray-cray especially when you know there's other spots to grab a bite that are close to DCP,  and doesn't rip you off *cough* The Goodwich, Tacos El Buen Pastor, Rollin' Smoke BBQ,  Art of Flavors *cough, cough*

AHEM!!! *clears throat* Anyway, it's a good place to hang out after dinner(and after 9pm for adults only) The live music stage is cool, and so is the huge slide! Haven't checked out any of the little boutiques yet, but maybe we'll do so on our next visit. ALOHA!!!

Shaka Meter:  \uuu/  \uuu/  \uuu/  \uu  3.5

Visit Eastside Fremont The Container Park where you can go down an adult 3 story slide, catch some live acts and grab a vegetarian wrap. Check out the praying mantis at night. It shoots out fire out of it's antenas to the beat of the music. Surrounding the container park you will find about two dozen different unique boutiques and specialty eateries built within shipping containers, stacked two-story high. During the day is a perfect place to bring the family, once the sun goes down it's 21 and up.


#Fremont #FremontExperience #ContainerPark #AdultPark #3storyslide #drinkswelcome #thedome #prayingmantis
My kids and I really enjoyed our Saturday night here, it is so nice to have a family friendly spot in downtown LV.

I guess it's a start.  The problem is it has no identity.  It's a lot like South Street Seaport in New York.  There are some retails stores and of course bars and restaurants.  There is a nice childrens playground and of course the fire breathing mantis.  Sigh, Las Vegas just does not know how to become a real city.

It's probably not a 4 but it's got a cool factor that most places don't have.  The basis for all the buildings are shipping containers with a lot of modifications. Like much of Vegas it is an attempt to draw folks n to spend money at shops.  It was 110 the day my friend took me there to show it off so there was not much going on. My guess is it picks up in cooler temps.  It has play areas for the kids during the day and adults at night.  We picked up a couple of popsicles and rushed back to beat the parking meter.

This place is awesome!!! They have a variety of shops and restaurants that are housed in shipping containers...not to mention a neat playground for kids. A totally modern concept and it's a fun place to go to kill a few hours. 

My family and I went and shopped and ate lunch there at Pinche's Mexican Restaurant. The chicken burrito was absolutely phenomenal! We also stopped and got some jerky at JoJo's jerky.....I'm not one for jerky but this stuff was amazing! 

They also close the place down to people under 21 after 9pm. We wanted to go back that night but had already made other plans. We will definitely go back to experience the nightlife. I strongly suggest that you go and experience Container Park at least once.....Fun place to be!

Lovely way to spend a few relaxing hours
 Nice local shops, restaurants,  and play space for kids. Fun venue and free.
By far one  of the coolest places in Vegas.  A nice break from the neon, glitz. Bin 702 is a definite highlight. Will recommend to everyone.

Container park is worth a visit if you've never been there before! The praying mantis fire statue outside is amusing (and often plays music of all genres including opera accompanied by fire jets). The park itself has a nice play area for kids of all ages, and plenty of shops and sining choices (although celiacs beware there isn't much here for us).

My wife and I visited this place on a recent Sunday afternoon and we're glad that we did. I'm sure we'll return the next time that we're in town. Here's what we checked out:

JoJo's Jerky

Yes, my vegetarian wife was curious enough to seek out JoJo's. We tried some of their sauces and spiced nuts and wound up buying some cactus jerky, which has a texture like fruit leather. We also bought their Caribbean jerk marinade. This place is not just for carnivores.
Thanks, Hans, for the free water!

Simply Pure

Perhaps as penance, we split a sampler plate at Simply Pure. Would you believe that the zucchini pasta, nachos, and "chicken salad" filled us up? [OK, I may have smuggled in a couple of beers!] If you've never tried raw food, you'll be surprised at how hearty some of it is. I'm sure this will make the short list for our return visit. Refer to Sandya N.'s review for more details. Apparently, head chef Stacey Dougan used to work at the Wynn. For fun, ask what Steve likes!

The Black Cup

Iced coffee hit the spot on this 100 degree day.

Art Box

We didn't buy anything here, but we enjoyed browsing. Of note were the pendants made from poker chips and others made from Scrabble tiles.

Next time, we'll have to try

Cheffini's

It's a bit obnoxious that the vegan hot dogs cost a dollar more, but they do look good.

Oak & Ivy

Can't resist a well-crafted cocktail!

The Perch

Correct me if I'm wrong, but Happy Hour seems to be M-F, 3-6. They do brunch on the weekends including build-it-yourself bloodies!

We were here on a Sunday afternoon and paid for parking at a metered space. Other reviewers mentioned free parking available in the area on Sunday, but we couldn't find any. Refer to Erin B.'s review that mentions a couple of places (hopefully nearby) where you can park for free.

But, what is a "container park", anyway? You'll just have to visit and see for yourself. Don't forget to check their calendar of events before you go.

I actually really really enjoyed it here.. More than I thought I would!

Initially I was skeptical because it's downtown, and what's so cool about stores being inside containers...? Boy was I surprised! It's a cool concept & pretty neat!

Although parking is a bit of a pain, once you're in the container park, life becomes good again.

I love that the stores are local business owners, especially the food! I enjoy supporting local businesses & helping them get started!

There's also a little play area for the kids, an elevator to go to all floors (for a unique layout like this, I didn't expect them to have an elevator), and a stage for local artists & musicians to perform. 

I'd come back here once the weather cools down.

Very cool spot with a nice vibe! They took shipping containers and made them into little stores. There's a cool toy shop in the back called Kappa Toys that is always a blast to stop in and see what they have. I also like to stop by and either eat at the BBQ restaurant called Big Ern's or the mexican spot called Pinches Tacos. 

Some other cool shops there are Jinju chocolates which have all sorts of delicious chocolate which sometimes look to nice to eat and also JoJo's jerky which might be my favorite jerky spot in Downtown.
Love the drum circle at sunset to wake the mantis. Great place for kids and adults, the playground and variety of shops and restaurants make this a place I will come back to many more times!

I was excited to see what this place was all about ever since seeing it in construction during the Life is Beautiful music festival. Wish it had been open then
Once I saw (on Instagram, of course) that the Container Park was open, the BF and I decided to have Sunday Funday/night there. 

We came around 9pm and were greeted with the fire breathing grasshopper fronting the Container Park's entrance. 

I was immediately drawn to the lights on the trees that add to the Christmas vibe...tis the season, afterall.

Then love the look of the stores and restaurants in the containers. Container Park, itself, seems to be only a fourth filled with businesses. 

In the middle, you see a park similar to Town Square's park BUT...and it's a Big BUT, there's a fairly gigantic tree house in the middle with slides on them. Slides so big that it kinda hurt my boyfriend on the slide that makes a U-turn. ***I just wonder if security is really watching the kids and controlling who goes down and when***
In fact, the tree house was so tall that I was scared to go up more stairs because it's, like, three stories tall.

Along with the park, there's a stage next to it. Perfect for outdoor concerts! Can't wait to see how the Container Park will participate in next year's Life is Beautiful Festival.

The mix of art galleries, restaurants, bars, even hair salon adds to the eclectic mix that is the Container Park! And that was just from what was open while I was there.

Downtown Project is doing a really great job rejuvenating DTLV =)

Entrepreneurial Opportunity. Innovation. Revitalization. Community. Entertainment. Culture. Fun. Family. Noms. Style.

Seriously, the concept is amazeballs. It is inspiring to be amidst the local musicians, families coming together with their children, young/old locals and tourists creating cultural delight, the delicious options of food and beverage... Definitely worth a visit; bring your friends and family. There is such a strong sense of community and growth that one cannot leave without at least a tinge of hope and inspiration for the future of Downtown Las Vegas. Live music throughout the day and night; a variety to please all ears. Slide down the big tree house slides whether you are 3 or 30... It will be great. The Downtown Rangers help greet and direct and it is helpful to those full of intrigue or at a loss. High safety due to the security patrol which is not abrasive, but does make one feel comfortable.

Really cool park within walking distance of the Fremont Street Experience. I didn't have the chance to browse through the shops but I would love to in the future. There is a giant tree house playground for the kids and plenty of shopping, eateries and drinking for adults. A huge grasshopper sculpture greets you when you enter which is really cool and the way they reused containers made the place extra unique. Very cool place in Vegas which isn't your typical Vegas attraction.

We loved the container park for a day trip with the little one. There is so much to love about this place, here is what stood out for us:

- Recycled shipping containers made into a classy outdoor shopping center and play ground. What's not to love about recycling? 
- The playground had water-misters to keep you cooled down. Both myself and my toddler loved the misting! 
- The playground is very secure- both with security guards and it is fenced in. This is a wonderful feature for the safety of my little ones who love to run off. The added security of the nice guard was also nice for a downtown park, and she made sure that my toddler didn't escape out the gate when he tried to, while my pregnant self was running after him. 
- Lots of creative play, not just structures- legos, foam blocks, chalk board, etc
- This may sound silly, but I loved that there are compost bins built into the trash/recycling bins. And they tell you what goes into what if you don't already know. 

I would love to check out the adults-only events after 9pm when the park is 21+. But that will have to wait until baby-in-the-belly arrives and I can have a night out with the hubby. 

Only downside- parking. There should be better and free parking for the container park. All in all, we will return!

Its not bad, fun the first time you do it.... some decent places to eat in there, more the BBQ place, all other shops are a bit tired out, the staff is a bit rude...but it is what it is. The whole place is missing a bit of something... it was really cool last year but has gone downhill since.
My boyfriend and I had a great time the show movies during the weekday and kick all the kids out at night it's a great place for a first date

Omg this place is awesome! I wish parks were this cool when I was a kid. Container park has a nice place for kids to play and is surrounded by local shops and boutiques (While it may seem like you can shop while your kids play, I still do not recommend leaving your kids unattended). They have fun face painters and the coolest balloon animal guy I've ever seen! He made motorcycle balloons, octopus backpacks, crowns, bows and arrows, unicorns you could ride, and cute flowers. I confess, I sat there for two hours watching him make cool balloon stuff, and even almost stood at the long line just to get one. 

They had fun gigantic Styrofoam legos to make cool forts and houses with (every kid's dream!), really high swirly slides for any kid to go bonkers with, and this really fun interactive light up game. This game you can play multiple games of your choosing from their selection in which you press the buttons as they light. 

For the "BIGGER KIDS" there's fun shops with artwork, furniture stores, clothing and accessory stores to browse. Wanting to get a little tipsy? Fear not, they've got bars where you can grab a beer or two, or maybe sip a little wine. Kids getting hungry? Fear not! They have awesome bbq joints and sandwich shops. Wanting something sweat? FEAR NOT! They have a candy shop, cupcake shop, ice cream shop...Need a hair cut? FEAR NOT! There's a barber shop! Wanting entertainment? NO WORRIES! They have live bands perform from time to time. The design is beautiful and fun both you and the kids would love...

Downside, the shops do get pretty pricey in things, as well as the places to eat so if you're looking to spend on a budget, food and drinks would probably be your first choice, and then if you find something you REALLY REALLY want you might walk out with something cool and handcrafted. Try the chocolate covered bacon. Those are pretty good.

This is a great place to go that is kid friendly. There are a bunch of activities including shopping, eating, social, free wifi, and a kids playground. This is really turning the downtown area around!

SO COOL! From the moment we walked in security was abundant and eagerly greeting guests. With multi-level container shops around the perimeter, Children's play area in the middle, and a stage at the end with live entertainment there is fun for everyone. Containers are made up of various retail shops and a vast variety of eats. I wish I would have known, I wouldn't have eaten before arriving because there were some serious good smells here. Prices in the retail shops and on the menus seemed very reasonable. So come hungry and enjoy, what this place has to offer!

I'm going to give this place an "A" for creativity.  Old Vegas is looking for another reason for the people to come on down.  Granted I went here during the day and it was super hot out.  I'd like to check it out at night sometime.  Looks like it's way more funner.  All the shops appear to be quality shops, it's worth walking up from Fremont St.  

My friend is really into the beef jerky shop.  I'd like to try the taquria one day.  If I had kids, they have a nice play structure with misters all around it.  So bring your kids with you.

To all my Yelp friends out there, please give this place a try.  They pumped in a lot of money to give old Vegas a new spice of life.

The stores are just so-so, but the fire breathing praying mantis is cool!  You can hear the flames as well as see them!  This place has also helped to revitalize Fremont Street, which has definitely gotten younger and trendier.  The area east of this location is still sketch, though, so I wouldn't venture any further than here.

This is going to be a great community concept downtown.  I was wowed when I walked in and saw the design.  It is so family friendly with the grass, tree house, and building blocks for kids to manipulate.  The kitschy factor of the shipping containers makes it very hip, the stores are eclectic and fun, and the food establishments have some interesting and tasty ideas going on.  

But there are some things that nag at me that prevent me from giving it 5 stars.  Like the fact that those blue building blocks are going to (a) be stolen pretty quickly or (b) have germs and kid snot all over them in no time.  Or the fact that there aren't very many bathrooms and they're made out of (duh) shipping containers, so it smelled like a Port-A-Potty only 3 days into the park being open.  It was also freezing outside, but the bathroom was hot and steamy.  Can you imagine what that will be like in the summer when it's hot outside?  Icky icky eww.  Or maybe it's that the food and beverage places do not have many great options...great ideas and food concepts, but not executed well.  The Boozery is not much of a boozery at all with only about 4 specialty drinks and not much great alcohol to choose from.

I want this place to be amazing.  I have a lot of hope for this place being kind of like a watershed event in the history of DTLV.  But there are things that nag at me that make me have a small grain of doubt.

Took a leisurely stroll around CP this morning and I am excited about the potential this has for DTLV. Great spots to eat, be entertained and socialize for kids and adults. Love the local entrepreneurial spirit that is enforced with only independently run vendors and businesses here.

I really like the container park but I had a not so wonderful experience this past weekend. I took my 2 1/2 yr old son and met up with some friends. 

There was a band playing on the stage and quite a few people on the grass. Well my son being the fun kid that he is, decided he would skip around and dance to the band that was playing. I got told by the security guard that he couldn't do that and he of course didn't stop when I tried to settle him down. So security told me, "he had to go". Nothing like telling a toddler he can't be a kid. So he of course cried when we had to leave the grassy area. I'm not sure why they provide a band, grassy area and a toddler isn't allowed to play around. We will take a break from visiting there so he can be a kid at a public park instead.

Very hip and cute little stores inside containers. I didn't get a chance to look at all of the stores but I could see that this place would be good for families and possibly a date. Parking is kind of a pain though since it's mostly metered but if you can find a spot it's actually not too bad. 

Lots of photo opportunities and FREE samples at certain stores. Although this spot is not somewhere you would go if you're in Vegas for the weekend. I don't think it's worth making a way out here but if you have the time do stop by and check it out.

The container park is a great family friendly addition to Downtown Las Vegas.  Make sure to catch the massive praying mantis at the entrance that blows fire out of it's mouth to the beat of songs a few times an hour.  You can sip a margarita, buy a gift for a friend, and have brunch all in one place.  I think it would be even better with a brewery like the container park in ABQ, but there are still many options here.  The Deuce bus drops off just down the street, so it's easy to get to from the strip.
Container Park was a blast for my son and at night turned into almos turned into a adult like playground. Good for mellow casual fun!

While waiting for Park on Fremont to open, I decided to stop by the Downtown Container Park which was nearby to check it out because it looked like a cool place to hangout for a little bit.  Going inside, the park is a lot smaller than I thought, but I was pretty amazed how they made this place out of shipping containers.

Unfortunately, I was there a little too early since all the shops and restaurants were still closed and I didn't get to see the flames shooting out from the antennae of the giant mantis sculpture which I think is pretty awesome!

I wouldn't mind coming back here again though to check out the food spots and especially to see the place shine at night.  It's a pretty awesome concept and it's great to see something like this built to have more visitors on the east side of Fremont Street.

I love the container park! This area of downtown was very run down before the container park went in. I think it is fantastic. When friends come to visit I have somewhere to take them.
I have only been at night after 9, when it is adults only.
The fire shooting mantis is the best! I love it!
The vib is super funky and hip, and it reminds me of the S.F Bay Area. So yes I am a fan..

Needs some time to mature. Quite a few of the stores were empty, Some of the businesses didn't seem very well stocked or staffed. The restrooms were nice though, clean anyway. If I happen to be in the area again, maybe I'll stop by and see how it's going but otherwise nothing here to make me want to drive across town to visit.

What a cool place!!  Shipping containers stacked into 3 stories of little shops, with a center play area for kids.  

Well, ok - that center play area has a big treehouse, so I officially rejected any kid age parameters (there are none here btw) & climbed on up myself.  There are mutiple tube slides that you can slide down, and the highest one even has a red light/green light system so that you know you're not going to brain anyone if you go next.  Fun!  

There's a stage where they have live music or movies showing, & a grassy area around it with lawn furniture.

The shops have local artists' stuff, plus food, cupcakes, jerky, clothing & accessories, and toys.  My fave shop was called Blue Marble - they upcycle discarded bottles of alcohol from the Strip into the COOLEST things.  We also got a yummy soft red velvet sammich cookie, with cream cheese icing in between, & half dipped in white chocolate at the little cupcake shop on the first floor.  

After 9pm, kids are not allowed in the area, so it turns into an adult playground.  There are a few bars in the park, & people were walking around with wine.  There's seating on all the outside patios.

Oh!  And there's a huge metal sculpture of a praying mantis at the entrance.  A guy mans it & shoots fireballs out of the antennae when it gets dark.  You'll hear it, & if you stand close, you'll feel the heat.

Also at the entrance is a big metal heart sculpture where people have padlocked messages on metal tags.  Sweet : ).

Just across the street (towards the spectacle that is Fremont Street) is a great little Whole Foods-y market that has baked goods, produce, a hot food area, etc.  A couple blocks past is Fremont Street.

Whether you're a big kid or a little kid, or a mixed group, this is a definite must visit when you're in Vegas!
Here for earth day so the kids got to plant some seeds and have fun at the park. They also are having movie night too. Fun fun fun

If there were zero stars, I would put that down. Selectively dog-friendly. My husband and I went one Saturday morning in January, and the place was crawling with dogs. We came back in May with our 5-pound chi-weenie who has a broken leg and has to be carried, and we were turned away by a very rude woman at the front. There are ways to state that a place is not dog-friendly that are still polite. She clearly chose to be rude about the matter. Lack of professionalism for sure.

Awesome idea! The fact that they made this really cool Las Vegas attraction out of shipping containers is just simply amazing. They found an effective way to recycle these containers rather than letting them rust like so many I see at the shipyards. Very artistic and modern. Will come back soon.

I had heard about container parks, apartments, etc popping up all over Europe so when i saw the sign at the entrance I had to take a look.  I read some of the comments about it being small, and yes, most of the stores and restaurants are small, but I feel that if it were any bigger it would lose the appeal of it being a Container park.  We went on a Saturday morning so parking was free.  If you go on a Friday night, you'll have to pay for parking.  We went to Freemont the night before and paid $5 at the El Cortez parking structure so still not too bad since there is so much to do in that area anyway.  

This place is great for kids.  They have jumbo sized legos, and some other foam toys they can use in a large play area.  They also have a large slide like the ones you'd find at the water parks.  Looks like it's a pretty popular since there was a long line of kids.  I even wanted to try it :)

It may not be for everyone, but it's definitely worth checking out at least once.  You'd be amazed at how someone took these shipping containers and put them together to assemble a pretty awesome park.  Plus there some pretty cool artwork all over the park you can check out.

Not many people venture to Downtown Las Vegas and if they do they don't make the extended trip to East Fremont street. Container Park is one of those places that is unexpected and just a little further passed all the touristy nonsense. This park is about a block and a half long and all of the businesses in inside the park are made out of actual shipping containers! The containers are all brightly painted and beautifully restored; there's bars, restaurants, nail salons, a stage for performers, and a playground for the kiddies. It's a very original concept, nicely executed, I always enjoy walking around and bringing people with me who've never been.

Great little oasis to enjoy some fresh air and check out some fun local shops! Only a few minutes walk from the Downtown casinos. It's away from the hustle and bustle and smoke of the casinos. There is a designated area for smoking. 
It's the perfect place to grab lunch or fresh ice cream made with dry ice and enjoy the sun. With all the local shops, it's a great place to pick up some unique souvenirs or gifts!

Come here to see the Praying Mantis (it breathes fire at night) and check out "The Heart Locket"!

Location: on the corner of 7th Avenue and Fremont Street in Downtown Las Vegas.  I walked from the California Hotel, through Binion's Casino, under the Fremont Street Experience, and down 2 blocks.  It took about 10 minutes. I'm glad that I walked in the morning to avoid the heat. There was shade from awnings along the way after the Fremont Street Experience. 

Parking: metered street parking and a paid parking lot across the street. I parked for free at the California Hotel since I was a guest. 

Features: about 25 shops and 9 restaurants; the Praying Mantis sculpture; "The Heart Locker" by Nova May; and lots of play area for children! There's a Tree House, Jungle Gym, maybe a climbing tower, a 33 foot slide, and open space!  On the weekends, there's live music at the stage area!

I want to go back when I have more time and get a photo of the fire breathing Praying Mantis!  The shops and restaurants looked good, too!  The best thing is that there is no admission fee!

Note: the gates don't open until 11am, so don't go too early. ..hahaha!

Cute shops, lots of seating and nearby parking. Have only gone during the day (three times now) so I can't speak to the night life. The mantis is cool. The toy store is awesome! Really unique space and fun to just hang out in. Shame to see it getting such negative reviews...
Be sure to stop in at Art Box while here. No Yelp presence, but well worth the stop inside

It's alright.   I was expecting it to be bigger.  A few restaurants, a bar and speciality shops.  The playground is very well done. The best thing is people watching.  Interesting people roam around here.   Definitely a great place for people watching.

Fun bars and a great atmosphere for getting out of the house and walking around on hot Vegas nights. Watch out for the occasional pool o' puke from wine drinkers who have found their limit. Staff definitely does a good job of keeping it clean and family friendly.

I love the concept of Container Park, but the execution not so much.  They do succeed at bringing diverse groups of people together in a common area.  Comes complete with screaming kids everywhere though.  My biggest gripe is that important details were overlooked in the planning phase. 

The live music stage is a very nice touch.  All of the dining options require customers to order from a window instead of table service.  All of the dining places had long lines for food.  Bars had long wait times and seating is minimal.

For people with young children, this is an ideal spot to take family.  The kiddos can play on the giant playground in the middle or run and whack each other with foam blocks on the stageside lawn.
Lots to do- for adults, kids, and the kids at heart. Fun stores and good food, too. Very creative design. Love the niche, enviro-friendly feel to it. Planning to come back
Very cool place. Nice shops and places to eat. They have live music on selected days. Good place for locals away from the casino and strip

If I could give this place negative stars I would! We came here to have a picnic lunch after my nephew's baptism. My brother in law came down 2-3 weeks ago and spoke to security regarding having the picnic. He was told as long as there wasn't any alcohol we would be ok. As we're setting up the good a security guard (named Aviomme) came over and informed us we had to leave as we couldn't have our picnic because 'it was against the rules'. The guy was very smug and rude to us. After explaining the situation, it took us 20 min to get him to call the manager about the situation. The manager then told us even different information than the original security guard, and Aviomme. This is an awesome example of the downtown project NOT having its act together! There aren't any vendors open yet in the park (11am opens) so there is no competition in any way for our 'business'. We only wanted to have a light lunch and let the kids play in the park. I can honestly say I will be avoiding this place from now on and will never recommend to anyone again!!! We live downtown and have always enjoyed the new things opening but this was just ridiculous! There are much better places in town, with nicer and more informed staff and genuine rules and guidelines posted...

I'm not quite sure when they finally got Container Park up and running, but as I've spent only a handful of days in Las Vegas in the last year, I hadn't had a chance to actually check it out until tonight.  Granted, I saw it at 10:30pm when it closes at 11pm.  Most of the shops were closed, but there were a few eatieries and a bar open.  And I got to watch a decent little jazz band play to the 20 people that were still in the park.  I'd love to see this place during peak tourist time as it looks like a good place to chill and people watch.  Perhaps I'll make it back out here when I have a day off next week.  I'm sure I'll be back during Life Is Beautiful!

David Hannum is shown to be correct yet again.

There are indeed containers; but, it is certainly not a park.

Downtown Container Park is as much as a "Park" as Downtown Summerlin is "Downtown[;]" as much as Phineas Taylor Barnum actually believed that his Cardiff Giant was an actual petrified man; or, as much as Tony "Montgomery Burns" Hsieh actually cares about anything besides dolla dolla bills yaaaa'll. 

This cesspool is more akin to an unnecessary "Mardi Gras of consumerism" than any park. In the old days, malls had the cojones to call themselves malls; and, at least, they respected the community enough to keep the cultish nonsense down to a bare minimum. 

One must at least respect that at the time Boulevard, Meadow, and Fashion Show malls went up, developers were not so Orwellian to bastardise the naming of malls by leaving the term mall out of their titles.

This place is rather on downslope of the mediocre side, and naming it a "Park" won't change it. So, cease the backpatting party, put the llama on a cross gold pendant down, and get real. Downtown Container Mall barely avoids the one-star. 

Detailed reviews of individual listings from Container Mall: 
Big Ern's BBQ: TBD
Cheffini's: TBD
Pinches Tacos: TBD
Sasasweets Chillspot: http://www.yelp.com/biz/chillspot-by-sasasweets-las-vegas?hrid=Opgl9SwwGcOHGHrC2Ig45g&utm_campaign=www_review_share_popup&utm_medium=copy_link&utm_source=(direct)
Simply Pure: TBD
The Perch: TBD

This is one of the coolest places in downtown Las Vegas! Why? Because they took an empty piece of land and boring old shopping containers and created a modern hub for shopping and family fun! And this place is fun! 

What's there to do? Just kick back with a cup of coffee and watch all the kids play on the playground, or with the park provided stacking blocks. Grab a bite to eat from one of the many good restaurants. Stroll up and down the different levels of shopping at the cool stores. Catch a movie in the movie dome. This place is the epitome of revitalization! 

I enjoyed strolling through the containers, poking my head out of the 'C' cut out overlooking the entrance, looking at some aluminum photography hanging in a container tunnel, watching the kids play play play, and taking it all in. 

Be sure to read all the happy lovebirds who put their locks on the Love locket sculpture outside the park entrance. Bring a lock!

Outside is a triple A sponsored autonomous vehicle that gives you a ride around downtown! There's parking galore in the street or in the lot. It's located near all the good Downtown eats.

Cool place in Downtown Las Vegas with lots of cool little shops and places to eat. What I liked most was the kids play area It's was in the high 90s the day we stopped by here to have lunch at one of the shops. The play ground was so cool it had this treehouse thing with slides coming out of it with lots of shade and misting thing so the kids won't get to hot while playing. It's a cool place to check if you if your in the area.
Cool site to see cool concept.  Fun businesses ...go to go...stop at Oak and Ivy or The Perch say Annemarie sent you!!!!

Great place for tourist or locals, families or a night out with friends. Located in downtown but felt modern & hip, also clean and very secure (didn't run into a single pan handler) Cool art work, cute shops, good unique food & drink venues. I recommend pinches tacos authentic Mexican food, taquitos were delish and everyone around us had the taco plates which looked good too. Awesome  playground with tree house and mega slides (3 story high). At the entrance is a fire spitting pray mantis at the very back is a stage and open lawn for live entertainment, they even include big foam blocks to keep kids busy and cozy couches and heaters to keep adults comfy. Just go check it out for yourself. If you want close parking it's $1 per hr metered, or u can park in the free parking near main st/California hotel and walk a couple blocks.

The container park was pretty cool. I didn't know what to expect as thought it would be larger and have a wide variety of stores. It's mostly restaurants and a few shops that sold anything from clothing and jewelry to beef jerky and toys.

I was impressed by the culinary options- there was a little something for everyone.

There is a play zone for children and a lounging area in front of a stage where I assume bands perform. 

The structure is interesting and a great example of resourcing rail cars. Ambience is casual and kinda hipster- it's just a great space to eat, drink, relax and chill w friends or family.

I just made a cursory stop to get some photos on my jaunt downtown earlier this week so I can't give the Container Park a full review.  I really like what they've done with this space.  It's hard to believe that only a block away was the site of the Western Casino, the much maligned spot on Fremont Street.

Until December 8th, the Project Y.E.S. spaceship will be in the Learning Center area for kids to explore.  Check the Downtown Project's website for ticket information (there is no charge for the tickets).

I'll be back in another day--at night--and I hope to see more as I have the time to walk around inside the Container Park and enjoy the vibes of this place.

While the T-Rex sculpture was pretty cool, the place was closed when we got there, at like 2200hrs on a Saturday night.  This is Vegas what closes that early on a Saturday night?  I thought the whole town was just perpetually open?
Uts a good place to bring kids! At least i found a place here in vegas where i can sit, relax and eat and at the same time i dont have to worry if my kids are enjoying themselves.

I knew going to the Container Park was either going to be a hit or miss and Unfortunately for me it was a miss. The only thing that made the visit worth it was having brunch at The Perch. The taco place also seemed popular. There is a cute kid section in the middle and a couple of mettle sculptures that make for a fun tourist photo op. However I was disappointed in the shopping options. There were a couple of quality options and the rest were a bust. Outside of brunch and a bathroom stop I wasn't there for more than 30 min max.

Unique play area for kids. Problem is the night time people mix in some during the day. Security is roaming though. They are surrounded by places to purchase alcohol which brings them in as well. Visit but do so with caution and keep eyes open.

Container park is a MUST SEE! During adults hours only because it's fun and nice having the band playing. At Bin 702, the flaming hot Cheeto and the Brie was DELICIOUS ! Also, the nice fu*ck%n model was soooo yum! So try that! Warning ***  the tree house sounds real fun until you go down it and the turns are built for little kids and it jacks you up! So be careful on the tree house slides haha! Otherwise it was great and I recommend this area! Don't leave Fremont without seeing it!

This is a fun and great place to bring kids, but there isn't a lot to see or do here. Luckily it's in a good location at the end of the Fremont Street Experience so you can just take a stroll and take a few photos with the praying mantis.

It's a cool concept, but the shops are restaurants are limited.

Cool little gem in the craziness of Vegas. It's a mixture of stores and restaurants and a playground. After 9pm everyday, it's adults only (21+) I can just imagine the shenanigans that happen here after 9. There is one restaurant upstairs that is open on Sunday's for brunch.
 I think this place is cute and definitely unique. It certainly has a little something for everyone. Worth a stop!

This place is AWESOME!!!!  I didn't know this was here and am so happy we found it.   We only found it because of the praying mantis shooting flames!  That was cool! !  Scared the crap out of me a few times. 
The park is so cool because it had a lot of play stead for kids.   From a park to a lego building area.   And the parents can sit back,  have a drink and watch the kids.  What is better than that? ???

Lots of cool stores,  bars,  and food in the container too. 

A must see for anyone visiting old town Vegas

Zappos is trying to take over!! Ack!!  They are the Godzilla of old Downtown Las Vegas.  Best hide your llamas!

We got around to taking a drive here to the current talk of the town, Downtown Container Park.  I do like the concept - what to do with old barge shipping crates?  I know, deck them out, put em together like a building, and charge a markup on services for unsuspecting tourists!  Brilliant.  Tony Hseih and company have got it down to a 'T'.

As an idea, the park is awesome.  I do like the rugged architecture, turning large containers into habitable shops and restaurants with a central park environment that can be used for playing, gatherings, concerts, lounging...what have you.  But the execution...whew...hit and miss.

Lots of things about Downtown Container Park drive me NUTS.  Let me count the ways:

1) PARKING - Damn.  If you don't like parking on the curb pointing to the middle of the street, you're screwed.  Don't take your expensive Lambo or vintage Camaro here unless you can park right next to the park.  I have no issues with the 'ghetto' part of town but beware.  Park your ride too far from the park and in the middle of near-darkness, you could be asking for a break-in.  Please don't leave valuables that are too tempting on your seat.  This is just par for the course and in no way do I endorse we get rid of all unsavory neighborhoods.  Respect people, always.  R-E-S-P-E-C-T.

2) CROWDS - Holy $hi+...wouldn't you know, Downtown Container Park is busy!  Friggin' busy!  Most of the daytime there is just WAY too much noise going on, people yapping, kids screaming, parents screaming, speakers blaring, singers singing, yada yada yada.  It's just too much!  Can this park be any more cramped?  I guess this is very par for the course as well since it is relatively brand new.  It's just cray-cray-crazy.  

3) SHOPS - Like hardly any.  There's not much to do in Downtown Container Park as of yet unless you love free random concerts (see #2 above).  Not too much in terms of retail or anything else for that matter.  Froo-froo shopping I don't do.  There are quite a bit of empty shop spaces.  Hello, arcade anyone?  A comic book store maybe?  Hell, I would settle for an Apple store at this point just so I could play with some gadgets, and I don't even have an iPhone (I show the Androids much love).

4) RESTAURANTS - It's probably just me just being impatient, but can we please have more eating choices?  What is this, only things Zappos employees eat?  A BBQ place, a semi-BBQ place, a jerky place, and a taco place.  Some candy and treats too.  But not even a pizza place within the park!  Or a hot dog!  I know it's no mall but a streamlined food court in the works eventually would be nice.

5) PRICES - Crapola, did the recession hit everyone except rich folk (actually, I think it did)?  Expensive!  Everything!  Food!  Drink!  Even a damn popsicle bar runs $6!  $3 for a bottle of water!  WTH?  This 'gourmet' trend can kiss my @$$, I swear!  Robbery I tell you!  But again, I am biased because:
      a.  I am poor
      b.  I am cheap
      c.  I am poor & cheap

But at least the park looks nice.  I like the playground area for kids (surrounded by Zappos security) where only animal allowed are llamas, grass is always nice, and I enjoy the hipster, eco-friendly vibe the place gives off.  I mean, the food trays used are mostly recyclable.  It is family friendly and very green.  But outside the walls, boy, you better be ready for reality to set in.  Downtown Las Vegas at night is no joke and is NOT for children.  That's probably why the park closes at 9 PM for anyone under 21.  Take heed!

Visited the park twice so far.  First time we met up with our friends and drove down from Henderson.  Parked in a pay garage, walked over with a group of excited kids, and then we were told that since it was slightly raining and overcast they didn't think anyone would want to visit so they were closing for a "maintenance" day.  Awesome waste of my time and gas and way to disappoint the kids.  Oh yeah, and we got to pay for parking.  No mention on the website, or social media about closing.

Fast forward a couple weeks and we decide to try one more time.  Meet friends, bring kids, etc, only to find out about height restrictions for half of the stuff.  My 6 year old girl is in tears because she can't go play with all the other kids.

Moral of the story: If you're going to arbitrarily close, post it somewhere so I don't waste my time to be turned away once we're there.  Also, if you have restrictions on your stuff, please post that as well so we know ahead of time.

After reading some reviews, I thought I was visiting some recycled metal park. Boy, I was wrong. In fact, I wasn't even too fond of visiting because of the downtown area. Sometimes, it's good to expect nothing. 

First, you have to park on the street meter. It was only $1 for every hour. I spent $2 for 2 hours. That's reasonable.

At the entrance, I was expecting to pay an admission fee which was none. That's a plus. As I entered, there's a huge playground in the middle with the tree house. My 12 year old loved the tree house. Aside from the playground, they had many different types of specialty stores from toys, socks, beef jerkey, candy shop, jewelry etc. They have 3 levels of different stores. I went into a lemonade store and got an instant fresh lemonade. It was made as I was waiting using some fancy machine. That's was the freshest lemonade I've tasted ever. The candy store there sells candies from the past. That was the coolest thing.

This place is very green. They have 3 different bins for recycling. They have clean bathrooms near the entrance. They have warm air in there so you don't freeze your butt during cold winter.

If you have children like me and you're in Las Vegas, it's worth visiting Downtown Container Park away from smoky and busy casinos. It's fun to just browse these specialty stores that are unique.

Cool little place two minutes from Fremont. The gigantic metallic grasshopper shooting flames is the highlight of the whole place. It shoots fire and dances to the music that plays. Super cool. 

As for the actual consistent park. It is kid friendly and houses cute little shops and restaurants.

Great addition to downtown Las Vegas! The area feels very safe and clean. The shops and restaurants all have a hip, inviting vibe. And, of course, the best part is the play structure- there are fun elements for the very little ones but still enough challenges to keep even Tweens engaged. Which means happy parents can watch them while eating barbecue and enjoying a drink from the Boozery. What's not to love?

I was super excited to visit the container park on my recent trip to Vegas. I looked at the website beforehand and was stoked to check out the cute boutiques and eateries it had to offer. So, on our last day in Vegas, my fiance and I decided to check it out. I think I was expecting a much bigger place with better stores. It's a really small place with not too many stores...a lot of the stores I wanted to check out have closed, and there's a lot of vacant space. Perhaps the website should be updated so that people aren't disappointed when they come looking for a certain store. I ended up buying some Tokidoki items from the toy store and some chocolates from Jinju chocolate. Other than that, this place was a bust. I don't see it surviving very long, given the strange location and odd mix of stores. A good concept, but it just doesn't work.

This is my 3rd time here. It has definitely gotten busier since my first time. This place is the talk of the town. They are known to be an earth friendly park. They have a lot of art shops, sweet stores, and some other knick knack shops. I would say 85% of the shops are art stuff. Not a lot of shops I would go to. I do like the clubhouse right in the middle for the kids. This clubhouse can get so packed that there's a line to get in. When going upstairs, the stairs are super steep, so be careful. Another thing I liked, is that there's a stage in the back for a live band to play on, in front is grass that has big Legos and foam stuff for kids to play with and build stuff. There's some lounge chairs, well, to lounge on while you hang with your little ones and enjoy the sounds from the live band. I say, it's a pretty chill spot to hang out with both kids and adults. There are some bars where you can pick up some liquor while your lounging. 
There are 3 things that my husband and I were discussing about what would make this place unpopular. 
#1 - Today, the weather was nice at 72 degrees. In Nevada, it's perfect when you're in shaded area and extremely hot under the sun. I noticed, there wasn't a lot of shaded areas. They'll need to somehow put a cooling system in there. 
#2 - the grass area, where the kids play, I noticed a lot of the dirt and dead grass were flying everywhere. Not a good place to eat my halo halo at. And those who have allergies.... And in Vegas too... Not good for those with allergies. My daughter was complaining about that the whole time. 
#3 - well, it's in downtown. Not the safest place to take your kids and especially when it starts to get dark. 

All in all, I do love the vibe I get when I come here. I can relax listen to feel good music while my little one plays in front of me.

This is such a fun place whether one is an adult or a child. This place will transport one back in time to when you were a child. Whether by playing on the huge slide made out of a large and massive tree, and indeed the adult in one even without children can play on. They will not even look at you funny if you take and channel your inner child.

Today, besides partaking in the wonderful food here at Container Park, and some wine even did a hula hoop try, but was unsecessful in making stay around my waste. So Vegas locals and tourists come out and mingle bring the little ones and forget your cares for an afternoon. Life will be there when you leave. There is also the heart lock outside and attached our lock had from house to always remember the love for a great dad, husband, lover, and friend... now a little piece of him is part of the city he was proud to call home and love so much.

I have been subtly avoiding this place for the past year because of how hyped up and packed it was bound to be. But needless to say the other night I ventured out and gave it a shot!

I'm so glad I did!

What a perfect idea. This is exactly what Downtown Las Vegas needed honestly. Downtown was lacking for a bit there and becoming sadly outdated but with this place opening and a couple other key places popping up after Downtown is totally the new Strip.

I much prefer Downtown to the Strip anyways, but places like Container Park make it 10x better.

If you come at night you can see the Praying Mantis that guards the entry spit fire in sync with songs and if you go inside climb to the top level of the containers and see it from a birds eye view!

Packed with cute local restaurants and shops filled with fun goodies. Complete with a playground for children (and adults) of all ages and its very own wedding chapel! We were lucky enough to catch a happy couple in the middle of their vows and it was perfect!

We will definitely be making Container Park a regular night out destination!

I love the idea of tiny hip shops all in one "mall" type setting.
I love the location, gentrifying further reaches of downtown.
I love the mantis that breathes fire in time with "Bohemian Rhapsody."
I love the central playground with a seriously huge climbing structure and a bunch of cool toys for kids, big and little (hello giant tinkertoys).
I love (some of) the dining options: pinche tacos, sasapops, oak & ivy, jinju chocolates...cool spots, local (most of them), with unique offerings.
Unfortunately, the container park kinda falls short on the actual shopping. The stores are tiny, of course, and highly specialized (a sock store! flip flops! plastic watch shop!) There are a couple of boutique-y clothes and art shops that are worth visiting and potentially purchasing from, but there's a lot of weirdness around it that will probably change out in a few short months when they can't afford the rent.
Still a cute place to spend some time with the kids or to take out of town visitors once. Just not really a shopping destination.

Two stars mostly for the terrible parking situation.  Sorry, but I don't want to pay $1 for half an hour of parking !  The City of Las Vegas really screwed up allowing this place to be built.  It seems to be just a method to increase cash flow to the city by collecting parking fees and writing tickets.  

Inside.  A few small shops.  There is not much for sale there.  Two candy shops.  Some restaurants.  A kettle corn shop.  A jerky & spice shop.  Some knick-knack shops.  A bar or two.  A bathing suit place.  Flip-Flop store.  Small clothing shops.

It's not laid out well.  There's an elevator on one side, but there's no bridge to connect the upstairs on both sides so you'd need to go downstairs to go to the other side.  The little play area in the middle is nice.  The place has potential if they can add to it and get some real stores in the neighborhood and then add some free parking.  I don't see this place lasting long unless they solve the parking situation.

Looks really cool but once you get passed the giant bug there's not much. Just annoying boring music on the weekends. Cool stores but most were empty.  For downtown I thought it would be a little more hip.  4 stars because it's clean inside

This place is a blast! It's a great spot to bring kids, the playground treehouse is our girls favorite. Food is pretty good, haven't had a chance to enjoy the bar experience as I've had my kids in tow every time.

Welcome everyone to Las Vegas HIPSTER PARADISE!

Been spending most their lives, living in the hipster's paradise
Been spending most their lives, living in the hipster's paradise
Keep spending most our lives, living in the hipster's paradise
Keep spending most our lives, living in the hipster's paradise

I really love how the built this near fremont. It gives the Fremont another thing to do at night. I really like the vibe here, a bunch of boutique stores, a jungle gym, free live music concert on the lawn and a friendly atmosphere!

A few of the notables are the trampoline, giant lego blocks, black wall and chalk, and giant praying mantis! We checked out the disney store, the ice cream bar and the beef jerky store. We loved it all.

Definitely, a cool place to hang out when you're bored of the strip!

Really neat place! I'm all about reusing things so the Container Park is perfect. Lots of little shops and eateries - enough to satisfy lots of different tastes. Nice place to sit and hangout when the weather is nice. A good play area for the little ones too!

The Downtown Container Park alone should make more people want to visit Downtown Las Vegas! Plenty of cool little shops at Container Park as well as various restaurants and bars. They also have a little coffee shop, a stage, playground for kids, and so much more. They even have wifi and I've even gone here to get some work done in some shade on a hot day. It's a great place to visit and one of the gems of Downtown Las Vegas. I love it!

One of the coolest local hangouts I've been to in Vegas and it's just blocks away from the Fremont Experience.

Literally, this place is constructed and architect with container trailers. Within the park it consists of shops, restaurants, a toy store, a planetarium, and even a wedding chapel. When I read its family friendly I was looking forward in visiting here, since there aren't many places for kids in Sin City. 

There's a grass area there in front of the stage where live music is performed where kids can play. My son was building a fort with other kids using foamed Legos. While us parents are looking on, relaxing on love sofas. There's even a playground right down the middle of the courtyard and I believe there's a playhouse with slides attached to it that towers that spot, which looks fun, but a little overwhelming for smaller kids. 

In addition, Container Park is trendy, its comparable to what I'm starting to see here in Southern Cali of outdoor hangouts. This place has restaurants and they serve some alcohol, so it's not entirely kiddy. I went into Pinches Tacos here for a frozen margarita, but their credit/debit machine was down. I settled for an Angry Orchard at Big Ern's BBQ to chill outside with live music playing, so it was a relaxing experience. 

The Praying Mantis at the entrance way catches everyone's attention and it gets pretty intense when it periodically shoots out flames from its antennas. 

I highly recommend this spot if you're looking to do away the hustle and bustle of touristy destinations.

Amazing downtown attraction!

Great concept, has shopping, activities for the kids and food and wine for the parents.

I'd recommend this place for just about any type of outing.

Families, dates or even just a sneaky bite and drink to eat
Pretty neat spot downtown. All the businesses are made from shipping containers. Large play park in the middle

Great idea for a weekend day out with the family. Good music, great food and overall the concept seems really cool. I have to admit the containers can get a bit cramped however keep in mind they are shipping containers.

WOW! Okay, so I thought this would be like a trailer park. I was wrong! This place was awesome! Super hip and very pretty. Unlike Fremont (which was a little sad). I absolutely loved this place! Wish it was bigger.

Container Park is a clever idea. Recycling old shipping containers into a mall complete with a park, tree house, restaurants, shops, a stage, art exhibits and an immersive musical/visual experience. They have a lot packed into Downtown Container Park. It is a cool place to walk around, browse, gnosh and gather. I have been a few times mostly just to walk around. I've checked out a couple of the shops and have even eaten once or twice. Today I could smell the BBQ place and want to go back to try it some time. It smelled unreal and was making my mouth water despite having already eaten lunch and a half. Keep that up and people will come back to Container Park time after time. There really isn't much for me here but I appreciate it all the same. I like the idea and fully support such a facility.

Thank God LV has somewhere cool to hang out. I am not a native of LV and while I know the casino industry is vital to LV, I just don't love the casino lifestyle and crowd it draws. 

I like Container Park simply because it's a creative, entertaining scene that is different from "LV" and feels like possibly you're in another city for a minute. Developed by Zappos, it's made from many huge shipping containers that are pieced together to make shops and restaurants, it's a great way to reuse something other wise very basic or utilitarian in a attractive, artistic way. There's a gigantic treehouse in the middle of the courtyard area, a stage for concerts, performances and movies (with a grass area). Lots of tables and chairs to sit at and enjoy the food from various restaurants and bars  or people watch. At the end is an old train caboose that is a barber shop. 

Adding to the artistic nuances throughout the park is the large Preying Mantis metal sculpture out front that spits fire and blasts music every 15 minutes, very Mad Max Beyond Thunderdome meets Burning Man. 

If you're looking to go somewhere not "Vegas" then I suggest Container Park.

I was visiting Freemont Street and saw this very interesting set up! What a great concept to use containers to make more space! The jungle gym in the centre was free for the children to run around while the parents could sit on the outside and relax or have a cup of coffee. 

There were many different stores at the bottom level and the artist shops were at the top.

I don't know why it took so long for Vegas to get creative... I enjoy every bit of the container park more often than not. It's artsy, hip and fun. Deegan has a blast on the playground centered in the middle of the park and there is seating around for parents. I do wish there would be a bit more seating especially on the busier days, but nothing too serious. 

The businesses are a mix of food and some pricey boutiques. Some of my favorites are jinju chocolates, cheffinis, Disney art, the new toy store and new Betty store. We also enjoy the grassy area in front of the stage and the fire shooting mantis that greats you in the front. Some of the store and shops do change because we were told they want to keep things new for people to keep coming back.

The container Park is something you must enjoy both during the day and at night. At night you get a different feel for things and you can enjoy the park as an adult because they won't let kids in after a certain time. Certified adult time! 

This is a spot we thoroughly enjoy and looking forward to them hopefully one day expanding.

This place was so cool. Stores build inside shipping containers. How creative.

Lots of small arts and crafts places. And their all priced very moderate. A ton of good food places. Ate at the hot dog place and taco place which was good. Lots of kids which I hated. They should stay home, it's Vegas.

The only thing I didn't get is the entrance where this band played and there was a gas lit praying mantis which made more noise the.n was entertaining. Kind of annoying. But cool place to see.

I haven't gone during the day time, but during the night, it's closed off to those who over 21+. There's a fun recycled tree house to play on and go down the slides and a beef jerky store that gives away samples. They also have a live performance going on and alcohol and food places that are open as well. Not all of the places were opened but many on the first floor were open. It's a pretty neat place to check out, to see how recycled material can be used to create beautiful places. It's free to get in, but parking is tricky. We parked at a dirt lot about 3 blocks down.

We were in the area, and searched out a good taco place. That search took us here to the Container Park. 

I was super excited to finally check this place out. I had seen a few photos of the area, but really didn't know much about it. Stacked containers with stores? Sure, why not. We parked along the street, and paid the meter which was for all of the spaces on that side of the street. It accepted my credit card, and we parked for $2/hour. 

The praying mantis with fire coming from the antennae greeted us at the entrance...which is at the north end of the park. Okay, that was rather interesting, and I had to take a picture...along with everyone else who saw it. We scoped out the taco place first, which was just inside of the entrance and to the left. Meanwhile, I heard this really loud sound, and found out that it was  flames errupting out of the same antennae that we had just seen on the praying mantis. Now that was a conversation piece.

After eating, we walked around the area. It was a quick walk. Things here are rather expensive, so we just decided to window shop. The area was much smaller than we had anticipated, but it all looked pretty cool. Kids were having a lot of fun inside of the play area where there were bridges and slides among other things. 

It was nice to finally say that we have seen the Container Park, but I can't see going back any time soon. If you are looking to spend your money in yet another place in Vegas, this place is kind of fun because it is unique. It is just a few blocks from Fremont Experience, so when it is not super hot outside it would be worth walking over here for shopping. Although my favorite thing was the praying mantis, to be honest. Great tacos at Pinches tacos, even though they were kind of pricey.

This place is awesome! We are not from Las Vegas and we wanted to take our kids somewhere fun off the strip. The playground in the middle of the park is huge with tons of things for the kids to do. My wife and I ordered from a few different places in the park and EVERYTHING was delicious.

I love Container Park! I've been here 3 times even though I'm from out of town and appreciate the design and options it provides. There are several different restaurants and bars to choose from and the play area in the middle is great to let the kids run around. They also have a stage area and looks like it would be a cool spot to check out some music or whatever they do down here. 

If you're coming down to the Fremont District, make sure to stop by for a visit and you can watch the Giant Mantis fire up at night!
Kid friendly place located in old town vegas district! Has some really cool places to check and hipster shops.

My family loves the Container Park.  We always discover something new.  Our newest discovery is Rykovich Dreamland. His art is amazing!  Pinches Tacos is a must eat.  Our daughter loves the park which is conveniently located in the center.  Who thought a bunch of shipping containers could be a fun and eclectic place to shop and eat.

Awesome place to hang out away from the strip. There are no gambling in the facility but a giant play ground with a tree house in the middle so great for kids until 10 pm when it turns into adult oriented environment with drinking and band playing. A lot of great eats and drinks located within the containers plus entertainment at certain hours. Great visit when you're in downtown Vegas.

Love everything about this quirky place! From the flaming praying mantis to the quirky shops built from shipping containers. But my absolute favorite thing is the playground.  At 9pm the kids have to leave and the (mostly intoxicated) adults take over the playground.  It's a guaranteed fun night with guaranteed sore muscles the next few days.  They have a stage in the grassy area for events and bands. Super cool fun place to hang out.

I love the vibe great environment family friendly! great shopping and food  great for a family outing or date night :) check out black boutique they carry all black clothes for men women and plus size! If you like wearing Black as much as me this is your spot prices are reasonable and great quality  all and all always enjoy going to the container park!

Yes! First to review!! I literally came here at 1:30 and there were already a ton of people there. The place really looks great, there are a bunch of guards, Downtown Rangers and a crazy Robocop there to assist you. 

Although some of the shops have not opened because of permit issues, the majority of stores are open. From the outside everything looks so small, but the shops are decent sized, all things considered. 

There are several communal eating areas to eat and drink outside, which is fantastic. It gives the place a college vibe. They also have seating on the top floor, those chairs look mighty comfy!

I checked out some if the stores and everything looks awesome. I had been eagerly anticipating Jessica Galindo's shop and was happy to find a leather business card holder. Score!

Loving it so much I'm coming back tonight! Viva DTLV!

Loved it.  Ate some good food (the chicken tortilla soup was great) and the margaritas were even better.  Contrary to another post I read, I thought the jewelry was cheap.  Will definitely go back with the grand kids.

Super cute place and an innovative concept. Loved walking through all of the different shops. Every shop owner was an absolute sweetheart. The playground area in the middle was running wild with little ones but there is then a strict curfew that clears them out after a certain time (9pm?). That is when the fun begins because you then see adults running around the playground and going down the slides. The praying mantis of fire is awesome but kept scaring the absolute crap out of me when I wasn't expecting it to go off.

The Container Park opening was a lot of fun. I am the Purchasing Manager for Xtreme Manufacturing,  the Cube portion of this project so you may think I'm bias but I'm honest and straight forward so I will give the good and the bad. This was an amazing idea brought to reality. In my opinion this Park is focused more towards adults then children although with a little Disney mixed in with cupcakes, and the playhouse the kids will love this place and not be bored at all. I like the way this place is set up and really enjoyed variety all the vendor stores. The only things I didn't like about the park is I would have liked it better bigger and more grass added. Also some of the vendor's signs could pop a little more. All and all I can't wait to call one of those dining or bar establishments my new local spot.

Pretty cool area. Definitely a great place for kids. I saw lots of kids there playing and having fun while their parents eat. Unfortunately, the food there are so expensive. I mean maybe not expensive for the local, but as a tourist, I found the food to be pricey. The only reasonable price I saw was two chicken strips and fries for about $6. It seems like a lot of live shows happen here.
If you have children, definitely the place to be. For the solo people, definitely a place to check out. Short walk from Fremont Experience.
It was okay for me nothing big they have a live band. Blankets and a swing chair you can set on really chilled atmosphere.

Really really nice place, great to know there are places like this one in town. We did come Sunday though, and that's the one downside: the place is rather small and it was PACKED. 

Overall though, really nice experience: tiny shops, cute bars and eateries, a super cool Hawaiian style band playing at the back, tons of space to sit down and an awesome kids outdoor playground at the center.

The concept of the Container Park is a nice addition to the Fremont East experience, however, similar to the retail development in Costa Mesa, which was intended to showcase more independent retailers and products, the Container Park still houses a fair collection of knick knack merchants.  Unfortunately,  a number of these items are the same junky items that can be purchased at many of the souvenir shops along The Strip and elsewhere.

The food offerings are a standout, in that they are not national chain fast food establishments that so many Las Vegas visitors seem to favor.

This is probably a great spot for the locals, especially ones with children. The overall concept is great, but it just felt like a miniature size city to me. A lot of stores here, but very small, if I see at least three people inside its too crowded to go in. The bars and a couple of eateries were slightly bigger, probably made with multiple containers. I can see coming here for some weekday shopping or catch some live music on the "grass", while children play in the playground, but for tourists, one time thing. Parking is terrible and expensive around the park, the lot across the street is 15 bucks flat rate, rip off.

This place is kinda cool, I guess? 

The concept is neat, and when you see it from afar you'll be thinking you totally want to go check it out. And you should. There are some unique art installations in front, which includes a giant bug and some military-type stuff. It's the sort of nightmarish hallucinatory artwork that would be at home in "Fear & Loathing in Las Vegas". 

Once you step inside the "park", you'll find it's just a collection of small boutique stores, many of which didn't hold much interest for me. This is the kind of place where you come to grab a beer, walk around window shopping for about 20 minutes, then hit the road. 

Of course, if you want to be lazy about it there are plenty of little alcoves and rest areas where one could lay down, catch some zzzs and people watch for an afternoon. Fun to check out once, but I can't think of a single reason why I'd go out of my way to go back.

Four stars cause this is a pretty neat place, not five though because there really is nothing here for me. If you live in the area I'm sure its a fun little spot to come hang out at but its just not my style. I will say its a quaint little gem for the area.

A total random awesome discovery. My friend and I just finished brunch at Eat. and was walking towards Fremont Street Experience and heard a bunch of kids. It was literally blocked out by shipping containers but through some "cracks" we saw a play area and was wondering how to get in. Once we got to the front and saw the giant praying mantis, we knew.

There's a lady in the front taking visitor count, I think. I thought we had to had to buy tickets because she was standing there. But it's free entry. Inside is a bunch of shops and a huge play area for kids. Giant treehouse looking thing. Favorite shop here is Kappa toys. Lots of anime, cartoon, cute things. Definitely come give this place a visit. It's only 3 blocks from Frement Street Experience!

What a great extension of the Fremont Street Experience! Vegas's own little Hipsterville. The old school barbershop screams hipster. Chic boutiques housed in shipping containers create a voyeuresque look. Very modern and clean. The containers are Architecturally interesting structures to wander through, it's fun for kids and adults.

There are rad outdoor sculptures that include a huge praying mantis. It's a Beautifully lit outdoor space for enjoying a different type of Vegas entertainment. Everyone is welcome, in casual clothes or dressed up. It's family and kid friendly. Kudos to the designers of The Container Park.


Food trucks hang out and offer tasty affordable Vegas food. Forget the strip, this is more my style. I'm happy to hang out and spend my $$ here.

I love this place. I take my kids here all the time and they are obsessed with the giant tree house playground. I also had their BirthDay party here and it was so cute!! I would def have it here again! 

This place is perfect for adults and children. Cute restaurants and bars. I love how they have live bands playing too! 

Definitely my favorite place in Las Vegas!

GREEN PACKING

I heard about this place but I had to go check it out myself. It is a short 2 block walk from the Fremont Street experience.  My only advice is to keep your eyes open in the back of your head. It is a short but seedy walk. 

Once you arrive you are greeted by a giant metal bug at the entrance. It is made of recycled stuff. The whole mall is made of those metal shipping containers you see on boats, trains & trucks. I thought that was an incredible way to recycle and go green. It also reminded me of my days of being a child when I stacked blocks. I can not confirm this but the architect might be 5 years old. 

I was really happy to see this place get packed at lunch time which means the tourists are coming down here. There are plenty of outdoor tables and many people were eating at the various restaurants located here. There is a great outdoor stage which has various musical acts.
