So if you want to visit Vegas in a nontraditional way, then don't feel trapped at the Strip, get inside the Downtown Container Park and don't contain your excitement!

Brought my girlfriend here for date night the mantis was her favorite part she enjoyed the whole experience and so did i. Oak & ivy was awesome and the bottomless drinks at downtown terrace were great

We walked over here from our hotel on Fremont St. A lot of different shops, a lot of which were closed but we did find the best Mexican food any of us ever had so that is 1 star earned right there. It was a fun excursion and nice for a change of pace.

I've lived in Vegas for 23 years and I'm so happy to see downtown thriving and bustling. The container park is a blast for the whole family. We had great barbecue shopped around play football in the grass and the kids loved the playground with the treehouse think it's absolutely fabulous. We had a great time and will be back soon but at night.

Pretty cool "shopping mall"! It is pretty small, but if you have a child that is circa under 6, this is a pretty fun place to go with the treehouse and slides.  It was different than most malls, since everything was in shipping containers.  It was pretty cool, good restaurant variety, good boutiques, and coffeeshops, bubble tea, popsicles and bars!  A little bit of everything!

A must see place while you're in Las Vegas. Yes it is downtown, but it ain't a far drive. It might be a $20-30 Uber/Lyft/Taxi ride but still, this place reminds me of this one place in Portland. 

So the place, if you haven't guessed it, is made out of shipping containers. They even have an elevator inside the shipping container. What's cool is that there's restaurants, a coffee shop, stores, and even a place for the kids. You've got to see the slides because they're pretty tall. There is also a quad area with fake grass and a stage so you can relax and hang out and I'm going to guess they have like concerts at the park. 

Anyways, I recommend you coming here. People post it on Instagram and even Chase has it as a background when you try logging in on the mobile app when you're in Vegas. Haha go figure

Had lunch here the other day at the BBQ place. There was a cool vibe happening. The weather was nice so we sat outside.  There was a live band playing during the lunch hour and it was pleasant. Had sometime to walk around after we ate and there are some very cool funky local shops. I will definitely be going back. I think it will be a cool place to check it out at night.
Man you gotta stop in here they have it all, food, live entertainment, play area for kids and friendly staff.

A block east of Fremont Street Experience, the Container Park is a must-see oasis in a somewhat drab and shady desert that surrounds it, so walk past the fire-breathing giant preying mantis (and the people near the gate who may or may not be security people, salesman, data collectors) and you will be in a gated and quirky outdoor mall (llama crossing?), free of the sketchiness outside, surrounded by three levels of intertwined containers repurposed into chic stores, services, and places to get food and drinks (I recommend Pinches Tacos), with clean restrooms, recycling centers, a somewhat limited amount of tables, a stage and entertainment area, a black brick makeshift chalkboard wall, and a giant play center that resembles a Coachella art installation.  That was one sentence, by the way.

This is a great addition to downtown Las Vegas.  Nestled at the Far East end of Fremont Street this park has a little bit of everything you need.  It's got food, bars, shopping, amazing art, live music and some great events have taken place here.  We hung out at the Perch then had tacos down at the entrance.  Met some great people and had fun.  This is a perfect spot to hang out and enjoy a day.

This is an amazing concept spot for non gaming fun in a gaming zone. Something our city desperately needs. A little cultural for a culturally starved city. 

My fear (or perhaps hope) is that the boutique style shops will not be able to maintain a presence, and will morph into more small specialty bars and eateries. 

I envision a gin specific bar, a red wine tasting room, a spot for blanco tequila flights, sliders, noodles, brownies. Cool niche stuff. The sky is the limit. 

Good music, great 'new options' for those who wish to explore and grow in a culinary sense without being intimidated by fancy expensive restaurants and snobby club settings. 

With the right marketing, and good people to fill the spaces, thus could REALLY REALLY become something truly special.

Took a friend to Container Park, after eating nearby.  He's from Michigan, so he has a lot of new sights and sounds to take in.  It's been several years since I've been there when it opened, so it was kind of new to me as well.

Lots of great little retail stores, bars and other things to see and do.  I like it better at night when it's really alive, but it was still fun to visit.  My friend liked it a lot too.  He'll be back this year and plans to spend more time Downtown, especially at night.

Cool
Area for kids to just run around for a couple of hours. A couple; not a few. Walk down the street and get pizza afterwards. Adults, you can indulge in a couple rounds of beers and get tacos!
Loved the COOL college like atmosphere and the Funky shops.

I'd heard about this place from a few people and decided it was worth a shot to check out.   The concept behind it is pretty cool, a little odd but cool.  Containers setup in a rectangle... stores in each spot and an awesome kids area in the middle.  

I had an awesome burrito at pinche's and the girlfriend and I sat there people watching for quite a while.   

So for the kids... they have this awesome 3 story treehouse with lots of little nooks and crannies that are going all over.  Random foam looking pool "noodles" along with connecter pieces were laying all over for them to beat the ish out of each other or be creative (something for all types I guess?).  I was ALMOST jealous for the parents that brought their kids there.  The kids vastly outnumbered the parents there, so I've got to assume many were enjoying beers at the tables and just watching their kids go wild.  Over-all really cool place to visit a few times. 

Since I don't have kids, not sure how often I'll be back.  The burrito I had was some of the best mexican food I've had outside of So Cal... so that's the main draw for myself if I do find my way back.
Fun place for the family. Although my 2 1/2 year old son was very disappointed when they told him he was too little to go down the slides.

I may be 45 but that HUGE praying mantis with the fire and music could keep me entertained for hours.  Get past that and the food at the Mexican restaurant is worth the visit.  Everything I have tried there so far is sooo good.  The artsy shops are fun to browse through and I like supporting local artist so even though a little pricey at least it isn't going to some big corporation.  There is a stage with live music and a bar that is very unique.  The bartenders are the best I have found in town and the drinks are amazing.  Pricey but again, worth it.  Even if you are a local this is a must go see place.  The only place we found so far that was not good is the BBG restaurant.   My husband hated the food there and was very disappointed.  A fun date night out.  Will be recommending this place to everyone.

Being in Container Park was such a great night out. The ambiance is perfect with great little shops, music and food. I want to go back in the day with my kids so they can play in the tree house. Finally Vegas had some small business places where we can enjoy a night out in a safe clean place.
Cool spot with many different restaurants, cafes, and stores. It was a fun place to hang out to get a break from dtlv and the strip.

I really enjoy the Container Park for what it is. I am a supporter of local business, and the concept is genius for start-up businesses in the valley. I generally don't go there to do a lot of shopping, but there are a few spots that I like to go to while I'm there, like Bin 702, Oak & Ivy, JoJo's Jerky, and a few other clever shops.
I like to bring an appetite when I come, too. There are a few spots for foodies like my partner and me. 
The large play area located between Bin 702 and Oak & Ivy is perfect for families - both children and parent alike. 
Oh, and I love when the giant preying mantis scares the pants off my partner.

This is a nice addition to the (former) derelict part of downtown. There were food and dessert shops, clothing and  jewelry stores, artsy and crafty little boutiques in addition to nice outdoor areas for little kids (and big adults) to play. You can walk throughout this whole place in less than 10 minutes so it's a rather small park but it is a nice place to spend an afternoon if you happened to be around the area. The praying mantis at the entrance was probably my favorite thing about this park.

Downtown Container Park has been instrumental in revitalizing East Fremont. Case in point: Before Container Park, there is no way I would've walked that far East to get to Atomic Liquors for fear of being shanked, but now I feel safe enough to do so! Container Park has become the focus for so many 5k fun runs held downtown and is doing much to become a focal point for the community as well. Small beer fests, live music events, movie nights, and holiday celebrations are regularly held at Container Park. 

I fell head over heels with Downtown Container Park the moment I laid eyes on it. A fire-breathing praying mantis greets visitors at the entrance. 'Downtown Rangers' stand at the ready to make sure the riff raff is kept out. Container Park is literally built out of colorful shipping containers. Trees line the park and cute stringed lights are strung about. A decent sized playground is in the center of the park. There's plenty of seating available near restaurants and around the playground. 

What I love about Container Park is that it features 100% local businesses. Each business is unique. Mention worthy restaurants include vegan eatery Simply Pure, Cheffini's for fancy hotdogs, JinJu Chocolates, and Oak & Ivy for crafty cocktails. 

Container Park is best enjoyed at a leisurely pace. Try to go at a time that coincides with an event. Grab a bite to eat, find a place to sit, and just relax and people watch!

YELP 100 CHALLENGE 2015: #210

Very cool spot.  Warning!  You cannot come in with any of those huge drinks you bought on Freemont Street.  So sit down and guzzle so you can enjoy this converted container park.  Different vendors are set up for food and various niche shops.  There is s stage in the back for live entertainment.  Also, a kids park for the young ones.  This place makes a lot more sense for families than nearby Freemont. Overall, things were on the pricy side.  I loved the artwork and the praying mantis shooting fire was just incredible.

Cute little park made out of shipping containers! There's a praying mantis in the front that shoots out flames to music every 15 min at night. Fun fact: it used to be a moving art installation at burning man!

Plenty of street parking for $2/hour. You won't need more than that unless you want to shop or eat a lot. 

Also great place for kids to burn some energy since there's a big playground in the middle. 

Bring a lock to lock on the heart with your loved one. They sell them here at Artbox, but it's $9.

Totally in LOVE with this place! If you have kids, and frequent the downtown area that's near the Fremont Street experience, this place is a MUST! It feels like Urban meets Modern and was placed in an upcoming area. Kind of reminds me of that Artist area in Santa Ana by the Playground. 

There is one main entrance area and there is a turnstile exit that is broken (boo..., we had to walk back to to the main entrance for not knowing) There is a public restroom by the left side of the entrance. Think of outdoor gas station bathroom but a LOT cleaner. 

The focal point here is the treehouse. It's great for kids to climb and discover the insides of this fake treehouse. On the far end there's a great lawn area and oversized legos. 

As for the shops, you can tell this place was made for the kids when you see Ice cream, candy, popcorn type shops all huddled together side by side. We got to try ChillspotLV and it did not disappoint. (Will be on a separate review) II also love how they have separate garbage containers. One for recycles, one for regular, it's funny they have a compartment for "weird stuff"

What I didn't really love is that you have to pay for parking here. I mean really? Isn't there enough free parking around this area? I guess I can relate people would just park here overnight making it miserable for tourists like us to find parking. 

There are other shops I really wanted to try here but the sun was just unbearable here the day I went and it was scorching hot with no sign of shade even though we were there for less than an hour. I will be back and I hope to spend at least a good 2 hours here next time.
Cool addition to downtown Las Vegas!!! Little specialty shops, 3 story tree house playground and more.

Love it. Happened upon it and wouldn't even have known it was there if not for the huge praying manthis whose antennae light up in flames! A great idea to get people's attention. But then Container Park, what's that? A home decor store? My boyfriend insisted they had cool bars in there so we showed ID and in we went. The first thing I noticed was a huge treehouse. We walked up it and not only does it give you nice views of the park when you get to the top (and exercise) it has tube SLIDES! What a great idea and so much fun. :) Chill live music is being played on a stage behind a "grassy" area where people are sprawled out relaxing. Behind the treehouse is a light touch game, another brilliant idea, especially drunk. :p This is all "contained" around a few restaurants/bars that look promising. We only went to one, Boozery. Love the concept, I will definitely be back and I hope nothing closes!! Pork and beans looks great, I wanna check it out!
The BBQ spot was delicious, and not too pricey either. Parking was relatively easy to find (came in March), and the entire facility was family oriented.

This is a very cool place, very modern and the choice of shops and restaurants is well chosen!  However there are a few places that were closed or closed that day during business hours which still gave it an off feeling, I was looking forward to seeing the salon in the train car at the back and it was closed, and the candy store was closed...

Fire coming out of a mantis? What's the difference between a mantis and a grasshopper? A llama and an alpaca? Helloooo?

We were pre-gaming in Summerlin then moved on to Banger Brewery but that wasn't enough so we came here for more drinks and shenanigans. We went down the slide a few times - I recommend curling up into a ball once you're in the tube. I had my legs stretched out the first time and I got stuck. This is a playground for big kids and I love it! You have to be at least 21 and they will check for ID. If they had swings, I wouldn't want to leave this place. 5 stars!

They have a jerky shop, clothing stores, cupcakes, frozen treats, barber place, BBQ, wine bar, a bar with beer and cocktails...but none serve fries. 1 star!

We went to a bar and witnessed a tall guy bitch slap a smaller guy with what looked like a paper bag from Mac (not Mac as in Apple but Mac cosmetics). Is this how hipsters fight? Too much PBR. I was confused as I've never seen such wussy fighting. There was too much smiling and too much talking, not enough punching. That "fight" was too G-rated so being 21 to get in CP was not warranted. Cops were in the BBQ place - if I were a cop, I'd continue enjoying my BBQ than waste my time on those people.

So yeah, the concept is a bunch of stacked containers turned into stores. I wonder if they'll have a dumpster jacuzzi. Hmmm...lots of drinks and shenanigans were definitely had.

I love artsy and creative places and this place fits It! Located near Freemont Street and The Mob Museuem (see my Yelp reviews), this is SUCH a cool place. They took those big containers that you see loaded on ships carrying storage, cleaned them out and arranged them into a really cool park, complete with art shops, restaurants, a huge stage for concerts, a playhouse playground in the center, cafes, stores and even a cute wedding chapel! When you get there, you are greeted by a huge metal praying mantis metal sculpture. Eww, but Wow! There are cooling misters all over since it is outside with no cover to protect you from the heat. I would have liked to spend more time exploring for sure. I would definitely go back!! There are 3 levels of places to explore so give yourself plenty of time!

This is pretty cool place. Its like a park and shopping center combined made with recycled shipping containers. What an ingenious idea! 

I love that this is both adult and child friendly. Its a cool place to spend time relaxing. There's plenty of places to sit outside to eat and/or socialize. There's a large play structure in the middle good for kids of all ages. There's also a large turf area at the back with a giant lego pieces and connect 4 and behind that a salon inside of an old train. 

There's numerous shops, several places to eat and several places to drink. I really wish we had something like this in the Sacramento area, it would be a cool hangout for a nice night.

I love that Vegas is getting culture or what I affectionately call the: Zappos-ification of Downtown Las Vegas. Downtown is supposed to have an edge and I wanna feel the need to walk with mace in my hand. 

What's the deal with DTCP? Old shipping containers have been transformed into a community shopping, eating, and playtime destination fit for the whole family. There's a huge jungle gym, locally-owned small businesses, a wine bar, and few overrated & overpriced diners. Some awesome perks, the entire DTCP is a non-smoking and offers free wi-fi. 

There is a stage in the back of the space where local and traveling talents perform for free or special events, like fashion shows, or even headliners Sheryl Crow take the stage. So, you can either be included or not included. Check the schedule ahead of time.

Container park is a cool place to visit, but there's nothing that has me begging to go back again. It's a place to eat, shop, and take in tunes. The only thing that makes this place stand out are the shipping containers.

This is a really great idea and use of materials readily available....shipping containers! 
I've heard of 3rd world countries using shipping containers as homes/shelters for the masses, but seeing this place takes that concept to a whole other level. It's really creative and well thought out.  It's got cute, boutique type stores (no chains in here), large artwork/sculptures and a play area for kids and I was digging the outdoor grass/stage are too. The potential for this place is huge, especially if they have concerts/shows or special events here. 

I went here to shop at JinJu Chocolates (first time there too) and it was a Monday afternoon so it was very slow and not busy at all. It was a bit confusing as there's only one way in and one way out of the park, which at first I thought was odd but then I remembered, you're in downtown LV which up until recently was crack ho central (am I wrong?) so of course you gotta have some sort of control over the "flow of traffic" so to speak. Due to time constraints I was limited on how long I could stay and didn't get to check out every shop, but what I saw was enough to know that Container Park is step in the right direction of trying to reclaim and rebrand a "blighted" area or better yet, be an oasis in a desert. 

Like others have mentioned, it's small, so this place in itself in not really a destination, but if you're staying in Downtown or planning to hang out in downtown, then definitely make this place a pit stop in your journey, it's different.

This was a pretty neat place to visit.  There was a fenced in playground in the middle with shops and restaurants all around it.  We were a little bummed though because the super tall (and super cool) slide was closed while we were there.  No explanation as to why so that was a let down because we specifically had gone there to let our kids run around and burn off some energy and had read about the tall, twisty slide.  

There were these cool foam blocks of all different shapes and sizes that the kids could build with.  I had never seen something like that at a public playground before. The blocks were kind of worn and dirty and our hands were filthy after playing with them but hands are easily washable.   It was something unique and it was fun to build a castle together.  

The only store there that we went in was the toy store and it was pretty neat.  They had a lot of Pokmon and Mario toys/plush/cards which is what my son is all about right now.  They had other toys and novelties too that would be worth checking out.

What a cool and unique concept - local shops in shipping containers in a "contained" retail park. I love supporting local business and the shops and restaurants are great here. Fashion, accessories, art, stationery, food, coffee, etc. There's something for everyone in here! There's even a cool "treehouse" for the kiddos to play in, and a lawn area where there's frequently musicians/bands to check out in the evenings and weekends. There's outdoor seating and tables to eat or just chill (and people watch). My only complaint is that sometimes the spaces are a little *too* tight, especially with a stroller. But what a cool place to come and support your local businesses and spend some time out.

Read online reviews wanted to take my nieces and grand daughter to walk it, got there at 8:55 pm on sat night, watched the mantis sing which was great, turn to go in stopped at the entrance because the rude black lady rent a security guard was a butt. Apparently the hours stated on their site is wrong for families with kids. What a disappointment for their first impression of Las Vegas, will not suggest it to any of my visiting family or friends.

This place is exactly what I have wanted to see in Las Vegas!!!!  It has some interesting eclectic shops and a nice big screen outdoors, perhaps they will show movies?  I came here to visit Chillspot but found the popcorn place, Big Ern's and San Miguel art collection stores.  I love this place and plan to keep coming back.  I don't smoke and I have asthma so I appreciate that smoking here is not allowed.  

They have bathrooms which are heated and stocked with plenty of toilet paper.  I wish to come back, in the spring perhaps, when it's not so cold outside.

This up and coming area downtown is a breath of fresh air. All the stores are made out of shipping containers and pushes for a more sustainable lifestyle.  They just need to change their plastic cups. While places in there use biodegradable items, the cups are not as environmentally friendly. 

Although it is still in the growing phases, there is huge  potential to be an awesome place to come chill out on the lawn and hang out with friends while bands play. 

The drinks are reasonable. Nothing too out of the ordinary for downtown. There is a beer and wine bar as well as a fully stocked liquor one on the other side. 

Once all the stores are fully up and running, this will be the it place for a relaxing night.

Great place to spend an afternoon eating and listening to music.  Places to go is the Taco place and BQ Joint and the places NOT go, the bar BOOZERY, JO JOs Beefjerky and Pork bean, these places are over priced.

Very disappointed. We had a bunch of family visiting from California that were staying downtown freemont street. Having a good group of kids we were looking for shops and something to entertain them for a few hours. Container park having a playground and shops seemed like the perfect place to take everyone in walking distance to downtown. What a joke this place was. The playground looked like so much fun! Most of the slides where closed and the kids spent maybe 5 minutes on the playground as everything on it was shut down. So we went to check out the shops. The kids being ages 6yrs to 15yrs old where over it in 15 minutes of walking around. We spent maybe 20 minutes walking around here and walked back to our hotel. Spent more time walking there then actually in the park. Very disappointing and embarrassing to take the family. Next time we will check things out before we take company!

Loved! Loved! Loved the Container Park! 
It's a very creative, clean & inviting space for families. There are multiple places for breakfast lunch, beer & dessert as well as little boutiques. 

The play area in the middle is free for kids. There is a large space in the back that has couches & turf for kids to run & play. When we visited Las Vegas this past week we found ourselves there 3 different times. It felt very safe and fun for our family. It's nice that it's within walking distance from the "Freemont Street Experience". 

Definitely a must see, even if you don't have kids. It has a nice vibe all around.

Every city should have a street block dedicated to a container park!  Downtown Las Vegas is certainly up and coming and I am pretty positive (even as a visitor) that the Container Park has a lot to do with it.

This spot has the coolest tree house/playground area EVER.  The treehouse is about 4 stories and has 3 slides.... and on it I rediscovered the joy of slides!  The playground is good for kids of all ages and very safe.  Security guards are sweet but watchful and they make sure all people follow the rules and don't abuse the space. When we went during the day there was even a base player. 

The container park is a great place for kids during the day but turned into an adult hipster hang out at night. The christmas lights that are strung around the area give a great ambiance to the area. The area is basically a great place to explore.  We went into a couple of great local boutiques and looked around.  There were some places to eat also as well as dessert shops.  

When we came back to the container park at night, we checked out Bin 702.  The cheese plate was amazing and so was the glass of Malbec I enjoyed while walked around the park. Yes, it is a little pricey but there was wonderful service and the place was awesome.

The area is trying to be a zero-waste facility- an amazing goal for a city that didn't seem to be too eco-friendly.  There are stations that tell you how to recycle and divide your trash.

The art there is diverse.... ranging from murals to a beautiful heart sculpture and a gigantic, kind of scary praying mantis that randomly sprays fire.  Super awesome!  I think the containers are also works of art: the windows, vibrant colors, the way they are stacked, etc.  

It is definitely worth checking this place out to get a break from the strip and get your does of art and culture.  Perfects for bringing the kids during the day also!
We had a great time!  My toddler loved it.  And we got some great BBQ,  2 hour paid parking but 2 hours was more than enough.
This is a good spot to meet your friends and just chat and nosh! My friend's daughter, who is 10, did not like it. We went at 9pm.

Very cool place to look at and seemed like a fun place to take the kids for the play sets running through the middle.  Just don't expect ANY service from the bars.  We went into several and were not acknowledged ONCE.  The first one was called, I think, Bin?  Went inside, got ignored.  No "hello".  No "go ahead and sit outside and we'll be right there".  Nothing.  We went outside and sat at a table for about 5-10 minutes watching the waitress serve some other groups while she completely ignored us.  And yes - she did see us.  And no - it was literally the two of us and two, maybe three, other small groups.  We wondered if we were going n the wrong place?  If so, say something!!  So, we tried at Oak and Ivy next.  Same thing.  Dude behind the bar was COUNTING money, looked at us then went back to counting.  Again, no hello or anything.  I started to wonder if you needed a code word or something to get served in these places.  Our last stop was Pinches Tacos.  Ignored again.  And let me clarify - NONE of these places were busy.  So, out we went to one of the fifty bars along Fremont where yes - we got served.  Yay!!  Unless you know the secret to service at this place, don't expect any.  Go take a picture of the giant praying mantis, let your kids run amok on the play sets and  sneak in your own snacks and water.  Then, you might enjoy yourself.

What a cool random find! 

You'll need to show your ID upon entrance. I'm guessing it's because alcohol is an option? 

It's a playground for adults! The first game is similar to kung fu panda game where you hit all the circles that light up. Then you walk a few more steps and there are tons of building blocks. A few more steps and you are walking up stairs to slide down tall slides! It was dark when we came so I was a tad nervous about sliding. These slides are legit though - you might be afraid from the speed. 

Besides the playground, they also have a bench swing, a grassy area, comfy seats, bathrooms downstairs and upstairs, tiny shops throughout and amazing paintings located upstairs with a view of the entire park.

Took the kiddos to Container Park and they had a really good time! Climbing the tree house, playing with the oversized blocks and having a shaved ice really made their day!

Definitely recommended for a date night or a kids play day.

Mom in town and brought her here to explore and have lunch at the mexican restaurant, support local artists and play in the tree house.  Well, my daughter did, but I loved how they have security at the gate and there is a fence all around so you they are safe.  My daughter loved climbing up to the top to ride the slide down many times.  We will go back for a date night without my child so we can explore at night when it is open to adults only.  I loved that we were able to come here and then down to Fremont Experience.  It was a great day!

This place sounded great. They have a secure enclosed park in the middle of the courtyard with surrounding stores for parents to browse while the kids play. Only problem is their security staff is way over the top and will kick you out of the park at a whim. I've never seen someone lose their mind quite like that. The lady heading up the staff there came unglued, refused to listen, and assumed an awful lot (which is the opposite of how security should behave). It was embarrassing and ruined the day. Take your kid to a real park. This place isn't worth the aggravation.

This place is fantastic.  Went last Friday night and they had live music and the vibe was great.... people laughing, kids dancing on the lawn, couples enjoying meals at the various eateries.

I love this project and the whole idea of fixing up the downtown Las Vegas... it was a diamond in the rough really falling on hard times and now I am really excited to see how the revitalization unfolds.

It's unique to say the least - the area is made entirely from recycled shipping containers. Good space for kids, given that the center of the park is dedicated to a large play area - slightly reminiscent of the Swiss Family Treehouse at Disneyland. There are Downtown Rangers within the play area to monitor children, although parents are allowed in as well. There's also a small stage on one end of the park where you can find free live music on the weekends. 

Other than the play area, it's basically a hodgepodge of small shops and eateries.  The food is OK although there is one hidden gem on the second level - Simply Pure. 

Parking can be tricky, especially if there's an event going on. Nearby streets are all metered parking. There are some free streets, however, along 8th and Bridger and 7th and Ogden. Otherwise, valet at the El Cortez for $2 bucks and call it a day!

I am so happy to have found this place. For the past 4 months I kept hearing people talk so highly about the container park so I had to check it out. Parking was extremely easy and I love the fact that they have security standing at the entrance to make sure kids under 18 can not enter without an adult. It is so clean and you feel extremely safe. The play ground for kids is amazing! It is gated with one entrance only ( with a security guard) allowing you to drop off your child while you sit back and relax on their outdoor couches. The guard will not allow any children to enter or exit without an adult. The boutiques are adorable and the staff is very friendly.

One of my favorite spots to eat, shop, relax, meet friends and did I say eat?
Clean, friendly, music, and a nice park for kids before 9pm. 
I even enjoy reading the chalk board.
I can't seem to make it out of there without making a stop at the candy store!

I love the vibe of the container park...it's a little gated off Vegas escape.  It has a more urban/modern feel than the rest of Vegas and definitely Fremont area.  The park closes to minors at 9pm, so definitely has a lounge/bar feel with some of the restaurants that line the lower level.  I'm not sure if there is a live cover band all the time, but on Friday night they were playing on the back stage.  Love that the drummer does vocals for the covers =)  There is a large child/adult play area in the center...with a huge slide.  Kid friendly by day with a preying mantus that spits fire outside.  I've seen adults go down the slide too...so parents who are scared of creepers beware.  Cute little boutique shops with the matching price tag.  Overall, probably a good week end date night spot with all the little restaurant options.
Pretty cool idea.  Neat shops. I hope it expands to add more.  It was just SO HOT that we couldn't really tolerate the outside for too long.  And it's walking distance from the Supercharger Station!

Pleasantly surprised! Nice to have a beer while watching the kids play.. Great for families who want to bring kids who want to run around.. Lots of restaurants & retail.. Great idea to utilize container units.. Parking had a fee, make sure you time it because we almost forgot about the time limit. Good mix of people, felt safe & environment was clean. We had a great time coz it was new to us

I seriously love this place, period. It's so cute and quaint. It literally makes me forget that I'm even in Las Vegas. My review is more for the kid friendliness of it. It is extremely kid friendly. It has this great tree house playground for the kiddos to climb and play and run and play and climb and...okay, you get it. Parents, just know you MUST accompany your child. The attendants will not let you just let your child run in then for you to walk off. Strollers aren't allowed in the actual playground so designate your significant other to be on stroller watch, or just park it on the side as you enter the playground. 

Aside from the playground, there is a turfed area where kids can run around. They have these oversized foamed building blocks for kids to build on this turf area. There is also a wall you can write or draw on with the chalk provided...or what's left of this chalk. Also, there's a small store that sells toys and other novelty items. This store is certainly not stroller friendly in my opinion. 

All-in-all, it's incredible amongst the downtown life to the whiskey lounges in the vicinity and restaurants...they remembered that there are adults with children and children need entertainment too. What's even better is it is completely kid friendly and FREE! In the summer...It does *suck* to be out there so it's not somewhere I'd prefer or think of bringing my kids to. However, people on vacay, surely it'd be an awesome find. Note, they do have mists to cool down. 

There's so much more I could brush on, but I felt the need to type more.of the kid part of it. Just know, though it is kid friendly...I don't think the restaurants are as kid friendly because these are containers and there might be food that just won't peek your kids interest. 

Highly recommend if you're looking for a different vibe or something/somewhere different to take the kiddos. 

Enjoy!

I love it here  for so many reasons.  First, I want to build a CONTAINER HOME, so this place gives me so many ideas.  Also its funky, fun and easy to get to.  I have been a number of times and always look forward to going back.   Hey and its free to see, another big bonus.
Love this place so much! Very cool vibe, very kid friendly.

Very cool addition to the Fremont Street experience! The container park is family friendly but chic enough to be that Friday night pre-game spot. Bars, restaurants, shops, mega play area all topped off with a stage for some live music.

This place is like an adults playground. I absolutely adore it and wish I could go more often. I live in Henderson, so it's kind of a treck up to the Freemont street area, but every once and awhile I just NEED to go there. So what exactly is the Container Park besides for sheer brilliance and awesome? I'm glad you asked. It's about a block south of Freemont Street, pas the Griffin, Insert Coins, and those other places that I never really pay attention to. On the right side of the street, you are greeted by a GIANT FIRE BREATHING PREYING MANTIS. No, really, you are. After the sun goes down, at least. Reasons why this place is awesome reason 1. That mantis is so cool. It's controlled by a person that presses the flame thrower button on it at various points in time. You can cheer them on for extra fire! Yay! Fire!

During the day, it's a good place for families to bring their kids too, since they have a free playground area complete with blocks, interactive stuff, and a giant slide in the middle. Great fun for the whole family, really. There are also a variety of small shops made out of, well, containers. If you feel like having a cold one on a hot day, which happens in Vegas, there are a few bars scattered around to quench your thirst as well. The area isn't exactly BIG per say, but the Container Park manages to pack a punch in the area it was given. They also have a stage with live music from time to time. Oh, and by the stage, there are couches that you can sit on, as well as balls you can kick around. Awesome, right? Yeah, awesome. 

So the fun part of the review. After dark, it becomes an adult only area. That's right kids, no entry after a certain time period. You have to be 21 or older to enter the container park after 9 p.m.? (I think it's something like that) and that's when the fun happens. Sure, some of the shops are closed, but the bars and places to eat are still available. Don't worry, the playground is also still open! You know you want to have a few beers and go down the 3 container story high slide. You know you do. I did and it was amazing. Hanging out with a bunch of adults that like to have fun and play with blocks, balls, and slide down slides is probably the best thing ever. Add some alcohol to the mix and it just becomes the best experience in the world. 

If you have children, I recommend coming here during the day and let them ride on the slide, or heck join them! If you are an adult, I recommend coming here at night and riding on the slide! I may like the slide, a little. Maybe. Either way, the mantis, the atmosphere, and the slide are just 3 of the many awesome reasons you should come and visit the container park. Oh and live bands. I mentioned that too, right? 

Now I want to go there again.

The good - it is a great place to walk around if you have a few minutes, with live music during the day and night, a playground for kids, and several shops in shipping containers.

The not so good - the shops are small, there is very little interesting here, several are closed or closing, and the food choices are slim.

It is a good concept but has not met its potential yet. Still, if you work down town and want a nice place to walk around for lunch, this is it (at least until it is 100 degrees out.

Fabulous shopping experience in the art district downtown...good, visible security, you sign in with a lock on a heart that you can check out every time you go there....no charge.  2 stories and user friendly with elevators or stairs, a presentation point for performances that I thought was a petting zoo...huge choice of adequate restaurants and a couple of gift shops.  No valet and limited parking for handicapped.

This place is great! I was so impressed and will back again. I went with friends for brunch and walked around a bit after. I cannot wait to come back with my daughter. This place is perfect for an outing with the family. There are great restaurants and little shops for the adults and a big outdoor area for the kids.
What a fun spot to come and have a chill day with friends and family. Really cool "box" shops all out of containers and other cool places within walking distance.

Finally made it down here... and this review may change once I visit at night and with a pretty lady on my arm. I basically walked around and took pictures/video and a few "to-go" menus for whenever I return. The concept is quite nice, I give it that. But sheesh, sooo small inside these places. Maybe I should lighten up since it's "containers." It's summer and eating outside is NOT my kind of thing. But hey, the vibe seems pretty cool, something new to the scene. I saw a stage so I'm assuming they play movies or have live bands play at night. Not too busy from what I can see, unlike LV blvd. I intend to review each establishment individually. I really want to review "Simply Pure" the next time I visit for some healthy vegan food. I heard the owner has lived in Ghana and I've been there myself so that'll be a conversation starter. Any who, I bought a bag of popcorn from LV kettle corn and left. I'm giving an overall 4 stars because I believe I will sorta like a few places once I come back. See ya next time.

Fun place to take your family. We just saw this as an option on one of those 25 places to take your kids in Vegas type lists and it dod not disappoint. Kids ran around and played while we waited in comfortable outside loungers, very cool.

The first time I came to the park, I was by myself and just walked around, scoping things out.  It wasn't too busy that first time, as it was a December Friday morning before the holidays.  The second visit was today, January 2nd, 3:00pm, accompanied by my two little cousins, 4 and 6-year-old brothers, and my 17-year-old son.  Today the park was a beehive of activity with winter break still happening.  There were kids running helter skelter all over the tree house and adjacent playground; the little cousins were in heaven.  They immediately ran away from me once we entered the playground/tree house area, which is nicely guarded by a security person at the gate.  This way, kids cannot escape the area without someone watching, resulting in the worst thing ever, a lost child.  Most parents/guardians were either in the playground or right outside of it, keeping keen eyes on all the activity, which was plenty.  The teen spent the time exploring the shops of the park and making fun of the hipsters.  He tried to teach me how to detect said hipsters and I think it has to do with clothes and visible tattoos, but I'm still not sure.  For a breather, the boys and I went to ChillSpot by Sasapops, which is conveniently located right next to the playground.  Smoothies for the boys and halo-halo for me, then it was back to more running, jumping, and playing.  The grand finale was a group of drummers outside the entrance of the park.  They provided bongos, tambourines, cowbells, and other percussion instruments for kids to play in a circle, led by one energetic drummer in the middle.  The giant metal grasshopper sculpture out front spewed fire from its antennae and that added to the show.  All in all, we had a great time and I would highly recommend this place for kids of all ages, but especially children who will enjoy the playground.  My cousins can't stop talking about it so we'll be back soon.

I came here last month while in Vegas for a wedding. It was a lot of fun! We went at around 10:30pm on a Friday night. The slide and the games were very fun. It was very laid back and a cool atmosphere with only adults there that late. I highly recommend it!

My husband and I love coming here! We always get really good food and drinks. WE love Big Ern's BBQ! I like the little unique shops, and obviously the structure of the park! We like coming late Saturday nights and playing the game in the middle of the park! We also love that there is a stage that plays live music and a grass area with seating! We also really like how close it is to some fun bars and Fremont experience!

This is a great addition to downtown. It's super innovative, but not fully complete. I'm happily giving it 4 stars based on potential alone. They are building more bars inside and the potential for a nice block party on weekends is there. They have cute little shops and it is 21+ after 9PM. Before that though, they have an awesome playground place for kids and a stage for performances. CAN'T WAIT to see this place grow. Such innovation. Just too new for 5 stars.

The night we were there to eat at PERCH, Container Park had live karaoke for a donation event, and it was very entertaining. Although I could tell the couches were wet from a previous rainstorm (Vegas, you rain wussies:P), it didn't deter people from plopping down on the grass to enjoy themselves. 

The event was live karaoke with a real back up band for a cause. If you donate, you get to sing, and people get to watch you. 

What's most impressive about container park is that it's an exercise in restraint and efficiency. Most restaurants and stores and tiny, but it just means everything that's there serves a very succinct purpose, just like the park itself.

I have to applaud Vegas for this, and my hometown (Seattle) could stand to take a page from this book. I hope Vegas continues it's revitalization of downtown!
My four year old son loves this playground!!!! There are three different slides to choose from and it has a cool treehouse feel to it. He didn't want to leave!

Really a cool place!
ive been downtown dozens of times but never gone through the container park area. Plus i landed some amazing kettle corn!!!

This is a very cool business park made out of cargo containers. It has a giant metal praying mantis at the front entrance who has it's antennae tips on  fire at night. The juxtaposition of the containers, colors and the clever use of balconies and walkways make this a winning design. Would definitely come back here at night.

Container Park was billed as a place that was going to be "generating tons of revenue for Downtown blah blah blah OMG Zappos."

What is Container Park? A nice looking place for food trucks to have a "brick and mortar" (or shipping container) location and a bunch of irrelevant, overpriced boutiques that nobody is buying anything from.

I would be absolutely shocked if this place was actually turning profits in the next few years, if it will still be open. Apart from the eating establishments, the stores are not geared toward local people who hang out Downtown or tourists that stay on Fremont. 

I'm not sure what anyone was thinking putting in so many random boutiques - places that have two of the same item, say 2 trendy skirts by an unknown label in two different sizes for $260 a piece. These aren't Fremont Street prices. If you want to charge that, go to Crystals. That's too pricy for even Fashion Show. The stores that aren't selling clothes for whatever reason thought it would be a good idea to try to sell their Etsy-kitsch crafts here and pay rent to do so. 


Walking past every store, you see the same thing - an empty store with a cashier looking down into their lap while on their phone. I can tell these places are making soooo much money to put back into the downtown economy. PSH. I feel like I'm the only person who can see how gimmicky this Downtown Project is.

So... while I guffaw at this nonsense, everyone else can keep on talking about how great it is.

Parking. No. Nope. No. It's metered street parking. Get out of here. So ridiculous.

I've seen grown men with handlebar mustaches sitting by themselves on the fake lawn playing with legos. There's stuff for kids to do, but after 9, it's just a bunch of hipsters being hipsters. Ugh.

Before 9, you can't kick your way through the strollers and babies running through the legs of adults carrying beers. It's weird. Why are you taking your kids to basically an adult hangout space?

These drunk adults tend to be the ones going up and down the tube slides, even before it's 21+, so keep an eye out on your kids so they don't get squashed on the toys by some chick in thick black glasses with a chest piece tattoo of cats while she wears a rockabilly sundress.

I LOVE Container Park! Every time I go to Container Park, I have a blast! There are lots of cool stores and places to eat there, not to mention the adult-sized playground! They also have live music most days. Coolest beans.

As far as the playground, there are like 3 or 4 slides, all really tall and really fun! If you think you're too old to ride slides, think again! You won't regret getting onto these. Super fun!

Also the food at Pinches Tacos is excellent!

My kids love this place! Their faces are so flushed from climbing the tree house house to slide down the slide. And they have very nice 'Downtown Rangers' who attend the kids area. Kids have to be dropped off and picked by an adult at the gate door...and they are strict. Kids 6 and below have to be chaperoned by an adult.

We came in early evening so we have shade to sit under and temp is cooler. Really fun place and hang out. Lots of food and drinks...pricey but good.

Thought it was time to update my review. Now that it it not so crazy packed, it's much more enjoyable. We have gone for their outdoor movie show and it was really fun. I love the large "grass" area, and the kids loved the huge building blocks. The park has been much less busy the last few times we have come and the kids have had a great time. I will say the only downside now is the food places are incredibly tiny (a line of 3 people is overwhelming in those shops) and pretty overpriced. But, it is a very unique place to visit and it really feels like you are not in Vegas (minus the scorching heat of course, lol) so it is worth it to visit every so often and experience something different :-)

After eating a wonderful donut, I wandered around trying to burn some of the donut out of my belly. I wandered over here and entered the park. The giant preying Mantis greeted me.  From what I understand, it blasts huge gouts of fire at sunset. While that'd be cool to see, a thirty foot long metal mantis is a pretty cool thing to see on it's own. After photographing the thing, I wandered into the stores.  
     There are three levels of stores of assorted items, trinkets and foods.  They all seem to be constructed from old shipping containers. There is also a way cool playground in the middle, and one of the stores is in an old train at the far end of the park. Which is also cool. As I wandered around the stores however, I discovered that I didn't really need anything from any of them.  They were all kinda earthy crunchy hippy things. If I hadn't just eaten my fill of donuts, I might have tried some of the restaurants in here.   
     There was a meat and hot sauce store. That one was interesting and the most likely one I would buy from.  But the giant bug, the way cool playground and old train. Super cool. I'd be back to see the mantis spew fire into the sky.

  The place is super cool. It's free to get into, and super fun to poke around in.  The shops just weren't my cup of tea.

This place is very eclectic. Great for people watching. Came here to see my friends band tonight. I was surprised to get carded as I walked in. I guess the summer concerts are 21+.
Concert was on a small stage with ample grass area for fans. One drawback is that most of the shops are closed by 9. Most restaurants were open.

This place always has something happening. The security is nice, the surrounding and ambiance is great. This place holds some of the best shops and restaurants in all of Las Vegas. A must go to on any Las Vegas Trip.

I love it here. Wish Vegas was filled with more spots like this. I also love downtown Vegas so it makes me happy that they're spending time and money to make it better. I think it's a cool concept, a few cute restaurants and shops, place to relax or listen to music. I don't think any of the shops are amazing but overall I really enjoy it. Went to the wine walk which was a good idea. The views are pretty. I think it's just a nice stop If you're already downtown and want to hang out.

First of all, the preying mantis...why is it so big and fantastic? Lol. This is a unique place. I mean who makes a shopping center out of shipping containers? And it has 3 floors and a stage for concerts. Places to eat as well. With an interactive playgrounds for the kiddies. Great idea, Vegas. Great idea.

A must see in Vegas.  About 15 minutes from the strip and its alongside Freemont Street.  The Container Park is an open air shopping center with many great restaurant options, live entertainment, full size move screen, games and interactive games.  The Treehouse include a 33-foot-tall slide, NEOS play system, over sized foam building blocks, and much more.  It was created from repurposed shipping containers and was created by Zappos Tony Hsieh.  Great creation, Mr. Hsieh!

I loved this place!  On a whim we decided to go last minute.  The architecture, artistry, and modern feel are dead on!  Loved the Loveless art studio & park with band.  The interaction with adults & children is what makes this so successful.

Fun place to hang out and people watch. Great play areas for kids. Delicious food and interesting shops. Misters keep the outdoor space comfortable even in summer time. Whenever I am downtown I usually stop by.

This review is from a daytime visit. I REALLY want to go for a night time visit. All the lights and the praying mantis fire would be excellent to see.

There's a few places to grab something to eat, and we opted for Pinches Tacos. Yums. Get their combo plate for the best value.

When you walk in, you've got the stores on the left that go up to 2 floors and then the right goes up to 3 floors. The one store that stood out to me is Art Box. Nice jewelry among other stuff. Support all these artists and small stores! :) There's another store where they make pretty cool shot glasses out of alcohol bottles and they can help you with custom ones. Great gift ideas in some of these stores.

Take a picture up where it says Container. Great for pictures when you stick out your head and all :D.

The vibe I'm getting is that it's a pretty nice place to chill at. Especially when the weather is very fall-like and you can bundle up and drink with friends (preferably at night :b).

This place is pretty cool, I had read @ it b4 but, wasn't all that interested in going there... Turned out to be close to VegeNation a favorite place near Fremont St. So in we go... WOW cute fun shops& restaurants a little park and stage for concerts nice different little area, great for all ages!! The heart locks are cool... The preying mantis is from BURNING MAN and spits fire which is pretty cool and they have a circle of drums they let kids play...They love it! I loved it and was pretty surprised by how much fun it was, Interesting place, reading about it just doesn't do it justice... Go check it out for yourselves!!

Recently, I went to the Container Park to check out a few spots. I've been reading reviews for a long time, and finally decided to stop by.

As a whole, the container park really feels to me like an unfinished Hipster idea. Take some recycled shipping containers and put stores, restaurants, and other businesses in them. The idea sounds really cool; however, I feel the restaurants are really lacking.

The playground in the middle is really cool and using train cars in the back is an awesome idea. The grass; however, looks really fake and feels really cheap. Why even do this? This is Las Vegas. It's in the desert. Go with that... Use that as your theme.

Anyway, as a whole, I have no real desire to go back outside of visiting Oak and Ivy again. There are places similar to this around me that have much better execution.
Love this place, totally different day vs night, I love to grab a drink and meander in the evening, all the business are super friendly.

The Downtown Container Park is an interactive learning experience for children of all ages. I appreciate the staff who monitor the safety on the playground. Grab a SasaPop after playing and enjoy eating on the lawn or table setting near the playground. The park opens at 10:00 AM, I found it to be a great place to go for all seasons.  Try story time at the Las Vegas Library at 833 Las Vegas Blvd. and then spend outdoor time at The playground.

This place is a lot of fun and it's family friendly. I was blown away by the praying mantis shooting fire. The kids and adults will love the slides. The shops have lots of different stuff to look at. I had a great time here.

Very nice layout and family friendly shopping area it what used to be a blighted area of downtown, drove by it a couple of times just never stopped in until this trip, nice selection of stores and restaurants, play area looked like it was being enjoyed by quite a few kids, not too crowded but enough foot traffic to keep the stores in business. Didn't have a lot of time to look at everything so we will need to come back and take a longer look at more of the shops on our next visit to Las Vegas.

Definitely one of the lost interesting places I have ever seen. I just walked around to see what was there also into the toy store...which I loved. It was very secure and actually pretty relaxing to walk around to see the stores/restaurants, etc. Such a cool concept!

This is seriously such a cute place to come to if you happen to be downtown. 

During the day and early evening you can bring your kids to play in the playground or on the lawn and at night they clear anyone under 21 out and turn it into an adult only zone. 

The shops and restaurants are quirky and cute. 

 It also doesn't hurt that I am a bit of a pyro and LOVE the fire shooting praying mantis.  

All this and it's free to get into?   Yep I'm there.

Awesome place to meet up with friends and just hang out.

It's located in downtown so you know this place has a lot of culture. Outside is the fire preying mantis which has been seen multiple times at First Friday. There's only one entrance so you can't really miss it. They don't allow outside drinks from what I heard.

There's a big Tarzan-esque playground in the middle with "imaginative playground" materials scattered across the play area in front. There's several shops and restaurants to eat at if you're here plus TONS of seating. If you've got an eye for art then this place is definitely for you. A lot of the stores feature art from local artists which is awesome. 

If you're planning on bringing your kids here do it well before 9 since they make the park a 21+ venue even with parental supervision. If you're in the park before 9 and are under 21 they may ask you to leave but I wasn't carded even tho I'm a 21 year old looking like I'm 16.

If you haven't been here yet and don't mind trying to find parking then you should definitely come here. The fact that it's located close to Insert Coins, Vanguard and Commonwealth makes it convenient. I just wish this place had a big parking lot or perhaps underground parking.
Check us out May 8-14th. Bring in our flyer for a free tote. Downtown Container Park is a must see.

This place was awesome! 
A diamond in the rough. 
I was so happy to be around normal people and not weird tweaker gambling types that cruise around some of the casinos. The only reason I'm giving it 4 stars is because all that white shit floating around is stucco and weird stuff from the construction going on across the street. It was all over everything and getting in everyone's hair and clothes and food if you ate outside which was the only option for most of the places here. Although it was Christmas time and it appeared like it was snow ask the local store owners they hate it and can't even open their windows due to health codes and this crap coming inside there restaurant. 
Other then that we ate at the hot dog place and pinche tacos super good but VERY expensive. 
Nachos, potato rolled tacos and a bean and cheese burrito plus a small juice drink and two shots of tequila came to $40!

While I get what is trying to be done here, there are just some things that are fundamentally wrong that can't be overlooked.

Everything is overpriced. I went into every shop, every food place, every boutique, and just couldn't justify it. I bought a pair of the cheapest, most decent-looking pair of earrings I could find - at Forever21, they'd cost $5 - FOR $15 - but *only* because one of mine fell out and I needed to put something in there.

I ate at some sandwich place and paid $8 for a grilled cheese. Hello, I just moved from NEW YORK CITY, and if I were to get a sandwich for $8, I CAN ASSURE YOU, it would be more than just two pieces of bread and some cheese. They would at least put a tomato on it, or some lettuce, or some SPICES??? Or SOMETHING to give it some flavor. Carmelized onions? Hell, I'd even take some raw red onions. Or chopped up raw garlic. Just do something to pizzazz it for THAT price. I still am in disbelief I paid for this, if you couldn't tell, and this happened two days ago.

(For reference - this is what I can expect for **$7** - IN MANHATTAN, in the LOWER EAST SIDE, one of NYC's most expensive neighborhoods, at a grilled cheese-specific restaurant called, "Little Muenster."

THE WORLD'S BEST BREAKFAST SANDWICH
Crispy Pork Belly/Soft Omelette/Gruyere/Gouda/Kewpie/Amy's Roll. 

AND BREAD FROM AMY'S. I rest my case.)

I am hopefully for the pork n' beans place and the taco place, which I have yet to try. The BBQ was fucking awful; I have no idea how that place is even in business or why they'd want them to be a part of this new-and-upcoming attraction.

The slides were cool, mostly because they were free. And the grassy patch area where bands can play - also free. But I'm scared to see how much it's going to cost to go to the *cool, hip* barbershop that's about to open. Yeesh.

All in all, it's a cool spot for people to walk around in, look at stuff, and take their kids. It *is* a glorified outdoor mall, after all.

HOWEVER, that being said, this is NOT a place meant to cater to the LOCAL Las Vegas downtown-er. As far as I know, from living here for as long as I have, most people here work in service, or work for a start-up... which means they make not enough money to spend $20 on a lame-ass sandwich and a beer, plus tax and tip. People don't go to Commonwealth for a reason - why would I want to pay $10 for a BEER... OFF THE STRIP? What? I thought I left the meatpacking district 3,000 miles behind me?

I'll probably come to sit and read a book (assuming that I don't constantly run into all of the 50 people I know in this city because, well, where else is there to go?) but probably won't buy anything else any time soon. MAYBE a taco, cuz a girl's gotta eat.

Just be true to who you are, Vegas, and stop trying to be other places. It's making me very, very depressed.

*****EDIT*****

Must apologize to shop owners for saying their items are overpriced. Should be obvious that it is NOT their fault, but WHOEVER decided to make the rent at the container park $9/sq ft! THAT IS THE PRICE IN THE HEART OF MANHATTAN. I am appalled, and deeply apologetic, Las Vegas. You're next in the bubble of cities-in-which-its-native-residents-will-suddenly-be-priced-out-of. I send my regards.

We LOVE, love, LOVE, this place!!! 
It's soo much fun to let the kids play while we get to sip wine, watch live music, and eat gourmet cheeses. 

With free entry, so many food options, 3 levels of boutique shopping, and 2 different play areas, it's fun for all ages. 

Once you get there, there is street parking and parking lot options. Once you're inside, there are clean bathrooms on both ends of the park.
Really cool spot!  Loved the art, the space, the whole concept!

Nice addition to downtown, but I just wonder how many of the shops will survive. They are all extremely specialized- for example, there's a store with only Disney paintings, one with only watches and another with only beef jerky. The live music is nice and there's a lot of outdoor space so I feel like this will become more popular once the weather is warmer in the evening.

I think this place is so cute! I would highly suggest this to people who want to get away from the vegas scene for an afternoon. Plus, in the middle of the park there is a huge playground so its perfect for kids. There are cute little boutique shops including an old school candy shop, a vape shop, and an awesome toy store! While was there, there wasn't any performances going on but there were several families sitting on the grass playing with their children. I look forward to coming here next time I am in vegas!

Very unique urban park in downtown Las Vegas built entirely of containers.

Nice collection of shops and restaurants albeit a little touristy. 

A highlight is the great artwork on the property.

One of the best concepts that should totally belong in the Bay Area. However, Downtown Vegas did do this repurposed shipping container shopping, food and drink area pretty well. This is a totally family friendly place and has tons of things for the kids to do if you want to just hang out and grab a bite to eat or sip on something refreshing. Upon entering, there's some really cool art installations that were left from Life is Beautiful. At night you can see the flames coming out of the giant bug's antennas, which is super cool.
As for the interior, there are a handful of places to eat, drink and shop at. They even have a wedding chapel on the 3rd floor. Some of the places that I really enjoy in there are the toy store, which has tons of unique things and Bin 702, which is a bar with really awesome food. Overall, if you're in the area definitely make it a point to go check this area out.

If you wanna find something new to do, off the strip, container park has lots of shops, and a mini playground for children to play at, so, very family-friendly.

I've only been there once, so what I remember is when you first arrive, there is this big praying mantis, that shoots out fire for a 5 min music performance. This performance happens every 15 minutes. Also, there is this "love lock" that's pretty cool to take a photo of.

When walking in, there is the popcorn store, a very popular hotdog place & bar. There was other stores too, but I forgot what they were.

Since we were there during October, there was a huge display of pumpkins, and Halloween decorations.

I plan to go there again one day, check out more displays, and more stores in the future.

Awesome Park
My wife has been trying to talk me into selling our house and moving into a shipping container. Crazy right! I thought so myself. She has shown me videos of shipping containers that had been turned into homes, really nice ones too. I was still not buying it (literally)

After visiting Container Park, I'm considering it now. Why? Because I'm so impressed with how they transformed shipping containers into amazing shops, restaurants and a playground with a huge treehouse in the center of this park. Wow. 

The Treehouse is made from shipping containers (and recycled material) as well. What an awesome treehouse. My son went up and down it for almost 2 hours. It's super creative and goes up 3 or 4 floors. They had a slide on the top floor. A kid's dream treehouse for sure. 

The playground had some big foam pieces of varying shapes and size that the kids can use to build bridges, house or a pretend spaceship that my son built. 

The playground also had an electronic touch game. Eight post with two lights each (top and bottom). The lights would flash either red or green and you're suppose to touch it as it randomly flashes either color. You get points for touching the lights and it kept score. Great for game for the kids to play individually or as a team. 

The best part of the playground was security. It is fenced in with only one way in or out and it was monitored by a staff member of the park. A+ in my book. 

Shops and restaurants flank the playground/ treehouse. Three levels on each side with an eclectic variety. BBQ joint, hot dog stand, tacos, clothing stores, unique toy store, even an art gallery and a lot more. Grownups won't get bored here either. 

Entrance: if you see a giant praying mantis, you found the park. Lol. 

Parking was easy. They have a lot across the street. It's a pay to park place. Very reasonably priced. 

The park itself is free. No entrance fee, another A+ in my book. 

It was cold in late December and the heaters they had all over the park helped. 

What an amazing way to re-purpose shipping containers. Would I move into one? Maybe. It's definitely not a definite NO anymore. LOL. 

Go see it for yourself, it's definitely worth a visit (specially if you have kids).

It's been about two years. The curiosity is gone and so are the dreaded crowds. Don't get me wrong. Definitely still crowded, but a nice outing type of crowded, not Disneyland bustle. 
They have so many cute little shops and eateries. 
It's conveniently located to Fremont and in the middle of the newly renovated downtown. A hipster vibe that I couldn't love more. The play place is fun for kids of all ages. They even do Family movie nights! I'm so glad I gave this place another shot. We'll be going at least once a month..... Just because.

This place is so great especially if you love repurposing. Perch is also awesome to have a great view of the park and a delicious lunch. I love to go and just walk around on a nice fall day. It does get extremely warm in the spring and summer so be wary of that. All in all a great place for families, couples, and singles alike. This place has a little bit for everyone.

I finally agreed to go with some Hipster friends whom have been prior and said they really enjoyed it. We went later one night so the shops were closed and only a few people left hanging out. Although from what I have heard, these boutique shops are way out of the norm selling silly items at ridiculous high prices. Um, no thanks!

I have to agree that there are some really cool and fun photo ops to be had here. It is pretty much just a very small outdoor shopping venue and some places to eat. The star of the show is the Tree house with slides for the kids to enjoy during the day and adults after hours.

In my opinion Container Park has a huge identity crisis. Is not really a place to bring kids, I mean other than the Tree house and slides, what else is there to do with the kids? They should have just promoted it as an adults hang out spot. Anyhow CP you just don't impress me enough to come back and pay for street parking. I don't see this really getting any better. They have already had issues with some of the stores closing due to no business. This place could be Awesome if they just changed it up and got some better merchants. 

There is not a whole lot to do here at night, maybe if we came in the day time it would be a different and more exciting place to hang out?

After all of the hoopla, I have to say I am disappointed. I must have missed a lot by not visiting in the day time with all of these 4 star Yelp reviews, something is going on. lol

What the hell, at least I checked it out and know what it is now. I can honestly say that I will survive in my crazy world without another visit here. 

I am happy about the positive and new vibe it has given the Downtown community though :)
Love he people and atmosphere great for the kids to play and the parents to relax food is really good and the entertainment is great

Love having this spot downtown. It's like a present within a present within another present. A mix of restaurants, bars, boutiques, and a stage for performances. There is even a kid's play area in the center. 

Surrounding parking is pay by the hour, unless you're lucky enough to grab something a few blocks down. 

Check the events calendar because there are a ton of events hosted here throughout the year. 

My only complaint is that I still haven't had the energy to go exploring some of the higher level boutiques, which means other folks might not be either. Laziness. It's an epidemic.

In my heart I feel like this is one of the best places to visit in Vegas. Since I lived here (less than a year), I have been to this place at least once a month. Dude outside in the mechanical praying Mantis plays music as he shoots fire in the air out of the testicles. At night it turns into an adult only spot. The bars are cool, plus at night they play movies on this huge screen some nights.

This was my favorite find of my weekend Vegas trip! Well worth the walk down Fremont Street to what I imagine is more of a locals spot. 
The Container Park is just as named- several shipping containers, stacked 3 floors on top of each other, have been repurposed into shops and restaurants, with a large, clean play space and nicely landscaped open seating area in the middle of the venue. The containers are large enough for people to walk in, and with large windows and open garage-door style bay doors, they feel open and inviting. We wandered into several restaurants and bars with our drinks for a relaxing and less hectic Friday night than one typically thinks about on Fremont street.

Just not sold on this place.
It seems to have morphed into a giant playground with shops/restaurants/etc. as a secondary attraction!
I'm sure it's done heaps to improve Downtown's image (?) and offer alternatives to nearby residents, but I've been here 4 times and still feel lukewarm about it. I've not imbibed at one of the many establishments serving adult bevvies but have heard good things about most of them!
I mention this place to visitors since it is fairly unique and may be worth showing to out of towners.

Not sure why it's taken me so long to review container park, but better late than never. 
First off, when I first heard of container park I was intrigued, and once it opened it's definately become a staple of downtown and a place that I end up taking a lot if my out of town friends. 
The first thing you'll notice about container park is the giant praying mantis art car on the outside. If you've been to burning man or are familiar with the art there you'll notice and love it. For all my other friends it's always such a giant shock when the flames burst from it. 
The concept of container park is an entire shopping center made from shipping container, it's a novel concept and it works better with some stores more than others. There's several restaurants, a few bars and clothing and art boutiques. It's a perfect encapsulation of the new downtown Vegas. 
One factor that really bumps it up for me is it's dual use. During the daytime it's a great family friendly park where kids can play on the slides and grass, but after 9 it's 21 and over and the only place I know where drunk adults can have a playground to themselves. 
There's also the staging area where they have concerts or a live band playing a lot and during the summer they're goin to be doing movies. 
The only real downsides in my opinion is that the parking is horrible, but that's atypical of downtown and that when it first opened, some of the businesses weren't really made to run out of such limited retail space, but it's definately improved and I love coming here

I really like this place. It offers a variety of things for people of all ages. It is something different for the locals that don't want to always walk fremont or be surrounded by crowds. I subscribed to their events emails and they have a lot of different things to participate in. I went to the Spring wine walk this year and it was GREAT. The park for the kids is nice, since they are closed in I am not worried about them running off.
Honestly this is pretty...meh. Not a lot of people, seemed somewhat abandoned other than the poor shop owners with minimal traffic. Tried weekend and week day, not much of a difference.

Great place to come if you have kids. They can play in the secure kids area with no worries. Great vibe especially in the early evenings. Cool little shops and eateries inside. Hard to believe you are in downtown Las Vegas! I come here all the time and have never had a bad experience.

I'm a first timer and I gave it 4 stars! I enjoyed the fire mantis at the front, I noticed people gathering up on the steps, it's the perfect distance from the fire and view of it all. The park is very creative and modern, something new for Vegas. You are greeted by security which is great it's secure to bring little ones during the day. There's many establishments inside, whether you're vegetarian or vegan, there's many place to choose you can't see everything in one visit, but this is the perfect place to meet up, browse the stores, have the kids get a little play date with the cutest tree house in the middle and a huge screen for movies or music videos. Such an enjoyable place to be!

Wanting to get away from the typical canopy vibe, I decided to cross the Boulevard over to Fremont East one afternoon and made my way to Container Park. This is a very neat looking place with some attractive looking retailers and restaurants. I respected that they encouraged recycling of everything used in the park, including the compost-friendly plates and dinnerware. The playground in the courtyard made it appealing for the many families I observed. 

I would definitely return here at night when I can enjoy one of the park's scheduled performances along with my meal.

I don't really get it. There isn't much to Container Park to entice to me stay more than a few minutes. There is only one place I have any interest in coming to visit here.

The stores are small since the entire place is essentially made out of shipping containers. Not much bang for your buck so have low expectations and you'll be good to enjoy the novelty and move on.

I visited the downtown container park a year ago (almost to the day) with a couple of my girlfriends. We were looking for a reason to get away from the strip during the day so we decided to take a trip into downtown to just walk around and see all the neat new stuff down there. Our final destination was the container park and it was the perfect place to grab a bite to eat, sit outside and rest our feet while enjoying some music and people watching and then to do some shopping before heading back to the strip. I highly recommend this place for families because there were great play areas for kids. This is a really neat concept that I hope spreads to more towns.

This Place is great fun!  

If you find yourself in down Town Las Vegas around Fremont Street you must go here. 
Its a special kind of park made out with colorful shipping containers that also includes bars, restaurants and some minor shops.  


We tried the BBQ Place (Pulled pork Sandwich to die for) as well as the mexican taco Place with devine and authentic (no not like Taco Bell......) fish tacos. A friendly advice here, if you ask for hot sauce, you get HOT sauce........   ; )
Really fun and unique. Great food. Great place for kids to play. Quirky shops. Arrive before sunset so you can experience drum circle and praying mantis fireballs!  Love the hot dog place!

I had read online about the Praying Mantis...so I wanted to check this place out when I went downtown to Freemont place. I was surprised how the area has changed for the better the last 3 years...they extended Freemont and created a neon sign street and opened some new bars and restaurants. My friend and I were not expecting the mantis to spit fire which was extra cool and the guy must have been on a roll that night because it fired in sequence alot. We decided to check out the park, which is small...especially when the center us taken up by a children's playground? There were a couple of bars and restaurants and some stores that were not that enticing. Save your time, come see the mantis from outside and use that time elsewhere. I give it 3-stars because the mantis is that cool!! Check out my photo to see.

I don't care what a container park is, this place is awesome!  

I had no idea what to expect going in, and afterwards I found myself enchanted with this place and wanting to ask all my friends why they haven't been here yet. It's basically a little community of shops, restaurants, bars, a hair salon, treehouse of slides, and outdoor stage with live music. During the day, kids roam around with their parents. But after 9pm, they kick all the little kids out and the big little kids get to play with all their stuff!  The treehouse side (as epic as it is) looks super unstable and like a lawsuit is waiting to happen, but it was really fun to ride.

I love the open concept of the whole place. Live music is awesome. You can order a drink from here and drink it over there. You can order food from there and eat it over here. No problem. I really liked it.

It's like nothing else we have in Vegas, and I like it. 

So, why haven't you gone yet?!

The is a really cool hip place to go for a date or just because. I love how they are big on recycling. The atmosphere was great and there's a little play place for kids in two different spots so it's a nice place to bring kids as well. Loved the pyrotechnic praying mantis and the heart you can put locks on like the gate/bridge in Paris.

Love this space and the use of the containers to create unique shopping experiences.   The outdoor space is awesome for all ages and provides entertainment and special events which are perfect for the Fremont street area.  Parking just across the street makes for an easy in and out experience for those not wanting to have to park and walk a long distance to enjoy the park.  

You have to check out the lock heart at the entry!!

What a unique spot! Container Park is definitely worth checking out if you're on Fremont. You might not want to pop into any of the shops - even though there are tons of options - but even just hanging out in the outdoor space is fun. There's a great playground and lots of al fresco eating options. They also have a stage and have night movies and other events. (There's a calendar that's well displayed right when you enter.) Great for people watching.
